And good luck with the internet connection -- it hates my iPhone, surprised i can write this on a Mac :-) I guess it is much better than a year ago, when there was no wifi in the room at all!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I frequently visit Tokyo and usually stay at the New Otani.The service is excellent, the rooms are nice and well equipped. the variety of restaurants, is remarkable .The hotel is very close to an efficient transportation junction.So it is my hoe in Tokyo.
user_name:
Elchanan H
Hod HaSharon, HaMerkaz, Israel

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed at Hotel New Otani on a recent business trip. Upon arrival I was greeted in typical Japanese style. Check in was smooth. My room was smaller than some I have had in Japan, but was big enough for me. Everything was great about the room, I was concerned about the small step up into the bathroom would cause me pain at some point at night during my stay, but it worked out that I did not. Breakfasts were good but a little pricer than I think they should have been. And the maid service on room was not until middle of afternoon. ( I was the very end room of a hall.) however it was still a very enjoyable stay and provide me a great place to rest during my business trip.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Excellent hotel and amazing garden!you can enjoy your breakfast Watching an amazing japanese garden.Food and staff are excellent.From the Narita airport you can reach the hotel through Bus limousine in 1 and 1/2 hour,and it cost 30€.Location is good and quite.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at this Hotel while for business in Tokyo. The Hotel is very well maintained and the staff was very friendly and attentive. The hotel complex is huge and the various restaurants offer a wide variety of food choices, including a typical traditional Japanese restaurant in the Japanese garden. The room was nice and very well equipped. The room rates are acceptable for Tokyo standards.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I must admit, this was my first time in Tokyo and I fully expected that hotel prices would be exorbitant. I suspect at some of the newer establishments they are, but the New Otani, at a little over $200 AUD - really surprised me. Try getting a decent room in Sydney for that price - it's often quite difficult.Sure this hotel is old, I believe it was built for the 1964 Olympics, but the older style rooms are more than compensated by the gardens (providing a beautiful oasis in the city) and it's proximity to the metro and restaurants (all the shopping areas are only a few stops away).Eating in the hotel is expensive - though the french cafe Aux Bacchanales is a good option for breakfast. Unless you really have to eat on premise, get out there. There's nothing more fun that pointing at the pictures on a menu and seeing what turns up on the plate! Can't wait to go back to Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel has all a visitor would want and need from plenty of restaurant choices, competent staff, beautiful setting and conveniently location. Room was very well laid out with bathroom nicely set apart from sleeping area.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel was built for the Tokyo olympics, but was not renewed since then.I recognised the "old modern" style which was typical for those days. In my opinion the hotel lost all of its glory (furniture in bars etc is really old, with scratches etc). The room itself was kind of smelly (old). The location is convenient (not far from metro). Restaurants are way too expensive and old.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is a huge complex which consist of three main buildings - I stayed at The Main, which I would recommend as the Garden Tower seems to be popular with groups.The hotel complex itself is much grander than the actual rooms - these are very spacious and clean, come with all the trimmings (kimonos and slippers changed daily, newspaper every day, perfectly working wireless and wired internet, etc), but the rooms are dated - the shower in particular is from a different era, with shower head which cannot be oriented in any way.This apart, the hotel has its charm, and some of the shortcomings (e.g. pool of inadequate capacity given the hotel size) are more than compensated by the wonderful breakfast - get a rate which includes it, we could choose between four different restaurants every morning.Location is quite convenient, with various line (metro, JC and urban rail) nearby, and Roppongi about half an hour walk away.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed in The Main for 4 nights in August. We had a lovely room with two beds overlooking the pool and garden area and city view - we could also see Mt Fuji. The hotel had a mix of business and tourist guests and catered for birth very well. The staff were helpful and attentive. We had a great evening buffet meal in the revolving restaurant in The Main - expensive but a great experience and fantastic selection of food with great chefs. We also had the buffet breakfast twice and again there was a great selection of food, although we did have to queue for quite a while before we could get a seat on both mornings. We didn't ever explore the whole hotel as it's so big and we were out and about but there were lots of restaurants and shops that we walked by and saw the signposts too! We did explore the Japanese garden and it was lovely. The location is good with great access to the sub-way system within a few minutes walk. Local restaurants in a few minutes walk as well. Great location for our first stay in Tokyo and lovely hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is the second time I stay at the new otani and I think it’s great. Its value for money and as extra you get great service and a great garden where you can go have a small walk in the morning or simply stare at it from the breakfast restaurant. I hope you stay at these hotel and have fun I really recommend it.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Historical place. But five star service and maintenance. The room is larger than average Tokyo's hotel. The garden is amazing. Very clean. Bathroom amenities are Shiseido. Bathrobes provided, towels are many. Complimentary bottled water is provided (many Japanese hotels don't provide them). Breakfast is excellent. There are 3 restaurants for breakfast: Satsuki in the first floor is excellent. It provides Japanese food. The other one is located at 40th floor. Also Japanese food. But not as great as Satsuki. The other one, is in the Garden tower corridor, facing the garden. The view is wow, but food is poor. It provides continental breakfast. Only 3 minutes walking to Akasaka Mitsuke station. Their English is ok. They can forward your luggage to the airport or other hotel in other city, so no need to carry the luggage around.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The hotel is part of a big, modern complex of several hotels and a lot of restaurants, coffee shops and a small shopping mall. The location near the parliament and many government offices make it a busy place. The hotel garden is spectacular and great to take a walk. Our room was nice, a bit on the small side and slightly dated, but very comfortable and clean. However, noise from guests in the next room was an issue. The walls are thin. However, service was very good and helpful. We visited during New Year and the atmosphere at the New Otani was very special with so many Japanese families coming for lunch or dinner or just meeting up with relatives. A lot of restaurants in Tokyo are closed during this time of the year, so the Otani was a good place to stay.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have been working in Japan and staying at the Hotel New Otani since 2001. I will stay there again next week, so I was curious and reading the reviews. I have always found this hotel to be clean, reasonably priced, and an oasis in Central Tokyo.The staff are always well organized, and pleasant. The hotel itself is huge, and has many dining and shopping options. The Main (Japanese style rooms) has been recently renovated, and the Tower was undergoing renovation when I was there last year. I always stay in the Tower with a view of the garden, nighttime Shinjiku, and on a clear day Mt Fuji.The best part of the hotel is the location. Within 5 minutes walking, you have access to Akasaka-Mitsuke station on one side, and Yotsuya station on the other. This gives you easy access to the main subway/train lines in Tokyo.The other location feature I wanted to mention is that around Akasaka-Mitsuke station there are many reasonable restaurants.With regard to the "no free pool", the outdoor pool is usually open the one week of Golden Week, and then only six weeks during the summer. If you are a member of their "New Otani Club", their rewards program, then the pool access is free. If not, it can be very expensive.Safe travels.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Completly deception...No free pool, awful room, also with a small bath that it seems a bidet...no socket close to the bed.....I wont recommend this hotel....I know what I talk (I´ve been at the Peninsula, Metropoll.....) this is terrible.....

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have now stayed 4 separate times a the New Otani. This being the most recent. The hotel is large and although not a true 5 star in terms of finishes and architecture, (it is quite dated) everything is in pristine condition and the rooms although set in the 90's still exceptionally comfortable.The stand out here is the Garden (400+years old on 10 acres of grounds in central Tokyo. An absolute luxury for hotel guests, second only I imagine the Imperial palace gardens for Tokyo. The Pool is also wonderful especially in the heat of summer. The fact that most guests seem to be Japanese, makes the experience in the New Otani Truly culturally immersive one.Enjoy what is a welcome calming respite in one of the worlds most happening cities.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is probably the largest hotel I've ever stayed so it took some time to get used to (like much of Tokyo, as a first-time visitor). However, there are many great offerings...so much so one wouldn't have to ever leave during their stay (which I no way endorse because the city of Tokyo was such an overwhelmingly stunning locale that I recommend all to experience). I did appreciate that the hotel could provide a proper king bed (because I am tall). And the size of the room and bathroom/shower was also adequate, but less furniture would have made the room feel a bit more spacious.The service was exceptional, even with the obvious language barrier. The front desk even printed maps to provide to our cab driver to help locate a difficult-to-find office location. I also liked the "make up room" button that you would press when you were ready for maid service. That is an innovation that more hotels should apply. The staff also assisted with a mailing issue (a post office is also on the grounds).There are an abundance of restaurants (of various cuisines) on the grounds. They are on the pricier side, but having a tropical drink at the Trader Vic's bar was fun and I do recommend enjoying a nice breakfast in the main dining room where one can experience the incredible view of their majestic garden (another high point of the hotel). The happy hour at the 40th floor bar was a good deal for cocktails and the nighttime view of Tokyo is likely unmatched in this neighborhood.The New Otani is a short walk from the Akasaka neighborhood, which offered numerous dining (Ninja was fun w/ tasty food) and nightlife options (Beer Horn and the Mermaid were cozy, but smoky little pubs). I also found the hotel was convenient to several traditional coffee shops near the Akaska-Mitsuke Metro station that I would frequent before beginning my day of sightseeing. There is also an enormous department store nearby (BIC Camera) that sells more products than you can imagine.My most pointed criticism of the New Otani was that the swimming pool wasn't opened during the time of my visit (in mid-July), which I found confusing because the very hot temperatures at the time would seemingly beckon one to visit the hotel pool.
user_name:
PrestigeWW
Washington DC, District of Columbia

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My previous stay at the New Otani dates back a few years, and has been rather forgettable. This time, we booked two nights in a Main Deluxe Room, as other hotels were unavailable. We had a few welcome/reminder e-mails prior to our stay, and check-in on the day was efficient. The room was above expectations, with a small lounge area with sofa, and had been recently refurbished. The hotel is notorious for its common areas: some feel like a giant shopping mall, but the gardens are outstanding for being in the centre of Tokyo. Excellent service throughout the stay, including proper information updates through in-room speakers during an earthquake (magnitude > 6, clearly felt in the room, but not unusual in Tokyo). Overall a very pleasant stay, albeit pricey at around JPY 40,000 per night - the quoted rate excludes tax as is common in Japan.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed at this hotel on business for two nights this week - it was not where I normally stay but it was perfectly adequate. It is a large complex with lots of restaurants and shops in the complex. There is a shopping street across the road but very little else around the hotel. I would not choose this location again but the hotel itself was very good with some great restaurants. The sushi restaurant was particularly good.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed at the Hotel New Otani for 3 nights in Tokyo. Having just come from the Grand Hyatt in Roponggi which was a minimilast boutique, it was nice to come to the Otani which is very traditionally Japanese in order to immerse myself in the Japanese culture. The hotel was built for the 1964 Olympics, and you can tell from the architecture with the domed top which was typical of hotels with revolving restaurants in those days. The ground level is the banquet floor, and the upper level is the busy lobby and front desk, which has a Japanese sculptural arrangement in the front. Uniformed bell people will usher you to the front desk, which quickly checked me in with old fashioned key, and not the plastic cards typical today. A very well dressed female bell person in complete uniform including a cap, just like the Pan Am flight attendants of yore, helped me with my bags and took time to show where everything is in my room. I have never seen female bell people in the US hauling my bags, so this is quite something getting used to. Best of all, no tipping is expected or required! The basic room at the Main Bldg is not the most spacious, but it does afford a view of the garden below. It has a sitting area, a big closet, flat screen TV with CNN, fridge with free water bottles, and a nice bathroom. I still had to get used to stepping up to go-I'm sure many people have tripped not being used to having to step up to go to the bathroom in the middle of the night. It also had the Japanese toilet with all the bells and whistles-a spout to wash and bidet, controls for water pressure, and the heat of your seat. Why hasn't this caught up in the USA?There is no flat iron in the closet, you'd have to call for one, have them bring it and sign in and out for it in one hour that you're given the time to use it. Some fire regulation, I am told. The first night I had internet connectivity issues which took an hour or so to fix.The breakfast at the main lounge downstairs is nice, you can have American or Japanese or continental. If you have Executive Lounge access (membership or more $) then you can eat there as well. It is on the top floors so the extra food, service and views are worth it. The lobby level below has an arcade of shops for everything else you need-high fashion, jewelry, tours; and it connects to the other building, the Otani Garden Tower, which also has a grocery, mini-mart and the iconic Trader Vic's which has the best smoked steak and other delicious Polynesian favorites and cocktails with umbrellas and birds in sticks.The piece de resistance of this hotel no doubt is the garden. which is a 400 year old Japaneses garden with bridges, koi ponds, lush trees and a waterfall. I wore my Jin Bei (Japanese men kimono) for lots of photo ops in front of the waterfalls.Although a bit dated, you cannot help but love the Grand Dame of Japanese Hotels-it is a gem of history and must remain revered and conserved for all time. It is in the Akasaka area, not far from restaurants, a church, Sophia University and the Yotsuke station which can take you anywhere in Metro Tokyo. They also have a convenient 3100YEN/31USD bus to Narita which was awesome!Thank you, Mr Otani, for building this hotel!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Failed to credit me my 15,000 Miles on United MileagePlus. I called and made sure my reservation was going to qualify and I was promised it would. When the statement came i only received 500 miles. Needless to say I was disappointed especially after taking the time to book directly with the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed at this hotel for 3 nights before going on cruise. Hotel was fabulous, very big and beautiful gardens to wander around. The service was excellent, the staff were a pleasure always smiling, very friendly and helpful. We stayed in the garden tower, room was as expected, a bit dated, nothing too grand but was fine. Different eating places within the hotel and were all very good, drink expensive but we expected this at this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed at the New Otani for 4 nights on a business trip. My room was in the Main wing - the hotel is a bit of a rabbit warren with multiple wings, but is also large enough to have several restaurants, shops and facilities. The room was a reasonable size and very clean. The bathroom was a little basic (no adjustments on the shower, just one hook for the head forcing you to stand at the back of the bath), but good toiletries. The garden was a peaceful spot to wander through or enjoy the waterfall. It was a little disappointing that hotel guests have to pay to use the gym or pool (maybe this is typical in Japan, but I've not experienced it elsewhere) but otherwise an enjoyable stay. As mentioned by other reviewers, staff spoke a reasonable level of English which is always appreciated.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I've been staying here twice a year for 8 years and felt it was time I gave this hotel a proper review. If you've not been to Tokyo, or not recently, then this could be a very good place for you to ease in. First of all, the room rates here are always reasonable and good value. Most often I usually seem to pay in the range of $150 - $250 USD per night. Very reasonable in Tokyo. The rooms are not spectacular, but certainly functional. Internet service is reliable,which is always a core requirement for me while on business. You might even get a view of Mt. Fuji on a clear day if your room faces it. Furthermore, the hotel is located very centrally with easy access to two different subway lines. The hotel staff is always friendly and helpful with good English language skills. So, what's so special about this place? First of all there's a 600 year old (so they claim) Zen garden on the premises for all to enjoy. The garden includes a waterfall and several restaurants tucked away in there. I always enjoy a daily respite in the garden while I'm staying here. Not the finest garden you'll find in Japan by any stretch, but a relaxing visage at the end of a busy day or over a morning breakfast meeting.And, as a lover of Soba, they have a fabulous Soba restaurant here, Nakajima. The dramatic wooden bar/counter is alone worth coming to see. One giant tree trunk, magnificently preserved.I do not recommend you stay here if you're seeking a quieter, more intimate hotel. To be sure the New Otani is like a small city with probably a dozen restaurants and bars, a small mall between the two wings, and the constant hum of activity of a big hotel. Still, for me it provides everything I need while in Tokyo on business or pleasure.
user_name:
GlobalBizMgr
New York, New York USA

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Second stay after 16 year during business trip. Nice memories.- Excellent staff with good English command. - Room was excellent and clean. Toilet kits are enough but again no body lotion. I noticed most Japanese hotels do not offer body lotion.- Hotel offers breakfast in 3 different buildings, was awesome.- Really liked in hotel shopping areas.- Location was good.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel is very nice. Located near two underground/metro stations. They are a short walk from the hotel. Near the underground stations are many bars and restaurants. The bars and restaurants are varied both in price and cuisine. I tried various restaurants and all were good. The in room wifi was very good. The high rooms had good views over Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This was the second time at the Otani and again it was terrific. The room was comfortable and we had a great view. There are several reasonably priced restaurants nearby and two subways within easy walking distance.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Super hotel, excellent service. I have been staying at the New Otani three or four times every year for over 25 years. Only one regret, the outdoor pool is not open all days in the summer! There a few days when the hotel is full on saturday night, which could block the Internet room reservation.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: First stayed here almost 50 years ago. I remember being impressed then, and I still am. Obviously this is not a new hotel. But we enjoyed the gracious service, nice views of the city, convenient location, and the generous midday checkout. And once again I was blown away by the Japanese garden. It is such an impressive oasis in the middle of Tokyo. Those who have not been should know that it is a large hotel with two wings which are kind of far apart. And being large, there are always a lot of people milling around including hotel guests, wedding and other party participants, and those eating at one of ther many restaurants. There is a lot of good food here - La Tour d'Argent, Pierre Herme's original store, Nadaman, etc. - although none of them are cheap. Recommended.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: very nice staff and their service.very convenient subway transportation.5 min walk to the restaurant street, where you can find a lot of different style food.The hotel has shuttle bus to airport, the price is a little bit higher than the subway.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: this is my first visit in Tokyo. I was expecting a decent but very small room and facilities. I found in the New Otani a very nice hotel, with small but reasonable and well equipped rooms, many and various restaurants, gym and all expected in an hotel. recomended

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani the night before our flight back. We wanted a big and luxury room before boarding a plane with narrow, cramped seats. We arrived via the Metro and were able to use an elevator from Akasaka-Mitsuke station to get to the surface and then wheel our suitcases to the hotel entrance. When we arrived at the lobby floor, the staff immediately greeted us and took our luggage, which was much appreciated. Check-in was nice and easy, we were asked if we wanted a double bed or two beds. The English of the staff was fine as well, we had a trainee checking us in. The luggage boy (I don't know the right term, I'm sorry. Bell boy?) was very hospitable as well, chatting wiht us, asking if we had already arranged our trip to the airport and recommending the Airport Limousine bus.Our room was on the 9th floor, big and spacious. The AC was perfect temperature, there were two bottles of complimentary water and while we looked at the parking lot, also had a view of Shinjuku. The only slightly disappointing thing about the room was the bathroom, a bit small and outdated with pink tiles. Nevertheless, the amenities were quite good, bathsalt, shower cap, razor. Nice. We tried their cake at the Garden Lounge, service was attentive and non-intrusive. The cake was as good as I remembered it to be (I had been there in 2005 and 2007). Later, we also walked around their garden, which is always relaxing and awe-inspiring. We were sad to leave the hotel, the check-out was quick and efficient and after telling them we were leaving for the Akasaka-Mitsuke station, our luggage was brought to the nearest exit and we were nicely waved off.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I stayed in the New Otani for 4 nights, room only before connecting to a cruise in Yokohama. The hotel is around 1 hr on the metro from Haneda Airport. The metro is 'do-able' however we have been to Tokyo before and it can be quite daunting as it is very busy, however don't let that put you off as the people are very polite and helpful. I have to say though it was difficult with cases although there are elevators and escalators. The hotel is huge and the staff are very polite. We only ate breakfast once because it was expensive (£30 per head) and some of the food was warm, a little disappointing but the view more than made up for it. The hotel is part of a shopping arcade and offices and was very quiet when were were there. The metro is about a 5 min walk and you can get to travel anywhere. The Imperial Palace is nearby too. There are plenty of good restaurants/bars nearby and would recommend Bums where they do a fantastic steak with garlic mash potato - it's a very trendy busy place, good fun. The area is very safe and I would recommend this hotel for it's convenience. I don't know how much we paid as it was in a package holiday, but I must say when we arrived it was midday, very hot and humid and we had lugged our cases around, and when we checked-in we were told that the swimming pool was out of service (and was for all the duration of our stay) and that was very disappointing as it looked lovely. There is an additional in-door pool but it's at a cost of ab out £30 per person per day and it was an independent business within the hotel complex that has a gym etc. Other than that I would recommend it. Lots of expensive shops in hotel,it has nice gardens with a lovely waterfall.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I had stayed here for official visit to Tokyo. Felt it was very accessible to my workplace, walkable ofcourse, the restaurant was very nice and helped me get some vegetarian food too. Not sure about expense as company paid it. The place boasts of a great garden and good ambience all around!This travel was on 2009 and wish it had got better now!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel is definitely getting old, but the service is still great.Who uses a metal key nowadays in 5 star hotel?...lol I wish they moved onto swipe card key already.Amenities in the room are awesome, bath salts? Really? Amazing!! Although they could probably upgrade the shampoo, conditioner and shower gel for something more modern instead of good old Shiseido ones.There were huge group of tourist staying at the same time and they were screaming and shouting in the hall way in the middle of the night. Room walls are thick enough to block the noise from next room though.Anything in this hotel is over priced, but that's same everywhere in the world I guess.Swimming pool should be free for those who are staying there :)

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stay in New Otani during my business trip this time, I have been to Tokyo more than 10 times and never thought of stay in this area, but after this stay, I think I will consider to come here again next time.The room is very spacious compare to many other hotel in Tokyo, there is even a sofa corner where you can enjoy a light refreshment, I personally love the toilet too, it;s very spacious yet there is bath top and shower room, also there is a big walking closet in the room, so you will have lots of free space for your shopping.Hotel staff are very friendly and helpful, it has many restaurant outlets and lots of shop underneath the hotel, if you would like to go to the main shopping area, subway station is just about 10 mins walk away, and it's just a few stop to shinjuku and shibuya. If you can wake up early (as breakfast finished at 10am every morning), you definitely need to try the outfit close to the nice garden, even though the breakfast is not special, but you will overlook the nice garden with waterfall while you are having breakfast, it's a must try experience in the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani is always excellent and while perhaps not as elegant as the Park Hyatt or the completely rebuilt Palace Hotel, the value is much better, especially using the package deals available for New Otani Club members - sign up for Club is free.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed hier for 4 nights. Great locattion. New Otani is an excelent hotel with beatyful garden. The room was comfortable and clean. Very good service. Plenty of choices for restaurants. I definitely recomend to everybody this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stay there in Dec 2013 for 2 nights. The room is really spacious compare to other hotels in Tokyo. The Japanese garden is so beautiful and we are still able to see the autumn leaves even in December.The breakfast place on top of the building can see Tokyo Tower, Shinjuku.The location is in the heart of Tokyo but a bit far away from the station, around 15mins walk to Yotsunoya station.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Excellent hotel in the heart of Tokyo with easy access to transportation. Service is excellent. Rooms are nice with standard Japanese accommodations. On site dining and shopping are available, but there are dozens of restaurants in the area. For my first trip to Tokyo, the New Otani was a great place to stay.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani was suggested as one of the Hotels local politicians use whenever they stay in Tokyo. It is a massive property with retail outlets and plenty of restaurants. The rooms are nice and big. Walk in wardrobe, big bathroom but aged interior. If you ask for iron and iron board you will get it but you have to sign that you received it and return it within 60 Minutes. One would think a hotel of this category had space to have that in the (massive walk in) wardrobe at all times. The room keys are still physical keys. I guess I did not have something like that in years. The Gym is weird and super small for a property of this size because it appears they just removed the interior out of one of the guest rooms and put some Cardio equipment in it. All in all it was ok but not memorable.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani Hotel is a small city on its own. Very large capacity and large spectrum of amenities make it very comfortable. The hotel features shopping area, several high quality restaurants, free small concerts, large spa area and a must-see garden. Location is excellent with easy access to Marunouchi and Roppongi.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Have stayed here before. The New Otani Tokyo is a large complex essentially 2 hotels joined together with a large number of dining, drinking and shopping options. The Narita limousine bus stops at this hotel. It is hard to think of a service that is missing from the hotel although some such as the swimming pool charge a fee. Dining options too are numerous though all tend to be on the pricey side. More reasonable options are outside the hotel in the Akasaka area just a 5 minute stroll; as well there is a large BIC Camera store just 5 minutes walk. Rooms in the Main Building are quite roomy with separate dressing areas. Bathrooms are on the compact side and reflect the limitations of the old building structure. In all public areas the hotel was spotlessly clean and well maintained and given the number of guests over the golden week holiday in Japan this must be a difficult task. The buffet breakfast selection was huge offering both Western, Japanese and Asian choices. Staff too were well trained and always helpful. The garden in the hotel is well worth a visit if you have the time. If the budget does not stretch the main section, rooms in the tower are usually offered on line at competitive rates.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The room in the Main was quite comfortable. I was especially pleased that the air conditioning was able to get my room cool enough. The lobby areas near the entrance to the Main seem to be sorely lacking in chairs and sofas for waiting and for meeting and having casual conversation. While there are seats on the other side of the elevator banks, you can't see the entrance when waiting for someone to come into the hotel.The breakfast buffet in the restaurant on the lobby level was outstanding and offered something for everyone; however, like much of Asia, getting crispy bacon that isn't chewy doesn't seem possible.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed for 4 nights in the Main building. Room was large for Tokyo, bed extremely comfortable, exquisite bathroom with both shower and tub, wonderful amenities in the bathroom but not in the room. There were no pens in the room for writing notes and no information or maps of the hotel. Did not have the little extras that make for a 5 star hotel especially for Tokyo. Rooms are not freshened up at night like at other 5 star hotels we stay at. Very helpful staff both at check in, finding your way around Tokyo, or just around the hotel.Location of the hotel is excellent being near both JR station and the subway. Is within walking distance of the Akasaka-mitsuke area which has lots of restaurants and shopping. Hotel has a beautiful Japanese garden with a restaurant that looks out on the garden. Great place for morning coffee or tea but the breakfast buffet is just okay. The buffet does not have a great choice of fresh fruit, pastries are just okay, no cereals and no hot items. It is a continental buffet but have had hot items at other 5 star hotel breakfast buffets. Hot items seem overpriced for what is served. We ate one evening at Trader Vic's as it was the only restaurant open - found it to be extremely expensive for what is served. The New Otani Garden wing has a great market located on the ground level where you can buy almost anything you need for your stay. Shopped here for items for snacking and to supplement the coffee provided in the room. All in all a good place to stay for convenience, the Japanese Garden, but find it expensive for what you get. We have stayed here on our many trips to Tokyo but will trying out a new hotel for our next stay.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the end of a 19 day tour of Japan. We had four nights in a room in the main buiding with a great view of Tokyo's south east and the neighbouring Garden Tower. The hotel is vast with around 1700 rooms and ours was well-appointed, comfortable and the room and laundry services were very good. There are lots of restaurants and bars in the hotel complex with The Gun Ship being very good and reasonably priced. We also dined at The Bella Vista Restaurant for a special dinner, priced accordingly. Coffee or a glass of something nice at Aux Bacchanales while watching the passing street scene was nice too. We also dined at Aux Bacchanales and can thoroughly recommend it. Even at the end of 4 days we were still finding new, unexplored things in the complex. The beautiful historic Japanese garden at the centre of the complex is a wonderful bonus for guests. We'd certainly recommend this hotel and would stay there again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: First of all, the location is pretty good - a three minute walk from the pivotal Akasaka subway station. The sprawling hotel comprises a 17 storey so-called Main hotel and a 40 storey Garden Tower separated by nearly 100 metres of corridor. I haven't stayed in the tower for a couple of years, but back then it had large rooms, sparsely furnished, with the hardest beds I've ever experienced. The Main hotel block rooms are far smaller, more recently refurbished, and with beds which help overcome jet lag rather than reduce your chances of sleep. Whichever block you choose, the bathrooms are small - and of course come equipped with the ubiquitous electric lavatory. Press the wrong button and you'll self induce colonic irrigation, and it's worth learning how to turn off the seat warmer.The complex - for that is what it is - is built on the side of a hill. This makes it quite confusing. The lobby floor of the Main hotel is on the equivalent floor to the 6th floor of the Tower (so the Tower lobby is on the 6th floor). There are restaurants and shops all over the place. The hotel is a hive of activity during the day - navigating the wide, shop-lined corridor between the two parts of the hotel is rather like walking down a busy street - yet turns into a wasteland at about 8.30 at night.There are several places to take breakfast. On a sunny day, opting for continental breakfast allows you to eat in the Garden restaurant - half way along the 100 metre corridor separating the Main from the Garden Tower. The huge picture windows overlook a 10 acre Japanese garden, complete with red bridge, rock garden and fairly sizeable waterfall. It looks less polished when you walk round it, but from the breakfast room it is a spectacular oasis of peace over which to gaze while eating your beakfast.We also had breakfast in the more popular, larger, and rather dismal breakfast room in the Main hotel. While the choice is good, the atmosphere is oppressive and the seating arrangements so convoluted that they contrive to create a 10 minute queue for a half empty restaurant at 06.00.Over the last couple of visits I have eaten in a couple of the hotel's Japanese restaurants, including the really excellent Kyubey sushi restaurant. The Sky Bar is a different matter. Service is pitifully slow, the ambience is uninviting (which is why the lights are virtually on "off"), and the view is completely spoiled by the distraction of the revolving restaurant which circles the bar.For the record, over the years I have found the service in the hotel to be solid if somewhat slow. This time they struggled to cope with the fact that I arrived with my wife rather than just alone as my booking indicated. What should have been a two minute rate adjustment took 15 minutes to resolve. This time round the bed had hairs in it: it happens in hotels; they were very apologetic; but it took two people an inordinate amount of time to remake the bed at 11.00 at night.It's absolutely not a five star experience, but it is reliable and - for Tokyo - reasonably priced for what you get (25,000 Yen per day including breakfast).

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani provides a comfortable nights sleep and has most of the amenities that you would expect of a hotel in this price bracket.Walking into this hotel informed me of what luxury was like in the 80's, I don' think much has changed since that era. Requires a bit of an overhaul, simple stuff isn't right. Hot water isn't regulated resulting in a shower that turns from hot to cold, lack of international plug sockets (typical for hotels in Tokyo) with an additional lack of adapters available, wifi is transcient, breakfast is poor in comparison with other international hotels in major cities. There are better options in Tokyo in this price bracket, e.g. Imperial Hotel. Not much significantly wrong but you notice the small things and as such I would look elsewhere. Not worthy of 5 stars.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed for two nights on a business trip. I had stayed at New Otani in 2004 and was a bit hesitant to come back since I remembered to property to be a bit dated and spartan, but this is one of the few hotels that are on my company's approved hotels list and my last experience with another approved hotel, Okura, was less than stellar.The lobby and the shopping arcade is exactly as I remembered it from 10 years ago. The public areas are a bit dated, but not in bad shape, and there is a certain classic dignity about the place. The staff is very friendly and there were never any lines. To my pleasant surprise, my room 510 was fairly recently updated. The sleeping area had received an almost Hyatt/Westin-like facelift with stylish gray textiles and dark, sleek furniture. Unfortunately the upgrade did not include the bathroom which felt a bit dated and cramped. The bathroom was very functional, though, and I got my shower taken and teeth brushed just fine. Oddly, a couple of wood surfaces had not received the same dark stain treatment, so the room is not going to win any architectural prizes but was still pretty nice.Regarding the room, my main issue was sleep quality. The bed was nice and there was no noise, but despite my best attempts to seal the curtains against the wall using pillows and chairs, light seeped into the room very early, interrupting my much-deserved sleep. I woke up around 5 both nights and could not go back to sleep (I was past my jet lag already at that point so it was the light). I also could not find a safe, but Japan is probably the only country in the world in addition to Finland where this did not worry me.The gym is small and is equipped mostly with a few pieces of cardio equipment. I did get my treadmill fix, and there was one other person in addition to myself at 6:20 on a Friday morning (I told you I could not sleep).The breakfast room has gorgeous views over the hotel's garden. Unfortunately the breakfast buffet is not top notch. The bread was dry, scrambled eggs tasted funny, and there was not much in terms of oriental breakfast foods.The location is great. Taxis are plentiful. And the staff is super helpful. I also liked the shopping arcade and was able to get some nice souvenir books for my kids from the book store by the lobby.The hotel is clearly past its prime, but in its price point I don't think you can do much better in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Hi, sorry for this very late review. But I happened to stay here for a week with AHRW group, known group for human rights from the japan government. Service here was really great, many times that i left some valuable belongings inside while attending the conference, room service really make my room clean everyday, and great that when i came back, my valuables are still there, though i happened to left my favorite coat when i check out, but i guess, that's my fault, not them. for food delivery to my room, its quite expensive, but you can save more if you'll eat down stair. They have restaurant on the ground floor, several boutiques are also within the premises and no need for you to go out, but if you're looking for more bazaar, and shops with lots of bargains, they're just a few walk away :) enjoy your stay here and do shopping according to your budget in and outside of this hotel
user_name:
Mcfloralde
Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei Darussalam

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed in the New Otani ( Main ) for 11 days with my Mum at end of April . My mum made the choice based on an overnight stay at the end of a previous visit to Japan and we were delighted that our longer stay this time met all our expectations and more ! Very helpful pleasant staff - only too delighted to help when the on arrival crazy jet lagged uk people wanted to borrow an iron at 1am ( their time ) ! Our room was meticulously made up everyday with nice touches like quality bathroom accessories and a free bottle if water each per day ( didn't get that on recent trip to New York hotel !) My favourite part of the hotel was the beautiful Japanese Garden - many a morning spent happily reading with amazing views and a waterfall ! Time to recharge or retreat from the hectic bustle of Tokyo .Also as others have said there are many restaurants in the hotel -the only one we tried was Trader Vic's a treat on our last day - and it was lovely with a good value ' lunch set 'As we didn't have breakfast included with our room we tended to use the small supermarket in the hotel on the ground floor of Garden a Tower or the Family Mart ( trickier to find !) Tips for staying in this hotel - it really is huge !! Like others have said we always exited through the Garden tower to be closest to Akasaka metro station - do not underestimate the time it will take you to get from your room if staying in the Main to the exit - and we did get lost a few times !Would have no hesitation in recommending !!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: There seems to be some duplication between this site, the one for the New Otani Garden Tower, and the New Otani Gardens (which is also attracting reviews for this hotel). I therefore copy my hotel review here (as I wouldn't want anyone to miss it!)This is a huge hotel complex, with numerous places to eat, drink and shop (although, in keeping with other hotel restaurants/bars, they are more expensive than going out). And because of the hotel’s excellent location it is very easy to go out for a drink or meal, as it is a stone’s throw from the Akasaka district (and metro station should you want to go further afield) where there are ample different restaurants to suit all tastes and pockets. To walk to the Akasaka area it is quicker to leave the hotel by the Garden Tower entrance rather than the main entrance as it saves a walk round the block.Our room in the hotel (in the Garden Tower Block) was more spacious than I had expected in a Tokyo hotel, with enough room for storage and suitcases. It was clean, comfortable and well serviced with towels changed every day. The bathroom was also the best we had during a tour in Japan, with a showerhead that could change the direction of jet, bars of soap, small bottles of shampoo and conditioner plus face clothes – all of which were lacking in other hotels we stayed in.Breakfast in the hotel is also good, with a reasonable selection of hot western style dishes, Japanese dishes and fresh fruit. (Although I found this never-varied selection was much the same in other hotels we subsequently visited and consequently became a little boring, but it was probably better here than other hotels we stayed at). Breakfast can be taken at one of several restaurants, but the main two for western breakfasts are the rooftop restaurant in the Garden Tower, and the central ground floor Garden restaurant (there is another Japanese restaurant if you want a Japanese breakfast). These open at 7pm and there is invariably a queue, particularly at the rooftop restaurant where great views over Tokyo can be had from window tables. If you want a window table here for an early breakfast you would need to get there by about 6.45, otherwise just before 7.30 when, although still usually a (shorter) queue, you will get the first arrivals starting to leave. The Garden restaurant is more airy and has a greater capacity, but again you should be there just before 7 for an early breakfast to get a table overlooking the superb gardens. For us, this was the more comfortable and relaxing of the two. (Incidentally, the attractive gardens and pools full of Koi carp are well worth walking round).Drinks are expensive (1000 yen plus for a small beer). The lobby floor Capri bar (near the main lobby) is a bit soulless with more serving staff than customers when we went (I noted 6 attentive serving staff for us and another couple), while Trader Vic’s bar (the only other we tried) was equally pricey but had a better atmosphere being decorated out in a Disney-like South Sea Island style. It also serves snacks in the bar.Overall we thought the hotel very good, reasonably priced for the size and style of hotel it is, and met our needs in all respects, although we did eat and drink out after the first night.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The new Otani is a good value for money. It is quiet, spacious, well located, large bathroom vlby any standards and great shisheido bath product. The hotel is clean. The staff at the reception is not of much help when the concierge or the business center are closed. The duck at la Tour d'Argent is as it should be and always an experience. The shopping center attached to the hotel has a large selection of shops bit they are a bit dated / catering to a older crowd. The cigar bar is OK, the service is great and the drinks adequate - a good place for a last drink. Don't miss to walk through the lovely zen garden which is large with multiple ponds and bridges. The swimming pool is great with numerous transats and shade areas. Definitely a place to relax during the hot summer day.
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
DamienBE
New York, New York, United States

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: During my stay I had need for medical assistance at the nearby medical clinic. Yasuhiro Kawakami the duty manager showed me excellent service when, without asking, he accompanied me to the doctor and the chemist to allay any language difficulties. Nothing was too much trouble as he calmly helped me through what could have been a difficult issue. Well done Kawakami san I was most impressed

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani is comfortable, spacious, centrally located, and easily connected to the metro system, making it perfect not only for your business but for your spouse to come along as a tourist! The included breakfast overlooking the garden is outstanding, the service first rate, and best of all, you get all this for a very reasonable price!At about $200/night, with breakfast included in my company rate, the New Otani is great value. The 'Akasaka' neighborhood is in the middle of Tokyo, and with the well-connected 'Akasaka-mitsuke' metro station right around the corner, I could get to work or to any of the big tourist destinations in minutes. The Akasaka neighborhood itself is fun, with tons of restaurants, bars, and shopping. In summer, the New Otani's pool opens, making the hotel a popular spot for visitors and locals alike when the weather gets sticky.Transportation Details:The Akasaka-mitsuke 'exit 10D' metro entrance is a 5-minute walk from the New Otani's 'Garden Tower' wing, and more like a 10-minute walk from the 'Main' wing. From the 'Main' wing you walk down the big hallway, past the shops and the restaurant overlooking the hotel's stunning garden, through the Garden Tower's lobby, down the elevator in the connected 'Garden Court' building to the first floor, out the door, to the right, over the bridge, and the metro entrance is on the right. It sounds complicated, but it's easy! We easily purchased 'Pasmo' cards from the vending machine at this metro station, which worked on all metros, trains, and buses in Tokyo. Buying the pass using the machine worked just fine, in English, and we had our passes in minutes. I highly recommend any visitor get a Pasmo (or the equivalent 'Suica' Card sold by Japan Rail) for getting around; it makes Tokyo public transit so easy! The bottom line is that this hotel is comfortable, central, good value, and well connected, making it a great choice for both business and pleasure. So why not bring your spouse along? You'll both have a great time!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Spent 2 days, the room was exactly what we expected : the main, large, king bed, beautiful bathroom, ok view. Breakfast at the 40th floor just near a window with a beautiful view too.Love this place, even if it is difficult to find a cafe nearby. The lounge is always full on sundays.We will come back ... again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed here for 7 nights in March-April, 2014. Very busy hotel - many people (business people included) always coming and going. Originally received a room with two twin beds (travelling by myself on business), but they were able to switch it after a few days (I checked back each day). Apparently they were too booked to switch me sooner. I'm also a member of the New Otani Club. Rooms were large and had all the amenities I needed. If anything, the hotel is too big. I tried many of the restaurants - the main breakfast place near the front desk, the garden room for breakfast and tea, the top floor breakfast place in the garden tower, Trader Vics, the Chinese Restaurant, and the bar at the top of the main tower. Dry cleaning services were quick and good. If you exit the hotel through the garden tower lobby (also part of a office tower), the subway station is only a 5 minute walk.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: You could feel that an efficient, consistent, and streamlined management is running the system. Flexible, accommodating and respectful enough to accept our lack of credit card, as guarantee, by just charging the room rates, with no added deposit. Everything was done based on well-thought- out instructions, so everything went on smoothly with well-trained staff: +: Well-informed concierge, who took all the time to arrange a mount-fuji/Strawberry picking tour for us, without pre-payment, the check-in, luggage handling and keeping, by the bell-boys, and bell captain even after check-out, airport limousine coordination, Otani member club coordination with different parts of the hotel, breakfast both in lobby (Garden view) and the 40th floor. Quality of breakfast, the meticulously kept garden,nice feeling that hotel has had some history, from Tokyo Olympics, to a James Bond movie, a 400-year old garden, a Patron of arts and culture of Japan,.... The Free wifi, The excellent brands of toiletries, in-room coffee, green tea, pillows, satin cotton sheets. Family mart in the garden court building, vicinity to Akasaka Mitsuke station with conections to Marunochi and Ginza line. Big room and big bed convenient with a 7-year old active child (the double beds could be used for an adult and a child). Hair conditioner and bath salt as toiletry is a plus, which is not included in many hotels. Excellent concierges, with helpful recommendations. Vicinity to beautiful cherry- blossom viewing and hanami route.-: The English speaking and International tv channels were either not present or pay per view. No shoe shine machine present in floors, or shoe polish present in rooms. Adding some kids play area would be appreciated!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed 4 nights. Cab had no problems getting to the hotel. Driver asked whether I was headed to the Main Building or Garden Tower. Check in was smooth. Everyone spoke enough English to communicate. Room was large and clean. There was a good sized work desk and 2 3prong plugs. There was both wired and wireless connectivity though the wired connection didn't work. 2 bottles of water was provided and a mid sized in room safe.Bathroom was small but clean and had a good set of amenities. Shower was in tub.There was a Family Mart at a shopping arcade next to the Garden Towers. Exiting from the Garden Towers, a short walk across the bridge brings you to plenty if restaurants. There was a row of beautiful cherry blossom trees too.Check out was smooth and never had a problem getting a cab at the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed at the Hotel New Otani many times on business over the past 20 years and I am never disappointed. This time I had organised a family trip to celebrate a milestone birthday and wanted a hotel I knew would be consistent and convenient. I booked well in advance as I knew a Spring weekend would be busy and so paid rack rate. However, by choosing a king size exec room with an extra bed we saved money as we were three adults.The room was large and the extra bed full size. The king was huge and could have slept 3 or 4!!!A separate bathroom and WC meant we weren't falling over each other, and ample towels and bath supplies were provided.A very comfortable sleep.Downside for us was that rack rate did not include breakfast, which is very expensive. I had intended to re- book when advance purchase deals came out, but by the time I checked they had gone.One fly in the ointment - on busy days the breakfast restaurant struggles to cope with numbers and you can end up queuing for 15 minutes or more. Something the hotel needs to sort out really.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My 2014 New Otani experience was my 3rd at this hotel since 1999, and the hotel continues to offer superb service, excellent accommodation, and the added beauty of the garden, this time in full cherry blossom splendour. The staff are exceptionally polite, the Garden restaurant spectacular, and the location so close to the Canadian Embassy a plus.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel is big more like a small town, it has beautiful Japanese gardens to get lost in.The staff in their very smart livery are very helpful. The breakfast is probably better on the Asian front rather than anything that looks western.Our room was very clean but very dated, it must of been state of the art 40yrs ago but this is now beginning to show.It boasts a terrific location,and once discovered, wormholes take you undercover right into the shopping/restaurant area where the metro station is also located .

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We enjoyed our 5 nights stay in our deluxe room at the Main very much. It was nice and refreshing to walk around the Japanese garden inside the hotel ground. Our room was very spacious and we liked the powder room which was away from the bathroom. The shower room was large and separate from the bath tub, so it was much easier to have showers without climbing in and out of the bath tub. All the staff at the hotel were very friendly and efficient.The only hic'cup we had during our stay was the room wasn't made up (no cleaning or bed making) when we returned to our room one afternoon but when we contacted the house keeping, they were most apologetic and came to service our room while we were out for dinner the same evening.Over all, we had a great time staying at Hotel New Otani and we will certainly stay there again when we visit Tokyo next time.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was set up here by my colleagues in Tokyo due to all hotels seeming to be booked. It found it each to get to with a cab, located within walking distance to stores and restaurants. My host stated it is an "older hotel". but I personally found it appearing to be looking like a "new property" in and out. My room was a good size with nice amenities and service. I enjoyed my stay…This all being said, I did believe it was a bit high priced for a property on the outskirts of Tokyo, but seeing all hotels seem booked for whatever reason, it may be a factor for the rate.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed for 4 nights at the New Otani Tokyo in the Main. It is very handy to the Akasake-mitsuke metro station. The station is a three minute walk from the Garden Tower exit. Yes it was a fair walk from the Main to the exit at the Garden Tower just allow an extra 5 minutes to catch that train. Easy to find and all in English. There is a street across the road from the station where you will find plenty of little eateries and convenience stores. We caught the limo bus from the airport which delivered us to the front door of the hotel, nice and easy after a fairly long and late flight. Unfortunately the hotel was not able to give us an early check in but were happy to keep our bags until the 2.00pm check in time. You have to pay an extra night if you want early or late checkin check out. It was very busy in the lobby as this hotel is huge and be careful as we decided to have a cup of coffee at a hefty price near the check in at the Main. Go for a walk around the hotel and find other choices. Service and staff were very efficient and friendly. We tried to tip when our bags were brought upstairs and the tip was politely refused as it is not hotel policy. That doesn't happen too often! Beds were lovely and comfortable, room clean, good size and quiet. We did get a key to the room rather than electronic cards which is a little old fashion. We wouldn't hesitate to stay at The New Otani Tokyo again although we didn't catch the cherry blossoms at their best. Not the Otani's fault!! The park in the hotel grounds is beautiful and well worth a good walk around, especially at cherry blossom time.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed here for 5 nights in March and it was very comfortable. I especially liked my room in Main which faced the Garden. In the mornings I would have a great view of Mt. Fuji. The hotel amenities in the room were very nice and included shampoo, conditioner, shower cap, toothbrush, soaps, and a few other things. Much more than you get at most hotels. The bathroom was great, with big towels and a robe and the shower worked really well for such a large hotel. The room included a stocked refrigerator (all kinds of soda and alcohol-types) and a drawer that had a hot water pot and tea and coffee. I was grateful for the hot pot because I like a nice cup of tea and since I had brought my own bags of English Breakfast, I was all set. The tea bags in the room tend toward green and other strange herbal flavors. It wasn't easy to get just a cup of coffee in the hotel. There were sufficient outlets for all of my electronic devices and the Internet worked really well. There are lots of restaurants in this huge hotel, but my favorite was the Garden Lounge. It had beautiful views of the Garden and as was really comfortable. I could look out over their formal garden and the waterfall while reading the paper and having a $13 pot of tea. Lunch in the Garden Lounge cost about $35 for a sandwich and coke, but all the food is always beautifully arranged. Breakfast was about the same price. Most of the restaurants were expensive, but it WAS Tokyo after all. I expected that, but it was really too much food late at night. I've included 2 pictures of a menu at the Hotel. I really wanted to eat there, but I have to watch what I eat when on Business Travel. Every morning I would catch a cab to an office building near the Tokyo Tower -- for $17. There was always a lot of cabs available. There was a McDonalds and Starbucks within walking distance. I even got to experience a small earthquake! Also, I walked for miles around the area. It had nice sidewalks, but I think I should have gotten a cab to one of the gardens and then walked. But the fact that it had a nice garden of its own was really special. Not much was blooming in March, but the framework of the garden was easy to see. That was the highlight of the hotel.
user_name:
Jeanne B
Washington DC, District of Columbia

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed here for six nights. The staff provided excellent service from check in to check out. The garden is beautiful and we were on-time for cherry blossom viewing. It is a huge complex so there is walking between the Main Hotel and the Garden Tower but that was fine.We were able to find gift and flower shops and a Family Mart in the complex so those took care of immediate go-to find things. Sophia University is right next door and this is the reason we chose the New Otani Tokyo since our daughter is a student there. The airport limo bus from Narita drove us straight to the hotel and the Yotsuya train station and the Akasaka-mitsuke subway station are both nearby. These provided easy access to transportation throughout Tokyo. The concierge desk and the New Otani Club Member desk (join if you're not a member. It's free) answered all our questions about how to get to places.You can walk up to Shinjuku Street (towards Yotsuya Station) and find all the usual big city stores and banks. We especially liked the Mumbai Restaurant for Indian food. The Concierge desk has a map that will get you there. If you head the other way (towards the Akasaka-mitsuke station) you will find even more eateries and city life. This area is great for evening meals and walks.There is so much to do and not enough time to write.It was a little more expensive then what we are used to paying but for this time, since our daughter was going to school next door and we were celebrating our 30th anniversary, it was worth it.We did run into a problem after we checked out and returned home overseas. We had misplaced important papers and we couldn't find them. I e-mailed the hotel and asked them if they could look for them. Mr. Kurashima from Housekeeping called me and told me that they searched and found the papers. We arranged pickup and all is now well. What great service!We made the right decision staying at this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The room was small & old. Very different from what I seen on -line when I make the reservation.Don't just put beautiful pictures on web site. We should know what we can expect with the room rate we paid. It really make me feel disappointed.For so many years, this hotel is still using very heavy room key ?!!The location is good, but the lobby is very old.Really can't recommend to my friends.Hong Kong

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed for 3 nights in the hotelThe lobby is a bit old fashioned but the check-in was fastI had the room 524 which was big enough with a kind of walk-in cabinet areaThe bathroom had the classic resin marble sink but the bath was cast iron enameledThe amenities were adequate if not fancyThe bed was firm but comfortableThere was a make up table as well as a small deskThe cleaning was very well made with tactful repositioning of my things when neededThe breakfast was adequate with diligent serviceThe tempura restaurant was averageOverall a good place to sleep during a business trip if you use taxi as the entrance is not very close from the subway line I had to useOne noticeable plus the room is one of the quietest I had in a large hotel for a very long time

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Our spacious room in this lovely hotel was perfect in every way. Takahashi greeted us in the lobby and took care with our luggage and with us! He was most professional and gracious and made us feel like we were very special guests. We were amazed at the staffs' attention to detail in all aspects of the hotel services. We can hardly wait to return to Tokyo and look forward to returning to the Hotel New Otani.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed here in March for a business and leisure trip, excellent choice by my company, although it was big it was beautiful. Lots of shops, restaurants and and beautiful garden. Location brilliant restaurants and subway on the doorstep.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed here in March 14'. 2 days then returned for another day. Hotel is excellent and easy to find from the subway system. Staff are friendly, attentive and speak English. Rooms are large and modern and comparable to any Las Vegas type American hotels. Bars and restaurants are quite expensive but often a line to get in -though as a budget traveller I didn't eat there- but did have a beer on the 40th floor bar on my last night, worth it for the view. Lovely garden. I work for an airline and got a good industry rate by contacting the hotel directly though the website, you might consider doing the same. Highly recommended

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I chose an executive room. I checked in at the main lobby and they quickly realized I had a separate place to check in and they whisked me away to the 11th floor for checkin. I was given a table to sit with a hot towel and ginger tea to drink while they processed the paperwork to check me in. And this is how it went the entire stay. Top class service and they took the time to know and remember who I was. The room was superbly clean. This is a very large hotel, and very easy to get lost in. But there is plenty of shopping inside the hotel and multiple restaurants.The hotel is walking distance from the subway and there is a nice walking/jogging trail through a park. They'll give you a map for that trail if you ask.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed for a week of business and this hotel is beautiful and the staff is wonderful. It is also very convenient to the subway system. We did not eat breakfast, use the gym nor spa facilities so we cannot comment on those.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We combined work and pleasure on our recent stay in New Otani Main. Great location. Excellent staff; could not be more helpful. We had breakfast in the restaurant overlooking the gardens, best view we ever had. Room was nice size, had great city view, large comfortable bed. Overall, great hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was required to stay at this hotel. The location is supposed to be very convenient to all government offices. Unfortunately, when I checked in, I was informed that I would be on the smoking floor BUT my room has had all the smoke smell cleaned out. Not so. I walked into the room and was hit with a cloud of stale smoke stench. I asked for a change, but was informed it was not possible since I was with a delegation.The room was about half the size of the Hilton I normally stay in. There was no iron in the room.The staff was courteous as is to be expected especially in Japan. There was construction going on outside which dashed any hope of catching a midday jet lagged nap.All in all, I'll be returning next time to the Hilton.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: it's nothing more than a typical business hotel in Japan, perhaps the rooms are slightly bigger and the bathroom is not plastic but tiledstaff is as friendly as can be expected from a hotel of this class, but nothing morebiggest advantage: the location close to subway and JRbiggest disadvantage: the price and the behaviour of a cheap airline - everything extra costs (you want breakfast? another 3000Yen please...)I booked a non-smoking room, got one on the smoking floor - it took one hour to get me a non-smoking room for the same price (if I would move into a better non-smoking room, I would have had to pay of course the price for that room)

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We've stayed in the New Otani several times and love the location and the very pleasant and knowledgeable staff. The hotel is easily reached by the Limousine Airport Bus that drops you off at the hotel's entrance. There is also a subway station within easy walking distance. The rooms are nicely furnished, some a little bigger than others, the bathroom is nice and a good size. Our bathroom had a great walk-in shower as well as a bathtub and of course a Toto washlet. The breakfast buffet has a large variety of delicious items and is served in a large open area overlooking the Japanese Garden, perfect ambiance and views to start the day. There are several excellent restaurants that belong to the hotel and in the basement of the hotel you will find more great restaurants that are run by outside vendors. The Yakitori restaurant was one of our favorites. There is also a medical clinic with an English speaking doctor on site, a post office and an ATM machine and of course lots of shops. We booked thru the hotel's website and got a good deal, the breakfast buffet was included. All the staff members are extremely friendly and always ready to help in any way they can.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Hotel New Otani Tokyo is my favourite hotel in Tokyo. Convenient location, very kind and skilled staff. I took NOC Winter package. The rate (including breakfast) was 27500 yen per night. Staff advised me attending the most interesting events in Tokyo according to my requests. I anjoyed my staying in the hotel and will come there again in future.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: After six or seven stays, this remains the favorite in Tokyo. There are several reasons for this. First, it is possible to take the Limousine Bus directly from Narita to the door of the hotel. No fuss, no bother. About $30 per person in fall 2013. When you’re tired and grumpy after a long flight, having someone deal with the luggage and getting you there is just very nice. Second, there are always English speaking staff available at the front desk and concierge desk, and most of the staff have some English, so it’s an easy affair to deal with the hotel. Third, the grounds / garden are just terrific, and between this, the surrounding areas, and the pretty fabulous shopping available in the hotel, it’s easy to spend the first day here getting acclimated, work on getting the body clock reset, etc. Fourth, my family and I love the “Western Buffet Breakfast” on the 40th floor of the Garden Tower. It’s easy to get to, and you can find most anything you’d like for breakfast. It’s got a terrific view, there are actually both Japanese and “Western” foods, and most of the guests are Japanese. This is a great way to start the day. And if you’re a member of the New Otani Club (no cost to join, but do so before leaving home so your card gets to you before departure), there are discounts on breakfasts, and indeed free breakfasts with certain kinds of rooms. There is an ATM in the hotel’s lower level Post Office that has English instructions so you can get more cash when you run out, and there really are a plethora of shopping experiences right in the hotel. And don’t be mistaken here; the goods on sale in the shops here are just top rate (albeit with matching prices). The rooms are large by Tokyo standards, and come with nice bathrobes, indoor slippers, bathrooms stocked with every imaginable amenity, Toto Washelet toilets, and the rooms I’ve had always have both a very nice Japanese shower and a tub for soaking. In room WiFi is complimentary. Free daily bottles of water, tea kettle and fully stocked minibar. Helpful, extremely courteous staff. They give the clear impression that if you called down and said you needed a small elephant in your room right away, they would only blandly ask whether it should be Indian or African, and how small. I like it a lot and keep going back. Oh, and there are sort of two hotels here, “The Main” and the “Garden Tower.” I’ve stayed in both, like both, and can’t draw much distinction between them. Let price and availability of the style of room you want be your guide here. Finally, note that the hotel does have a U.S. reservation service with an 800 number listed on their website, where helpful staff in the U.S. are waiting to help you. It’s pricey here, but not the most expensive in Tokyo by a long shot, and that will be your only regret. If you just have to have the most expensive room in Tokyo, look elsewhere. But I doubt you’ll get a better experience. Oh, and there are two subway stations within a five minute walk, with sites such as the Imperial Palace grounds, Tokyo Station, Tokyo Tower, etc. just a very short cab ride away. Enjoy.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I spent my honeymoon in Japan and this hotel was recommended. Having never been to Tokoyo I found the staff extremely helpful. They organised tours and helped us navigate around the city. The hotel was located close to shops and the metro. The subway system was so easy and cheap to move around. On the opposite side of the hotel was a whole street of restaurants. I would recommend the grilled seafood which is cooked on a hot plate on your table. The 400 year old Japanese garden on the roof was amazing. My husband and I are already planning to bring our friends here.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I really enjoyed my stay here, it was only a block away from the metro line, and there was lots of shops in the area. The room itself was quite spacious when planning our travel to Tokyo we realized that most hotel rooms were going to be small compared to American standards, but not this place , the rooms were amazing! they also had incredible gardens and lots of restaurants and shops inside the building to choose from. The only drawback was the breakfast at the hotel's restaurant it was a bit over priced for what it was, only a few croissants and some fruit and juice for about $35 USD per person, we decided to take it because we were short on time as we were departing to Kyoto that day, but if you have time , there are plenty of food options outside of the hotel. Nonetheless i would most definitely stay here again. Also the staff is very friendly , helpful and most speak good english.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I spent a week at the New Otani in Tokyo this December. It's a large, well maintained hotel complex, that I have been staying at on regular visits since 1990. The rooms are small but loaded with subtly high end fittings. The service is efficient. There is a multitude of very average but expensive restaurants in the complex, as well as better choices in the nearby Akasaka-mitsuke area, which also has a handy subway station on the Ginza line. The service is efficient but very impersonal and rigid. On the negative side, though I have had the habit of staying at the New Otani for over 23 years, and spent my honeymoon in a suite there, there is never any 'welcome back' or acknowledgement of this when I check in. They don't seem to keep a database on clients meaning there is no personal touch. I joined their New Otani Club last year and was unable even to log in to make the reservations this year, despite several interactions with them through email. Being in The Club seemed to make no difference on price or services. The prices are very high in global terms, even for 'special packages' offered at around USD 350 in the off season. It is the only hotel that I've stayed at in the world that does not offer open access to the gym for guests, which is a serious shortcoming that has been going on for decades. I wouldn't expect this to change, given Japanese rigidity.
