review_body: I stayed at the New Otani for 3 nights in early May. The hotel is very central, close to sub-way stations and is a really big property with a nice Japanese garden. While the breakfast is standard the view from the Breakfast room from the top of the tower was fantastic. The stay was generally good and the staff were very helpful. The downsides were that the property is a bit run down and the equipment in the gym was quite basic and not always working.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani for two nights on April 27th and 28th/2012.What a great experience! The lavish Japenese Garden with the water fall and the koi ponds with the beautiful red arched bridge connecting the pathways were absolutely magnificent.The staff was over the top with their kindness and helpful service.We found Japan to be the cleanest country with the most helpful people in the world. I told my wife that I wanted to stay up one night to see if they actually washed and vaccuumed the entire streets and subways before the day started!Now we understand how this beautiful culture bonds together to handle any crisisThe Hotel is located next to the emaculate subway, which takes you to any location in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The relaxing outdoor garden, the koi ponds and the hotel itself. The beautiful lobby decorations and wonderful shops were interesting. I attended an international assembly and the food was excellent. The service is A class.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed there over an full weekend at capacity. LOVED the zen decor of the room and the teapots!! Felt myself relaxed immediately when coming in.Clean, super helpful staff, beautiful property... just the breakfast was kind of blah... Nothing to write home about... maybe a 20-30 minute wait to get a table... and the cannot cook eggs!Overall I would stay there again, but definitely not pay for the breakfast inclusion

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was in the Main and the room was plain, but perfectly adequate for a one person 2 day stay. The concierge made dinner reservations based on my emails and was very accomodating. Just wished they had warned me that getting to the tuna auction at 4:45 am would not be early enough to get in. The sushi restaurant in the hotel was very good. The garden is nice to walk in but it could use a few more benches.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed at the New Otani before, but quality deteriorated seriously this time. The room stank badly of cigarettes and the air conditioning didn't work, making for an intolerable evening before business meetings. Think twice about staying here!!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Rooms has nice views to the garden. Walking in the beautiful garden makes you forgot that you are in the middle of a busy crowded city. It is near subway station that takes you anywhere in Tokyo, but it is also a short easy walk to Akasaka area and there is a shopping street right in the other side of the street with lots of restaurants. If you book through package tour deals, it would be a very valuable for the price.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed in this hotel for 2 nights - if you can get over the fact that it feels a bit like Las Vegas (huge hotel, easy to get lost), than it's a great place to stay. The shops and restaurants downstairs have reasonable prices, the rooms are great and the beds are comfortable and most of the rooms have spectacular views of the city. The traditional Japanese garden on the premises is amazing, you almost see similar things only at temples!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed here a lot over the years. It is a quality hotel and in a good area to get out and about and enjoy Tokyo. Rooms in the main building have been refurbished in recent years, they needed it, and the results are very good. They are large, comfortable and well equipped and the bathrooms are good. When booking, check out their website for deals, for example if breakfast is included. Breakfast is possible in three locations, including the tower building on the 40th floor, and you get a fabulous view of Tokyo. The restaurant overlooking the garden is nice, with a view over a nice garden. It has more choice than the tower, including somebody who cooks eggs and stuff. There is also a restaurant close to the reception, this has the widest selection. There is a french restaurant, I *believe* it may have a Michelin, personally I've not eaten there, but I know somebody who has and apparently it's good. Personally, I want to eat Japanese food when in Japan. There is a sushi restaurant that is known as one of the best in the city. It is expensive, but it is very, very good. If you need a more western food fix, check out Trader Joes, which is at the bottom of the tower end of the restaurant. It's pretty good. BTW, you can also walk outside to Tony Romas, which is about a 1km walk. in the neighborhood, around Akasaka Mitsuke, which is the main subway station, there are some nice places to eat. But note it is quieter over the weekend, this is more of an after work area. If you know you are going to stay here a few times, or use the New Otani chain, sign up for the New Otani club, it's not so obvious if you are not a Japanese reader, but it can give benefits like free breakfast and so on.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The hotel is grand and old school, with beautiful garden between the two towers. Rooms are basic though. And wifi only works in the lobby which is a little inconvenient. Location is convenient as it is near a few subway lines which makes traveling easy in the city.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We booked this hotel because finding hotel rooms to accommodate 2 young children is tricky in Japan. the website we used allowed us to book one room for 2 adults and 2 children. It had 2 single beds. First the man at the desk said it was OK for us then he agreed to put in one extra bed for a fee. In the end he gave us the extra bed for free. It wasn't ideal.Otherwise the hotel is in a good location and the staff were very attentive.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Had a really nice stay at the Hotel New Otani, Tokyo. The room was quite large for Tokyo standards (note: very small for just about every other city in the world). Service was impeccable. I was surprised at how quiet it was not just in our room but in the surrounding neighborhood. Subway was about a 5 minute walk, so very convenient. The garden of the hotel is stunning. Overall, I thought the room rates adequately reflected the service/comfort/location of the room and I would definitely stay there again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I agree that the hotel is getting older and that the rooms are on the smaller side, especially for Western tourists. For Tokyo though the rooms are quite spacious. Being a prestigious hotel, the staff are really attentive and alert. The restaurants also serve very good food, although very pricey.The downside is that being a large hotel, there are no small shops in the immediate vicinity. Also, non-smokers should be careful not to accidentally check-in to smoking rooms.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The hotel is an old luxury hotel and the rooms are starting to show this. However, staying at the hotel you get the feeling that they still think they are the leading hotel in Tokyo. On top of their already hefty room rates (even for Tokyo standards), you will have to pay extra for a lot of things other hotels offer as a service. I arrived around noon and asked whether I could already check-in (having a corporate rate and lots of people staying there) I was told that they would charge me 50% extra if I wanted to check-in before 2 PM. You want to go to the pool - you will have to pay for this. You want to uyse internet... You go for breakfast and want eggs? Don't go to the lounge cafe because eggs are not included. They have several restaurants where you can get breakfast for $35 - check before you walk in that they offer what you are actually looking for!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is a fine hotel. The staff is courteous, as you would expect. The rooms are well kept and clean. The breakfast is good and includes a buffet, if disired. I will stay here again on my next trip.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I originally was booked into the Garden Tower (it was cheaper) and when I got to the room, it took me about 3 minutes to call the front desk to get me moved. The room is the equivalent of a Motel 6 in the US. Extremely disappointing! The room is tiny, the bed was awful, windows are small, furniture is old.I agreed to pay more for the Main Tower and the room was better. Now better is relative - the room was about Courtyard level in the US and for the price I should have received more. There was a little more room, but to give you an idea of the age of this place, it had a make up bench.The best part of the hotel is the Japanese Garden. Explore it even if you're not staying there.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani gives you a palatial feelings upon entry, the service is fine, rooms spacious and well equipped with lot of traditional Japanese and western style options to choose from. Surroundings are resort like with beautiful gardens. Location is central with ample transport and dining facilities including both Tokyo airports. It is uniquely good for business as well as holidays. The breakfast is sumptuous with plenty of choices. The hotel has three segments, The Zen, Main and garden tower. Try staying at Main which is relatively new and at Zen if you want to enjoy Japanese style.Deluxe rooms are recommended for their quality but Standard & Quality rooms are equally good except the bathrooms in these rooms are bit crampy.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Great location, very pleasant staff, clean and comfortable rooms. A bit pricey though.
user_name:
Annie O
Lehi, Utah, United States

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The Hotel New Otani is a refuge in the heart of Chiyoda Ku. One of the busiest commerce areas of Tokyo. We've been back three times to this Hotel when in Tokyo and cannot speak highly enough of the establishment and it's staff. The staff are attentive without being overbearing, (as is the Japaneese way), the rooms and suites, we have stayed in both are outstanding value. All the accoutrements one might expect of a 5 star hotel are in abundance at the Hotel New Otani.Ask for a high level floor the view over Tokyo at night is breath taking.The subway is only 200m away and on the main line into Shinjuku, Ropongi, & Shibuya.The garden is a standout.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is one of the older and bigger hotels in Tokyo, with the service you would expect from established, well known hotels, different from the contemporary business styled hotels. The Otani has a established and respected reputation in Japan. It is situated centrally with 5 min walk to a roofed subway connector that gets you to 3-4 different metro lines. It has a beautiful Japanese garden, which is one of it's charms. Stay here if you want old class charm and service in the heart of Tokyo, with character more than waht you find in big chain hotels. (hyatt, hilton, marriott etc) Don't stay here if you want in and out fast, efficient service and on a quick business trip. Rooms are good sized, even for a standard (remember this is Tokyo..) and the hotel has a "garden wing" and "main wing". we stayed at the 'garden wing" which is the newer additon.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Located in central Tokyo with very easy access to a central subway station with multiple lines the New Otani is set apart from its 4-star hotel peers by the wide variety of options available to a traveler whether it be rooming, dining or leisure. Upscale business travelers should consider the Zen floors (9th & 10th) in the main building which offer a lounge with true bespoke service and very modern, luxurious rooms. Vacationers can choose from a wide variety of rooms and suites in multiple price ranges by studying the web site carefully. With more than a dozen restaurants in the complex, the New Otani offers the most dining choices (and for all budgets from super expensive French to local tonkatsu) of any Tokyo hotel. Trader Vics is a fun place to visit with its upscale, romantic (darkly lit) Polynesian atmosphere though a bit pricey. The 400 year old Japanese garden is worth walking through (by far the best of any hotel) and can be viewed from one of the coffee lounges offering an impressive view through magnificent floor-to-ceiling windows. Activities include on-premise tennis courts (3 in fact!), garden walks, spa services (with an in-room option) and a large gym/pool.The clear downside is that despite the recent renovations (2009~2010), the hotel still feels dated and for business travelers, it may feel a bit out of the "hustle and bustle" of the city. This isolation and time warp can be good or bad depending on one's view. As the hotel is certainly not in vogue, excellent value can be found by studying all the options available.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We had to chose somewhere to stay before a morning flight from Narita and this proved to be a great choice. The hotel,itself has friendly, helpful staff and a wonderful rooftop bar with stunning views. It is also very close to the restaurants and bars of Asakusa. Only quibble - no wifi!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed at this hotel several times , it is handy for the subway system and walking distance to my office when in Tokyo. The rooms are dated but clean and well equipped. It has has possibly the worst Tv channel avialabilty for international travellers ever, They even seem to dub most of the English channels in Japanese, so if the weather is off or if you work in room , be prepared.............

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I've occasionally chosen to stay here for the past 15+ years, and it's never let me down. The New Otani is conveniently situated in Tokyo's Akasaka district, and is a 5 minute walk from Akasaka Mitsuke Station and 10 minutes from the JR Yotsuya Station. In the past, the hotel would've been considered 5-star, but time and competition have relegated it to 4-star status at best. Not for the service, which is as terrific as ever, but the rooms, at least the ones in the (Garden Court) Tower. Rooms in the Tower are older, smaller and showing their age - for one, internet is still via LAN (no WiFi), not to mention that power ports are very minimal in the rooms. Even worse, the port is behind the desk and is very hard to reach (I had to physically move the table and crawl under to plug my laptop into the wall.)While the rooms in the Main building are nicer, they are priced much higher. Therefore, you have a choice of staying at a so-so room at a competitive price, or a nicer room but at a price that's at least 50% more. For the price of a room in the Main building, travelers will have other choices in the area, most notably the ANA InterContinental.For me, the Tower rooms do the job since they're a great value, and I just make sure to bring a power strip so that I can plug all of my gadgets during my stay. Works like a charm.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I booked a room at the Garden Tower, and following the advice of other TA reviewers I joined the New Otani Club. Upon check-in I was offered a room at the Main, but it was a smoking room and preferred to keep the original booking. The room was nice enough; the furniture and general decor was too old and in need of refurbishment, but it fulfilled my needs, and I especially liked the view of the Shinjuku skyscrapers from one of the windows.If you are into bouquet and cosy hotels, stay away, because the New Otani is so big that it feels a bit cold and impersonal. But it has a very convenient location, next to a subway station on the Shibuya line, so it's a quite good option when staying in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed here as part of a business trip, which covered the expenses. This hotel is located in Akasaka near the Akasaka Mitsuke station. It is one of the older style all encompassing luxury hotels, and so it is a huge complex of two hotel towers with many shops and restaurants and other services (even babysitting), so it is easy to just stay within the hotel the whole time. However, this can be quite expensive, as most of these shops are high-end. The hotel is situated on a beautiful, 400 year old Japanese Garden that is really worth a long visit. The rooms in the upper floors have very nice views of the city or the garden or both. The neighborhood is mostly office buildings, and from what I could tell, not very exciting for exploring.The service is very good, as with most hotels in Japan, and they will try to help you in any way they can. I did run into some attitude from one staff member, and I think it had to do with being a foreigner. Most of the hotel staff can speak only rudimentary English, so be prepared. My room was in the Garden Tower. Two things about the rooms really surprised me (in a positive way). First, the rooms are absolutely immaculate, and probably the cleanest I have ever experienced. They are cleaned thoroughly each day. True, the decor in the Garden Tower may seem a little outdated, but I didn't find it to be shabby, and the cleanliness of room made up for it. Second, the rooms are incredibly quiet. I think the hotel was quite busy with numerous guests coming and going during my stay, many as large groups for business events, but I never heard any noise from neighbors or people in the halls at all when I was in my room. It was by far the quietest hotel I've ever experienced.The space in the room is small for western standards but it's laid out very efficiently, and if you are short it's not so much of an issue. The bed is hard and low--which is great if you like hard beds, but for those who prefer big high fluffy beds this may not be your thing.The restaurants in the hotel tend to be very expensive and on the posh side. The sushi restaurant Kyubey has a renowned sushi chef, supposedly one of the best in Tokyo and Japan. There are also a few restaurants that are quicker and somewhat cheaper, but you have to find them. I found that the hotel website was the best place to determine where to eat, as they have the menus and also maps that show the location of each of the restaurants (which is helpful because it is easy to get lost in the hotel).If being stuck in a hotel complex (even a large one) all day is not your thing, and you are up for exploring other neighborhoods of Tokyo by subway, then it is very close to the subway station (Akasaka-Mitsuke). There is a shortcut through the hotel (via the Garden Court entrance) so the walk is not far. Also based on previous reviews, I signed up to be a New Otani Club member before I left. Since I did this only a week before my trip, my card did not get mailed to me at my home in time. However, I found that they had it at the desk when I checked in. There are some perks to being a NOC member, (like a free newspaper, some free services like laundry, and some discounts at the restaurants), and signing up is free, so it is helpful to become a member.Some things to note:-There is no wifi in the rooms. Based on some previous reviews, I brought an internet cable along, but I didn't need it in the end one was provided in the room). Internet use induces a charge to the room (not cheap).-The toiletries do not include lotion unlike most western hotels.-Also, there is no iron and ironing board in the room (in case you were planning on ironing your clothes!).-There's an exercise room in each tower, but it is small (for the machines, only one treadmill, two ellipticals, and two bicycles. For some inexplicable reason, there are also chairs and stools).

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My wife and I stayed in a main standard room, and because we received such a good price, I feel as though the value was very good. I think the pictures we found beforehand were an accurate representation of what to expect.This hotel does look dated at this point, and the style is something I would expect to see in Las Vegas, especially in the lobby and shopping areas. However, the room was noticeably and tastefully refreshed (except for the bathroom) and was comfortable, if just a bit too small for two with luggage. The walls were thin, but I only knew that when I heard our neighbor cough and it sounded like he was in our room. Fortunately the staff did a good job of keeping some rooms empty around us, so it wasn't a problem. The bed was just a bit too hard for my taste, even for a Japanese style. Great bath products, and a hot shower with great pressure.We had a very good breakfast in one of their restaurants, and though it was expensive, it was excellent and kept us going until dinner. Overall, the service was excellent throughout the hotel.The gardens are quite beautiful, and there is a cute restaurant in there which we wished we had tried. The location is very close to several subway lines, and once you figure out how to exit through the Garden Tower, you can get to the trains in 5 minutes. Overall, we enjoyed our stay here, but I think we would try another option next time in Tokyo. Still, this is a great place for exploring the city, especially for those in the older set or if the price is a bargain.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I came to this hotel 10 years ago and I thought it was adorable. Now Im in Tokyo again and decided to stay there again. What a bad idea...I did my reservation through hotels.com for 3 non-smoking rooms (2 adults, 1 children - 10 years old). They tried to put me into two single bed rooms. I asked where the children were going to sleep and they tried to charge me for extra beds. I didn't accept this and than they moved me to triple rooms - one of them with a horrible smell of cigaret. Tried to complain again but they said it was the only room available.Next day in the morning wake up, drank my pre-workout supplement and went to the "gym" or "fitness center". Well... they SAY its a fitness center, but believe, it's not. They have a couple of treadmills and elipltical and that's it. No weight lifting equipment at all. Went to other one on the next building and it was the same thing.We are almost in 2012! Every 3-star hotel have at least a decent fitness center! New Otani Tokyo was suposed to be a 4/5-stars hotel!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!They have a thing on the 3d floor of the garden tower called "GOLDEN SPA" where you can pay around 80 dolars PER USE and it looks like they have a better gym. I guess I'll never know because I asked to make a quick tour to see what kind of weight lifting equipments they have and they said I could not make a tour. What????? Im not paying 80 dollars without seeing the gym! And come one, is this the world most expensive gym or what? Regarding the rooms in the garden tower, they look like they hadn't change since the 90's.Believe me, I'll never come back here again. And I don't recommend this hotel to anyone.
user_location: Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
user_name:
paulinhofig
Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: New Otani can be a bit worn at the edges but the Main building is now absolutely first class as is the service throughout the hotel. Food is expensive but there are plenty of places to eat nearby. Location is quieter than Shinjuku but there is still plenty going on and transport connections are excellent. The fantastic hotel garden is a good reason for going back.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I've stayed at several hotels in Tokyo, and this my second sojourn to the New Otani. The majority of the 4 star reviews are spot on - it's not the glitziest, the shiniest, the newest. It has a familiar, homely quality though, which makes stepping out of the taxi a comforting experience.It is best seen as a great vantage point from which to jump into all that Tokyo has to offer. The intersection of 5 metro lines within 50m walk is a bonus that cannot be overlooked. And Akasaka has some terrific spots for a quick bite to eat, with a little flash built in.For us mobile roadwarriors, do note there is no WiFi access, only broadband via RJ45 cable in the room - speed very good and the price reasonable, about US$15/max day. I have a MacAir and did need to pop out to buy the RJ45 adapter, though this gave a charming young concierge the opportunity to practice his english on the crazy lady who looked him in the eye and said 'Apple Store!'.This trip I was 'gifted' with a 5.3 earthquake in the early hours of the morning. The room shook a bit, nothing cracked, and no panic ensued. Seriously, what could I truly complain about after that!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: A good central location with easy access to central Tokyo. I have used this hotel 3 times now, because of it's location. The rooms are a little tired now.Service at the hotel is excellent.5 minutes walk there are bars restaurants in narrow streets, plenty of good casual food, and drinks.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: and a cup of coffee is 12 euro. This massive 1600 bedroom complex is nice enough to stay in but peripheral services are completely outrageous and out of all proportion to anywhere else I have ever stayed. If you do not have to pay for anything and are working for an investment bank, you would probably choose a newer hotel, but if you actually have to put your hand in your pocket, it is hard to understand why to choose the New Otani. Unless you bring your portable gym and your kettle with you. Seriously. On a more positive note, the views are great, the location is excellent and the staff are superb. It's the little things that get me.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The rooms are wonderful, but the gardens surrounding the hotel are nearly worth the price to stay there.. Also enjoyed the buffet in the lobby restaurant. Great transportation hub out front. A quieter, parkland alternative to staying in Shinjuku.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I went with a tour so I barely spent too much time. It was clean quite and had friendly staff.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is a perfect place for a first time visit to Japan. The staff were friendly and courteous. They spoke Engish very well and were willing to accustomed to helping foreigners in the hotel and around the city. The restaurants in the hotel were excellent but pricey. The rooms came with hot water pots that let you make tea or noodles. This was convenient when jet lag set in or I wanted to save a few yen. The hotel is built on absolutely beautiful grounds with an over looks Tokyo tower and the city is a sight at night. This hotel may cost more than others but the service they made my vacation much more enjoyable.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was in the older tower, so experience my be different in newer tower. Location is good, convenient with bus to Narita, restaurants nearby. Room felt cramped and small, room service was extremely expensive. I felt this was an "ok" hotel and would stay again if there is a good deal on price, otherwise I will look elsewhere.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Very dissappointing. Be careful as the name "new" Otani is anything but new. We stayed for 5 nights with two kids in a tiny room with an extra bed.Despite the hotel being very quiet we were given a room which overlooked concrete highways, not the famed 400year old garden.The room was tatty and old with holes in the chair and had a general worn look. One of the reasons I booked here was the pictures of their great swimming pool HOWEVER they charge Y5000 per person (USD60) for a swim and do not allow under 18 yr old children. So in the heat of summer, at the end of a hot day touring Tokyo we had nowhere to relax other than a tiny room overlooking the freeways and concrete.When I approached the front office manager requesting a change or upgrade to make our stay more enjoyable, he wanted an additional USD200 per night for a "newly" refurbished larger room. He did not seem to hear that we were not happy.Concierge and laundry staff were exceptionally helpful though and added a small happy touch to an otherwise dull, experience. Location is perfect with easy access to the subway.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The Hotel New Otani is a very nice business type hotel with easy access to the rest of Tokyo via subway (the station is just a couple of blocks from the hotel). The property is huge - we stayed in the main section, not the garden tower, and had a small but well-appointed room that was fine for a couple of nights (and this being Tokyo, larger rooms are hard to come by). The gardens looked lovely but as it rained during our stay we didn't go out to explore. Overall, I would definitely recommend the hotel.One tip - if you like coffee in the morning but don't want to pay the steep prices for a full hotel breakfast, there is a decent coffee shop in the office tower that is attached to the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed here for a week on a cycling trip with my brother. Clean , comfortable, very polite and attentive staff, could not fault it. Expensive for food and drink but what would you expect in downtown Tokyo.Pool is "seasonable" but not open in June!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is a typical but pretty standard luxury business hotel, everything is there. All services you expect from a 5 star hotel are there. Reasonable good English speaking friendly staff, except for the breakfast room. Spacious rooms are excellent and well maintained. Free morning newspaper service. Lot's of restaurants, for a hotel pretty extensive shopping mall. Beautiful garden. Pool was closed while we were there. No wifi connection in rooms only in the lobby wifi is offered at a ridiculous rate. Great location to discover Tokyo, not far from subway stations.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I spent two weeks in this hotel during February 2011. I had a Quality Double type room in the Main (not Tower) building and it exactly matched the room shown on their pages. Everything but few things was just perfect. First being absence of WIFI, either complimentary or paid, only paid cable line was available. Second is that there is obviously not one type of Quality Double, but there is also Quality SemiDouble, which lacks european power plugs and is somewhat smaller - this type of room is not even advertised on their pages. Also it looked to me that the Tower building is rather some kind of vacation hotel for middle-class Japanese tourists, but that's not the case of the Main. Overall, it was a pleasant stay and I would recommend it for business trip. However, I would not go there for a vacation, since it is too expensive and somewhat cold. Japanese garden is awesome.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed here for one night with a friend. The hotel is unbelievably huge and has zero character or atmosphere. We checked in and were taking to our room by the bell boy- the walk to our room to a good 15 minutes. The corridors are lined with shops, which, unless you arrive during the day, make the place seem quite deserted as they were all closed. Our room was average- the furniture was very outdated and the cost of anything in the minibar was very expensive. We did have a nice view- you could see all the skyscrapers of Shinjuku in the distance- but there were quite a distance. We went to have a drink in one of the bars in the evening and everywhere was totally deserted. There were three people in the bar and about 6 members of staff. The drinks were expensive 1100¥ for a beer (about £8.50, $13.50) so we only stayed for one. The location of the hotel isn't very good- its about a 15-20 minute walk to Yotsuya station. Our stay wasn't terrible but it wasn't what we expected considering it is marketed as 5 star.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We went to celebrate a family milestone, and while we had been there before, each time the New Ohtani gets bigger and busier and more confusing. We went to Trader Vic's for lunch, with it's somehow chintzy interiors, and the food was kind of like a parody of the Trader Vic's we know in San Francisco and Oakland - but without much taste. Nice service at the restaurant, though, which was too bad since the food was dull. The New Otani isn't a five star hotel and the staff of the hotel often seem to struggle with english and with foreign guests, and the rooms are OK but just OK as a rule. Many Japanese guests there seem to come from the countryside; there is nothing at all prestigious or fancy about the place, although again, the people try hard, even if they can't deliver. The interiors seem like a non-wetsren person's take on what must appear to be western glitz. Evocative of parts of new Bangkok in a way. But there are some very pretty areas in the huge garden, like the area where the Japanese restuarnat called Nadamen is located. On the whole, though, the place is kind of clutzy.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: It's a perfect hotel when visiting Tokyo. It's location is good, within reachable distances of most parts of central Tokyo. It has a fantastic garden with waterfall. The staff is incredible. Restaurants are terrific. Breakfast fantastic with view of the beautiful gardens.Stay there!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Our visit to this hotel was very memorable as we were there when the earthquake hit. The staff were very good in providing us with tips on what to do post-quake, e.g. if the train lines were up and running and the best way to get to the airport. The hotel was also very generous in opening its lobby up to guests who could not return to their room and stranded workers who could not get home after the quake - providing them with robes, water and chairs while they waited the night in the lobby. Fortunately for me, there was no damage to my room and I was able to stay in my room and not the lobby. The rooms are clean (and we were given an upgrade to the Main Tower room which was very nice). There are many restaurants in the complex if you do not feel like going out for dinner which were quite nice - I recommend the Yakitori Restaurant in particular! There are also convenience stores, chemist and a post office within the complex which make it quite convenient. There is also a beautiful Japanese Garden within this complex.The hotel is in a very central location with the station nearby and lots of food in the area. I would definitely go back and stay - the staff were very good especially noted after the earthquake and the location is very central.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel is very memorable as we experienced the big earthquake after check out. We stayed the night at the hotel lobby along with the other people and I couldn't ask for a better place to be stranded in. On the prior nights when I was still checked in, I enjoyed the service and most of all, the location. The hotel is walking distance to shops, a university, a Catholic church, the city center where most of our business meetings were. The staff speaks English and are very accomodating.I will definitely go back. This is also my chance to thank the hotel people for taking care of us when we were stranded there and for the amazing service.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Staying at the New Otani for the second time for an extended business trip to Tokyo proved to be a good choice. The connection to both international airports (Narita and Haneda) via airport busses is excellent (approximately 1 hour transfer time coming from Narita and going to Haneda), and the check in service was efficient, friendly and accomodating. The hotel is vast, and it pays to ensure that one is booking a room in the main tower of the complex: the rooms are freshly renovated, well appointed and nicely furnished (stayed in a deluxe king room). The value for money is quite good - if one chooses to become a New Otanic Club member; this is due to the fact, that NOC members not only receive substantial discount offers (in this case: 50% reduction), but also collect NOC points, which can be used in the hotels restaurants and for hotel services etc. The level of service at New Otani is very good - with friendly personnel and high quality of English spoken by almost all staff encountered. The choice of eateries and top restaurants is more than sufficient, but of course most high quality establishments come at a price (like "Tour d'Argent" etc). The room service is of high quality and equally high service standards are offered (very quick delivery and friendly staff) - again, this does come at a price, as it is to be expected from a 5 star hotel in Tokyo. The only real drawback is the breakfast choice: I took breakfast in the garden restaurant, which offers a fabulous view onto the Japanese garden (which is a really nice and unique feature). Unfortunately, the breakfast choices do not live up to the standard of a luxury hotel: the buffet does not even offer warm food choices, and only the most basic bakery and some small chees items. The breakfast service offers such a stark negative contrast to the prevailing quality and service level at New Otani that I find it best to advice guests to forego this offer. Otherwise, a predominantly positive experience might be tainted by an unfortunately negative impression at the start of your day. So skip the breakfast, and enjoy a good hotel choice in a really central area with some good value options for Tokyo standards.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: HUGE Hotel but still seemed very Japanese. Rooms were big and clean and very bright. Had many Restaurant options but there were also a few local places close by. There was still a language problem, most of the Hotel Employee's only spoke Japanese.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed at the New Otani Hotel in Tokio in September 2010. The room was nice with a great view to the nearby ocean. The beds are really comfortable and the room was really clean. Room service is unfortunately really expensive but nice and friendly. Unfortunately they do not offer 24h room service. It is situated in the Makuhari area, about 10 min walking distance to the underground. It takes about 45 min to Tokio Station.What I really missed is a bar and a real lobby.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: very nice hotel, took others' advice to book into the Main building and must say it was the right thing to do, the Garden Tower looked less attractive (from the outside anyways). Nice view, perfectly clean and freshly renovated room. It is not ideally located but that's not a problem, only max 5 minutes walk to the metro station, and must say, the location provided somewhat of a restful character to where one sleeps, not in the middle of the crowd. Would stay there again if ever back in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: BEWARE!Make sure you're booked in the main tower. The other tower is ancient. Very outdated and smells like the 1970's. The bar at the top of the main tower was amazing with the revolving restaurant. The older bar close to reception was awesome too. Staff were very willing to help.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The only positive thing about this hotel is its location - very central to some main attraction and business centers. Other than that, I found this place not to leave up to its price range. The check in was very slow and there were some language complications with the staff. The room was clean and had basic things in it, however most of the appliances were old. The room, while being non-smoking, had some smell of a smoke. The restaurant was big, but the breakfast was nothing special. Dinner service was nice, but it was rather pricey and a less expensive option could be found outside of the hotel.Overall, I would look for a different hotel in this price area.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed in many 5 star hotels owing to my multiple business trips. As a business travellor one would want the hotel to be near to business districts and also conveniently connected to the city in case one gets time to see the city. New Otani at Chiyoda-Ku in Tokyo is a nice hotel with a good spacious room (great value for money spend) and multiple options for dining within the hotel premises. Its well connected with the Narita International airport using the Airport limo bus service which was a very convenient 1 hour ride to hotel from airport (door to door). The room has all the modern amenities a well travelled executive will like to have to relax after a hard days work at office. Hotel has ample choice for breakfast, lunch and dinner and is about 15-20 minutes on cab to the famous Ginza complex in Tokyo. I liked the hotel and would surely stay there again when i go to Tokyo next.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We have stayed at the New Otani several times and keep going back, in part because location and service are excellent. We have not found any real flaw with the hotel. Yes, the rooms are a bit on the small side, but that is pretty common in Japan.The Main building is a lot nicer than the Tower, but you will also pay more. I recommend joining the New Otani Club, various useful benefits at no cost.
user_location: City of San Marino, San Marino
user_name:
mugwump888
City of San Marino, San Marino

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I had no real qualms with this hotel. Just a big decent from big expectations. A lot has been refurnished and updated, since it's an old antique-ish hotel. But at times it still felt as if I was time-traveling into the 1980's when around some cheesy golden railings, or the empty depressing shops on the B1 floor. However, the room was very clean, ample space, gorgeous view and windows, remodeled room, but the bathroom was definitely reminiscent of the early nineties or an average Tokyo business hotel. Dined at the Belle Vue Italian "fine" restaurant on the 40th floor of the Garden Tower. It was a nice restaurant, not many spoke Japanese on staff, the foods had Japanese twists to them like the: Gnocchi made from さつまいも (Japanese sweet potato). But surprisingly it was the best caprese salad I ever had. The wine list is very pricey for so-so to shouldn't-be-that-expensive wines. The 110g Japanese Filet was 8,900 円... but a delicacy. The bar next foor has a spectacular view of the Tokyo Tower and you can have a nice glass of Hibiki Whiskey while gazing at the skyscraper stars and smoke a nice Cuban. All in all, the Hotel New Otani has a legendary reputation as a classic hotel here in Japan. Unfortunately, this old fame with a new facade is what they're trying to cling on to. I've experienced much better valet, front desk, and and all hotel service at other establishments from Shinjuku to Ginza. I just wasn't blown away.But why not give it s shot. It is indeed a nice place.By the way, if you're a fan of true modern and sleek, please look elsewhere!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed in this hotel for two days at the start of our trip in the Garden Tower and 7 days at the other end of our visit to Japan in the the Main Tower. Both rooms were good, small as you come to expect in Japan but if you unpacked your cases into the drawers and wardrobe so you didn't need to keep going in and out of your bags it was fine.The rooms are clean, modern finishings and well appointed with everything we needed - had the usual hilarious toilet / bidet combinations with heated seats and heaps of buttons. Staff are friendly with good English and very helpful.The subway is close, we used Akasaka Mitsuke station just across the bridge but there are others nearby, we simply found it easier to keep using the one, you get a subway map at the front desk or subway stations and it is really easy to find your way around even changing lines. Once we found we'd got on the right line going the wrong way but no problem, got off next stop switched sides of the platform and got on the right train maybe two minutes later.If you head the same direction as the subway from the hotel there are loads of restaurants here - and although I love Japanese food, at breakfast I can only handle a cuppa and pastry or toast so there is a Starbucks there too. Near the entry to the subway is a 7/11 for anything else you need and there always seems to be a vending machine handy to grab a bottle of drink (you can use your PASMO subway card on a lot of vending machines).Internet is available in the room at extra cost, if you do much online we found it cheaper to buy either the 24 hour period or one week than pay by the minute.The airport limousine bus comes right to the hotel and as we travelled late we found that the easiest way to and from the airport at similar cost to train and less dragging our bags.We got a good price on Expedia considering it was cherry blossom time, very popular for tourists, think it was about A$220 a night.We are staying here again in winter 2011 when we visit (got an even better price) and would definitely recommend it to friends. It is worth joining their club, it's free and we got free late checkout which was great as we had a late flight and other little bonuses.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband & I stayed at Hotel New Otani last April for a 9 day vacation. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful and I found their English to be quite efficient (certainly better than my Japanese!). I was especially pleased with the concierge desk. The ladies that staffed this area were very polite and professional. We had a very soft itinerary so they were very helpful in aiding us in our activity selections. They had a map with the subway lined out for just about any activity we could think of. I've read complaints about the size of the place & getting lost - even though we were warned about it, it happened to us too. It was only bothersom on our first day after we came off of a 13hr flight, tired, jetlagged, & hungry. It took us a few attempts to find our way out the right exit. Our room wasn't bad. I was expecting it to be small and it was, but somehow it was optically deceptive in that it didn't "look" as small as it was. Our view was lousy unfortunately. We were on the 5th floor and it overlooked the side of another building. No biggie though as we didn't spend much time in our room. There is an ATM in the bottom of the main tower in the post office. I only mention it b/c we ran out of cash - take more than you think you'll need b/c MANY places don't take CCs. They will also provide you a box for shipping home souveniers for a price (naturally). It was expensive to do this, but we got our box on our doorstep in less than a week!I can't comment on any of the restaurants other than to say they were very expensive. We took most of our meals in the Akasaka district right outside the hotel. Word of warning to my fellow coffee drinkers: coffee shops open much later in the day in Tokyo. Very frustrating if you're still on Western time - you may have to wait till after 9am to find an open coffee shop (Tullee's within the hotel included). We had breakfast in the hotel twice. Once in the open dining area with a great view of the gardens. The food was disappointing for the price at this location. There is another breakfast buffett near the front entrance and I thought the food was much better there.There is soooo much to do in Tokyo - but for what it's worth, some of my favorite things:Take the day trip to Mt. Fuji - very informative and fun. Go see The Great Buddah in Kamakura - neat village around there with shops and shrines. Alot some time to spend in Harajuku - Wow! Great people watching and a shoppers dream. Definately go to the Tsushigi (sp?) fish market. If you'll be jetlagged, you may want to do this on your very first day since you'll likely be awake at 4am anyway. (If the fish market is a "maybe" on your itinerary, move it to the top of your list) Try Japanese kareoke - there is one right accross from the hotel. This was so much fun we did it twice.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel is located quite conveniently within a short walk of both Akasaka Mitsuke and Yotsuya station and a couple other nearby. Thus you can get onto most suburb lines easily. A short walk away is the Sophia University and along that road are beautiful cherry blossom trees on a slight incline and overlooking the park. There are myriads and I mean myriads of tiny shops and boutiques of all kinds in this hotel which is actually almost three different hotels in three towers, all connected at different levels and we never finished seeing all of it from the inside. There are several options to eat inside, but obviously expensive as this seems more of a business hotel, but we just walked towards Yotsuya on a couple of occasions when stuck and there are plenty of realworld options like Subway, a fast food outlet (like First Kitchen, Fresh burger etc which are the Japanese versions of McD or BK). All in all, the hotel was clean, staff very friendly, helpful and efficient (no different anywhere in Japan though) and the rooms were very very roomy, unlike some others. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel to anyone if they have the budget to spare.A tip - sign up to the membership (check out the hotel's official site) well in advance so you can avail of some benefits available only to members.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani Tokyo for seven nights in the second half of July 2010 for a vacation. We booked for a standard triple room as we have our eight year old with us. We were upgraded to their deluxe triple room which located on a corner, at the end of the wing, facing the Tokyo Tower. The deluxe triple room is almost like a mini suite, about 700sq ft, with a separate living area, and a bedroom. The staffs are excellent. The attention to details is simply amazing. The tea cups, and the teaspoons so precisely lined up every single day. The fresh flower in the vase on the vanity was changed either two or three times during our stay.The Japanese Garden is breathtaking. Our eight year old was thrilled checking out the kois on the pond, and by the waterfall. When we were in the Japanese Garden, we felt that we were in an oasis, so serene and peaceful. The outdoor sports facilities are amazing. We had stayed at other hotels in Tokyo, we've never seen anything quite like this before, it's a resort in the middle of the bustling Tokyo.The location is great, the subway station is just right across the bridge from the hotel. And across from it, there are small streets lined up with all sorts of restaurants. We would come back to this hotel next time we are in Tokyo, and highly recommend this hotel to everyone.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: A stunning hotel with an incredible garden in the heart of Tokyo. Walking distance to lots of restaurants and not far from the other sites. Not cheap but nothing is in Tokyo for 4-star hotels. Top marks for breakfast buffet.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: It was confusing that the hotel has some entrances, which made me difficult to identifly where is the right access to. I was assigned at a room in old building. View from the room was marverous, however, aged furniture are not 5-star-level comfort.The beautiful garden is absolutely must-see!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We like to stay at hotels where we can pretty much walk to a lot of attractions and places. This hotel, while mid-range luxurious, was close to a subway station, but a little bit far from Tokyo attractions. Service was impeccable and people were polite. The boutique stores in the hotel were fun to browse. The room was your average room the size of which we're used to encountering in the US (rather than Japanese-sized rooms). The gardens are delightfully peaceful with the man-made waterfall and momoji trees. The restaurants in the gardens were a bit pricey, but strolling through the grounds was a nice treat each day.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed in this hotel for a few nights at the start of our visit to Japan this summer and it was a great choice. The premises were clean and elegant as was our room. The staff were extremely helpful (although their English was not the best) with gentle smiles and manners. The concierge desk was especially fanttastic in providing maps and pamphlets for all tourist attractions (including out-of-town trips). The swimming pool was by payment (unless you are a New Otani club member) as was the gym. We only visited the pool which was ok. Several boutiques in the lobby and extremely well-located for touring Tokyo (just a few hundred meters from the metro station).

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We have just returned from an 8 night stay at the New Otani in the Main Buildiing. We booked two rooms, both spacious and comfortable by Tokyo standards. The worst complaints: 1. too much furniture, 2. not enough dresser drawers. The best aspects: 1. location--easy access to subway, cabs 2. numerous restaurants--all of excellent quality, if pricey, 3. superb staff. This is my second trip to Tokyo and I would definitely stay here again. It's expensive, but amazing breakfast buffets included (3 restaurant choices)at appx $30USD for 4 made the room prices more appealing. The subway is walkable...but....this hotel rivals anything you'd find in Vegas, so wear your sneakers...cabs are accessible at all hours, but they charge Tokyo prices...beware.The hotel is truly spacious, modern, well-equipped and staffed. And the air conditioning is EXCELLENT. The baths are small, but highly functional with superb hot water and water pressure. Flat screen TV, no dresser drawers to comfortably unpack.. The beds are firm and comfy, pillows hard as rocks, but I tend to prefer that. Linens are always fresh and housekeeping honest and reliable. Front desk is helpful and polite beyond belief. Try every restaurant.. The Sky Bar is great for drinks and a nice views of the city. Cato's is to die for. The Garden View restaurant is nothing to write home about but there is a yakitori place in the Arcade that is totally authentic and a lot of fun--many locals.When I return, I will definitely stay here .

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This very large hotel is impeccably and very professionally run, with no unexpected surprises and prompt responses. I had left my laptop in a room drawer at checkout, and when I called upon noticing its absence an hour later the housekeeping staff had already recovered and secured it.I stayed in a standard room in the main wing; due to the size of the hotel one must inform taxi drivers which wing is the destination, as they have separate lobbies. The room was as expected, conservative decor, comfortable, quiet, and extremely clean.The hotel is in an upscale area of Tokyo, within a short taxi ride of the government agencies district. In fact, for those who prefer taking taxis, I find this hotel particularly well located, as traffic around it is usually fluid, and the location quite central.There are a number of subway lines nearby.Outside the hotel is a street with some drinking outlets and a number of Korean restaurants, among others.The New Otani often runs special promotions yielding generous rewards for AA and UA mileage program participants, at non-inflated rates.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Finding a room in Tokyo that would accommodate three adults was very difficult. The New Otani provided us with three comfortable beds and a separate living area, as well as, a nice size bathroom. The view of the city from our room was spectacular! We spent our first morning in Japan wandering through the beautiful gardens at the hotel! The subway station was right around the corner. The concierge staff in the garden tower building had a difficult time giving us directions in English, but were very courteous. Great start to our visit to Japan.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Just don't expect a 5-Star, except for the prices! Rooms are small, service is good but not more, breakfast is rather 3-star standard, the pool area is not half as nice as on the pics and costs extra etc...!!! They charged us for an additional bed for the kid (4 yrs) although we booked a 2 bed room - with the explaination "yes, we would expect all the three of you to sleep in one bed"! simple and short: a very expensive disappointment, far away from 5 stars.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The suburb Chiyoda is quite far outside of downtown Tokyo. There is however a subway station in walking distance from the hotel, but it can be quite stressful to commute every day and also expensive! Disneyland on the other hand is only 2 stations away. The hotel itself is not bad, but has missed it's life-cycle update. Windows cannot be opened, just aircon adjustable. For me a reason not to come back! Also the 1990 reminescence style is not really hip anymore. Staff is helpful but English a big, big problem! For me not understandable that an international hotel employs non English speaking staff.There is a beach close by but unusable as spilled with garbage and sewage.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Reading some reviews I wondered if we stayed at the same hotel - I guess there must be some variation in the rooms. We stayed in a deluxe room in the main tower and it was one of the best rooms we stayed in - huge comfortable bed, good TV, bathroom, dressing room, very quite.What impressed me most was the staff - they were so friendly and helpful (maybe using a few words of Japanese to them makes the difference). The garden was great.We only had breakfast there but it was good.Only criticisms - 5000 yen to use the pool is a bit steep, and they would not allow early checkin.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed in the refurbished Main Hotel for 4 nights. The room was modern large and well equipped. The complex is huge and I seemed to spend a lot of time walking through the foyer and small shopping mall trying to find a exit. Service was very good. Some of the restaurants were very expensive, but there was plenty of choice. The Japanese garden is very well maintained and peaceful. Once outside, the hotel was in easy reach of the subway and close to the busy side streets of Akasaka with many places to eat. Internet was very expensive though.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed for one night in the New Otani Hotel. Good location with a subway station nearby and many places for food and entertainment. Very central, so many places are just a short taxi ride away. Room was very small and the furniture looked a bit old, but yet comfortable. All in all, not a bad hotel, if you don't stay in the room most of the day, but if it's only for sleeping at night, one can find cheaper options.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The staff spoke enough english for us to get by. The rooms were serviced daily and were clean. Every day there was a complimentary newspaper, and if you're english-speaking, they give you an English language paper. The bathroom was compact but functional, with a good deep tub to soak in after a long day of walking all over Tokyo. There was also an evening massage service available, The location was great, quiet day and night, but so close to the subway station that there was never any problem getting anywhere .If you're looking for somewhere reasonably priced, in a quieter area to put your head down after a long day at work or sight-seeing, we would higly recommend this hotel. There are too many items to count in the bathroom, replenished daily, and the beds are comfortable, as well as that great bath.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Traveled to Tokyo for work couple weeks back. We were supposed to stay at ANA but it was full so we got stuck with New Otani.I usually would give a more detail review but this will be easy & short with this hotel:Old - very old room & smell so badLocation - 2 stops from Shibuya (so not too bad)That's it. I really don't feel much about this hotel to be honest.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have been a regular at the New Otani for about 15 years and, while I can just about afford it, would not think of staying anywhere else. Booked a room in the newly refurbished Main building and found it to be spacious and immaculate. Staff as competent and pleasant as ever, with everyone I came across having an adequate command of English. My only slight criticism is that the breakfast service in the Garden Lounge, my favourite place for breakfast in Tokyo, was provided mainly by very young women who seemed to be under rather too much pressure, tearing around as if their lives depended on it. Seems absurd that the Keio Plaza, which I also know well, rates above the New Otani on TA. In my view, it is a much inferior hotel.Now that I pay my own bills I no longer eat in any of the hotel's very expensive restaurants (£200 a head in the French version) but there are plenty of reasonable places close to the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We were in Tokyo for 8 nights and the hotel just wonderful. Even by Australian/USA standard, the rooms are BIG and modern.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Great hotel, with lots of good food nearby. Enjoy the beautiful gardens, and waterfall. Quite romantic and peaceful.Rooms are large for Tokyo, and well equipped. Though the hotel likes to nickel and dime, like for internet or pool use, join the New Otani Club, then its free. Restaurants are all 5+ star, with the care, and attention you would expect from such a high end hotel. We ate off sight at several great local restaurants. There is plenty do in the local area, and a nearby train station to venture out anywhere in Tokyo. The airport shuttle took over 2 hours so consider that in your plans. As for the train, it’s a little quicker taking the Narita express to Tokyo Station then subway to Yotsuya station.Join the New Otani Club, its free, and gets you late checkout, and discounts at some restaurants.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel was great. It's GIGANTIC and in a really good location... very close to the metro and also lots of fun placed to eat and drink nearby. We were in a suite, so I can't comment on the standard rooms, but our room was very comfortable and clean, albeit stuck in the 70s. It had a great view (37th floor) and Western style bathroom, TVs, etc. The hotel staff was very helpful and nice.I would not recommend eating at the hotel, however, as the restaurants in the hotel were VERY expensive and there are some really good cheaper options a close walk nearby.Overall, I'd recommend this hotel to anyone. We had a very good experience.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I went to the New Otani expecting a cramped, small and overpriced room. Luckily the room was large, clean and although smoky for a non-smoking room it was adequate. The hotel was elegant but a bit overdone and the staff hardly spoke any english. The beds were comfortable and the washrooms recently redone. The only major problems I found were that it was a bit of a walk (15 min) to the subway station and the restaurants in the hotel are ridiculously overpriced (15 bucks for a salad). The sheer immensity of the complex is daunting but the rooms and beautiful gardens make it a worthwhile stay

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: After staying at other hotels, this is the one I return to and have not been disappointed. Be sure to get the best room that you can afford as older parts of the hotel have smaller rooms that need updated. The grounds are beautiful if you have time to explore and the property is centrally located. The staff speaks english and the food is very good. The views are very good as well.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We booked through Expedia.com and were not sure based on the low price.We ended up being extremely impressed with this hotel.The staff is amazing and speak English very well. The beds are comfortable and so many dining options right there in the hotel. The garden on site dates back to the 1500's and stocked with Koi complete with waterful, turned this quick 2 nighter into a romantic stay for my wife and I. We loved the 40th floor bar with great views of Tokyo tower. Being so close to I think 4 or 5 subway lines made it so easy to get around Tokyo. There was a nice little "neigborhood" nearby with local shops and restaurants too. We ended up doing a 55 minute foot massage session after a long day of walking.If you can afford it, you must eat at the Teppanyaki place in the garden, the food is amazing!
user_name:
Brian M
Long Valley, New Jersey

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Excellent location.We had a wonderful time at this hotel.Definitely coming back !! Make sure you do your research as the hotel offer diferent activities like tea ceremony also has more than 30 restaurants.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I stayed here for 10 days recently. The location was superb as it was a 8 minute short flat walk to the Metro, The Ginza line being the most popular as it takes or connects you to all the major tourists spots. We stayed in the Newer main tower, the rooms were large and well equiped. The meals in the hotel restaurants are very expensive however you have a huge choice of restaurants within a 10 minute walk of the hotel. The only dissapointment was there was no free internet.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed here for 3 weeks when their star attraction a japnese style garden and various pools were not functioning, still the hotel is clearly a landmark in Tokyo walking distance from a palace , and on top of a huge mall and with 3 subway stations in walking distance a great place to also discover tokyo, what i loved where the travel desk in the lobby and cool resturant options in the hotel complex (there were tons)The major negetive was a very poor gym only running machines : ( and also the room service menu is a little limited.But an amazing part is the hotel seems to be a japanese social meeting place so you can see women in gracefull kimono's and families meeting for lunch which made the atmosphere nice and warm

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed at the New Otani Tokyo twice now, in January 2009 and February 2010. My experiences were consistent and both very positive.The rooms (I stayed in the "Garden Tower") weren't remarkable, but were in good shape. The internet access is excellent (typical in Japan), and I was able to adjust the thermostat to my comfort. Whether I had a city view or a garden view made no difference -- each was interesting in different ways.The breakfast buffet on the main level was extremely good, and it was always nice to start the day looking out on the 600-year-old garden. The variety of foods was good, the fruit very fresh, and I consistently found that I ended up eating healthier at the New Otani than at other hotels. The Top of the Tower buffet is a bit more expensive for similar food, and the other restaurant has a larger selection, but can get crowded.For business travel the location is great -- just a block from a major metro station that can access the Ginza, Marunochi, and other lines. The hotel is not in a particularly touristy area, so don't expect lots of attractions, but there are plenty of restaurants and stores nearby.I haven't stayed elsewhere in Tokyo, but I've stayed at several places in greater Asia, and I found the New Otani to be squarely at the Very Good level. It won't blow you away (well, maybe the garden will -- it's wonderful!) but it's reliable and comfortable.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: As a westerner coming for the first time to Japan, I felt this hotel is built to made me feel I never arrived in Japan. Everything is made in pure "tourist trap for westerners" style. It looks flamboyant from the outside, but except for the lobby, the rest of teh hotel is pretty dissapointing. Rooms have a fine view, but the furniture is old. The corridors seem not properly taken care of. Nothing in the hotel is genuine Japanese, and even the nice garden seems a little fake. Personnel seems trained to be unnatural and not very friendly. Everything is heavily overpriced even by Tokyo standards: snacks, room service, internet. You feel you need to pay even for breathing.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed at this hotel with my wife, infant son and a friend of ours. We were trying to save money so we only got one room. They actually have triple rooms available and this one had 3 separate beds plus a sitting area. The view from the room was incredible at night. Perfect skyline view of Tokyo looking directly at Tokyo tower. The rooms/decor are in need of updating but clean and comfortable with all the expected amenities. Our biggest complaint was that the beds were really hard but in my experience that's common in Asia unless you are staying in a western brand hotel. This hotel is a true 5-star. Lots of shops, good restuarants and all the services you'd expect (pool, fitness rooms, spa). Location is good with easy metro access and tons of cheaper restuarants/cafes nearby. Service at the hotel was impecable but I've found that to be the case in every Japanese hotel I've stayed in.For a splurge I'd reccomend Sunday Brunch at Trader Vic's. At $60 it was expensive but allowed you to sample a lot of what they offer on their menu which is something that would otherwise cost a lot more.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My Mom and I stayed at this hotel for six nights while we explored Tokyo. It was a great location, near both the Metro and JR train lines.The property gardens are beautiful - like an oasis in the middle of the city - and the room we had was unsurprisingly small. But it served the purpose as home base. The service was pretty good, with English spoken. The hotel complex is huge and it's not hard to get confused but once you get it, it's easy to know which entrances to use, etc.We didn't eat in the hotel but we did go to a few of the places they suggested, and we were not let down at any of them. We also wandered about the area with no problem. We also had massages in our room which was nice... these two older ladies came in (never judge a book by its cover) and helped our tired muscles.Overall, I would stay here again even if I researched other options just for variety.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is a nice place to stay - almost a city in its own right. The hotel is arranged in multiple tower blocks with a very memorable garden with waterfall and Koi fish. I stayed in the old tower. The rooms were ok but verging on needing refreshing. There are over 60 (yes sixty) restaurants and bars to use so choice abounds. Room service menu was extensive and very rapid service. The Sky Bar rotates offering nice views. Service was good and breakfast in the Japanese Lounge overlooking the waterfall is a nice way to start the day - food here is ordinary but quite satisfactory. For a large hotel experience this is a good choice, so I would return.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Beautiful grounds around the hotel, the Japanese garden was absolute solitude right in the city. The breakfast was delicious. I arrived late at night checked in and walking to the elevator I saw a huge orchestra with people dancing all that was missing was the bubbles. Very elegant hotel

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: After many years in the city, I always recommend this hotel to friends and family visiting Toyko. It's a giant hotel by Japanese standards with expansive lobbies and hallways in every direction as well as wonderful gardens. It serves as a microcosm of the city in that it's very easy to get disoriented and lost, but there are always friendly staff to point you in the right direction. It's just a few minutes from Akasaka-mitsuke station on the Ginza subway line, which can get you directly and painlessly to Shibuya in four stops. I don't recommend spending much time in the hotel as everything is terribly expensive, but if you'd prefer the luxury of reading and speaking English, it's a small price to pay (according to my non-Japanese speaking visitors, that is).

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The Hotel New Otani is in a league of its own when it comes to attempting to nail you to the wall with charges. The staff is wonderful and the place is very clean, but at absolutely every turn the hotel wants to charge you outrageous fees to do anything. From day one they are trying to rent you umbrellas, get you to buy things in their crappy stores. They charge about 13 bucks a day for LAN internet. NOT WI-FI. Then they wanted 5250 yen to use the pool or gym ONCE. Everything they do is an attempt to make your bill larger and it eminates through absolutely everything they do. You end up not feeling like a welcome guest and more like and ATM.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My wife and I have been taking advantage of the cheap fares to travel on weekend getaways. We therefore want a reasonably well located and comfortable place to sleep. The Hotel New Otani Tokyo Garden is a really great choice. I am writing this review now because I have been too busy up to today but really wanted to help any of you that are searching seemingly endlessly for the best option. Stop now here it is. The hotel has three main wings we stayed in the least expensive and had a city view. I would say that the garden view is probably not worth the upgrade. The room was totally spotless and had everything we needed. The bathroom was large. I am a big guy and we had more than enough room and great view. One small piece of advise would be if you need a "cold" room to sleep in keep the black out curtain closed all day and the air on max.... otherwise the air may not have the strength to cool the room down especially if it is hot. The hotel sits on a beautiful piece of property with a beautiful garden which you definitely should walk through. We even popped for the brunch one day simply to look out at it. ps the brunch for Tokyo was good not great when compared to similar typical hotel brunches but we were not disappointed. Across the street is a great neighborhood for finding a good restaurant and it is very close to the metro. taxi's also abound and I did not find them very expensive as we stayed away from busy traffic times and like London the driver's really pride themselves on getting you where you want to go quickly. Honesty is embedded in the culture so no worries there. The hotel is accessible by easy, frequent and not expensive airport shuttles. The staff is totally friendly and could not do enough to help us. The staff treats, regardless of the room so you get, you receive the same gracious service. I was so happy with this choice! enjoy Japan!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: It is very dark, over-priced and the rooms are so old and dated- they are desperate for an update. I have honestly never seen a smaller bathroom in all of my life. The water pressure in the shower was excellent, that is about the only nice thing I can find to say about this hotel. The breakfast buffet was awful, the scrambled eggs are more like egg soup. I felt like I was in prison! There are many much nicer hotels in Tokyo, I would not recommend this one at any price.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We have stayed at the New Otani In Tokyo on a number of occasions. Each time we have never had an unpleasant experience. At check in the staff always try their best to find a room for us even though we generally arrive earlier than the official check in time [2 pm]. The rooms are clean and well equipped with individual air conditioning controls and a large of TV with stations in English, Chinese, French, Korean and German. The cheaper block is known as the Tower Wing whilst the larger rooms are in the Main Wing. The hotel is serviced by a regular airport bus to Narita International Airport however there is only 1 service a day to the domestic airport at Haneda. It is a 5 minute walk to the underground with access to about 5 different lines including the main Ginza and Marunochi lines. It is a taxi trip to the main Tokyo JR station.The hotel is part of a large complex that includes an office tower and shopping. Generally everything you will probably need will be in the complex and within 10 minutes walk in the Akasaka area. During week nights Akasaka is full of office workers and the back streets are very busy but on weekends it is a little quieter.The hotel has a large number of restaurants all of which are on the pricey side - there are cheaper [and expensive] options nearby in Akasaka. Generally this is a very good big city hotel with reliable service. There is a large swimming pool which is opened only in summer and small gyms in each wing. It is in a good location and the surrounding area is quite green and in cherry blossom season in blossom nearby.Booking on the hotel's website is usually the cheapest rate.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I lived in the New Otani for 2 days . The Hotel is a new experience for me because I had never seen a hotel of this size before.In Tokyo, where there is a poverty of space,this edifice stood aloof in arrogant exuberance.The whole hotel is a maze of lounges ,shopping areas and restuarants.The room in which I stayed had a magnificnet view of Tokyo city by the night and as I had forgotten my tripod I couldnt photograph it.The room was spacious,the bathroom well provided for and the decor good.The service was good.The food was good.I would definitely recommend it .

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
