review_body: We had a hard time getting the rooms that we booked 2 1/2 weeks before our arrival. They said it was fully booked. But how come they confirmed our rooms? After telling the front desk people how come there is only one room available upon our check-in, they were still insisting for us to wait for another hour or so for the room to get ready. We had a 2 1/2 hrs. ride in the shinkansen from Osaka and the whole family were quite tired. I had to insist on calling for the manager and after some time Mr. Furuya, the Manager on-duty came out. He turned out to be a nice person and upgraded our rooms. Instead of a double room, he gave us a triple room and instead of a triple room which is the other room that we booked he upgraded it to a suite. We had big rooms with separate living rooms! At the end, we were very comfortable with our stay but the rooms need a little facelifting. It is also near the train station which is very accessible to hop around Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was a business traveller to this hotel for a week. I have to counteract some off the rave reviews I see here and just say that this is strictly an average hotel, nothing special. We got a very good rate (about 15500 yen) so that was good but even at that price I will make an effort *not* to stay here again next time I need to work in Tokyo again. Here are the good and the bad:Good: About 100 yards from a subway stop (of course this is after walking 200 yards from your room to the front door - see "bad"), absolutely top notch sushi bar in the garden wing lobby floor (6th floor) although you'll pay 11000 yen for the omekase which is over priced, stunning 400 year old secluded garden on hotel grounds including a beautiful waterfall that you can see from one off the main restaurants with huge fish in the ponds and feral cats running around, nice view from the top floor restaurant including of Mt Fuji on clear days, Taxis are always available and waiting so if you need one, no problem (though in Tokyo they are extremely expensive). Service is good.Bad: Air conditioning does not work well and does not remove enough humidity. This is not an isolated issue as my coworkers who have stayed here several times over the last several years have attested. This will drive Americans crazy as we tend to like our AC. The western breakfast in both major cafes are *really* mediocre. About the only thing that was halfway decent were the custom made omelets. Otherwise I didn't have a decent breakfast the entire trip. Hotel is extremely spread out, exactly like Las Vegas. Each major wing of the hotel is about 150 yards apart, and it seems to get out of the hotel you need to walk about 5-10 minutes from your room. If you are dressed in a suit and in a hurry this gets old fast. While the Akasaka district offers some fun restaurants, the general area is very sleepy and somewhat boring. You'll need to get on the subway to do much. Garden wing rooms seem to have not been updated in 15-20 years..As a long time Tripadvisor user who was forced to stay here for business reasons, I think you can do better than this place. Keep looking.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Hotel New Otani is massive, but beautiful. The rooms were much larger than I'm used to in Japan, and the view from the windows was incredible at night. If you want a great stay in a "mega hotel" with excellent customer service in Tokyo, Hotel New Otani is a perfect choice.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani for four nights, and were quite impressed. The room was adequate, although the bed was a bit hard. It was kind of stuffy as well, and you couldn't open the window, nor was the A/C turned on in the building yet. Internet rate was reasonable, although I still don't realize why every hotel doesn't include it nowadays. The location was great, only a 2 minute walk from the subway, and some local nightlife. It's pretty much in an oasis in the middle of the city with all the trees, which you see very few of in most parts of Tokyo. I would stay there again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I travel to Tokyo every year for bussiness, in 6 years only once I decided to pick a different hotel (to see a different one mainly), and even though it was a good hotel, the difference was huge. The New Otani is a small world in itself, with over 30 restaurants, a shopping arcade, a beutifull japanese garden, a small catholic chapel........The service is up to the highest standards, although price is on the higher range it is well worth it. Tip: I joined their NOC (Club) years ago, you can do it online and avail of discounts on your reservations. The subway station is only about 25 mts from one of the entrances, and you can get anywhere in Tokyo in no time.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I have just returned from our 2 weeks stay in the new otani hotel... It was recommended to us by my parents who stayed here 30 years ago...Our arrival was smooth with a very warm welcome. We had pre ordered our membership cards... Unless you are a frequent traveler here don't bother. I had read you got a free breakfast and other things no you don't... Anyway we were shown to our first room which had twin beds and a view of a motorway... Back down to reception and a wait of over 2 hours for our next room ( we had also been traveling for over 26 hours by this point...) Any way a room was found on the 36th floor with a view of the gardens. Well worth the extra wait.The room was small and very dated (70s show springs to mind) However it was comfortable and very very clean. Lots of travel essentials in the bathrooms. A complicated toilet. Hairdryer etc.Great tea and coffee things and a cool kettle... Lovely kimonos and robes and slippers. Plenty of info on the hotel which was handy... We tried at one point to have room service to empty the fridge so we could put our own beer in... Slight problem with translation so we just emptied ourselves and put in corner till our departures.We ate in the hotel a few times... Tomcats which is cheap and cheerful although to Smokey for us... Had a great meal in trader vics. great service and the food was great. A little expensive but good. Also ate twice in the bistro next to reception not too expensive and good food but the service wasn't the best... We also had a drink in the bar up on the top floor as the view was amazing and great for photos but the prices were stupid. A beer and wine 25 euros. Also had a drink one night on the ground floor this was just as expensive. But thats hotels for you.The hotel had some great amenities such as 2 handy food shops (don't buy fruit 25 euros for a bunch of grapes). A chemist which was great as I caught a cold on the flight over. A travel agent who gave us times and costs to Kyoto... ( just buy ticket at station its cheaper). A post office with a European ATM. Lots of shops some expensive some not. Its nice to window shop though.The concierge was very handy. Although they were way of with there taxi price advice. They booked all sorts of things for us.The area is akasaka. So much to see and do in this area. Plenty of good restaurants and very easy access to the metro which we used all the time. No need to buy an all day pass all the time... Usually takes a day to explore an area. It was a 5 minute walk from the 36th floor to the ticket machine in the metro station...Should anyone want to ask a question or need prices for anything I would be very happy to help.A great hotel with fabulous staff.Ps Only down side really was the limo bus but doesn't start early enough for 9am flights at this hotel so had to get a taxi to the bus station at 5 am to get our flight at 9am...

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed att this hotel for three nights and thouhad a plesent stay. The service was outstanding och the building was huge. It was like a small town inside the hotel with many diffrent shops and restaurants... but everything was to expensive.We would never stay at this hotel if we were paying the bill ourself, but it was an experiece we do not want to have undone. The breakfast was perfect on the top floor with a nice view over Tokyo. We stayed at 22:nd floor and had a nice view over the hotelgarden and the city.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I really liked the hotel room as the King size bed was huge. The room is very clean and organized. The bathroom is quite big by Japanese standards so I really liked it. I also got a corner room on the 33/F so it had a nice view of Tokyo and a nearby park. This was what I really liked about the room. The room was very spacious and the even had a few different types of pillows in the room that I could try and choose to find the perfect pillow. The slippers are also very soft and comfortable. Overall, I liked the room and a great place to rest after a long day of sightseeing and shopping. Staff's English standards were pretty good too. Concierge was very helpful. Checkout is very quick and speedy.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We booked through [--] for £100 a night, and although it wasn't exactly where we wanted it to be (we were told it was near the station, but it was miles away!) as soon as we saw the place, we were in heaven. It truly is a 5 star place, we couldn't believe our luck. Luggage porters, kingsized bed, amazing view of Tokyo from our room, and the sky bar. Beautiful Japanese gardens, bars and restaurants galore - frankly we could have just stayed in the hotel and had fun! But Tokyo was calling.The hotel was right next to Akasaka, where there are many great bars and restaurants. Sad we only had the one night to explore really.And then there was a bus to take us direct to the airport the next day! Fantastic.I guess if you paid full price it would be steep, but thanks to lastminute.com it was a dream come true!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel was absolutely HUGE, and very attractive on the eyes. Nice carpets, nice shops, classical music over the intercom, tons of restaurants (I loved the revolving one), and well-dressed porters and staff. The onsite garden was amazing, complete with waterfall, koi, and a tea-house! The rooms were a tad small but I didn't spend much time there anyway, there was too much to see in Tokyo. If you don't like walking, I wouldn't reccomend this place.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I stayed at the New Otani for four nights. Three nights we were in the Garden Tower and one in the Main. The Main tower is a newer more contemporary styled Tower. The rooms are the same size, but the Main tower rooms have a floor to ceiling window which gives you a nice view. The Garden tower is a bit dated, but still comfortable. When we got to our room, it was on the 12th floor facing the garden and it was beautiful. We even had a view of Mt. Fuji!! Overall, the hotel is a good choice in that it's a good price (230 for garden, 330 for main) and it's about a 7-10 min walk to the Yotsuya train station.As for the rest of the hotel, the staff was very helpful, attentive, and spoke english. The resteraunts are ok, but we only tried the sushi and the bfast buffet. But, avoid the sushi rest (can't remember the name, in the garden tower). It's below average and a complete rip off. You're much better off going to Roppogi and getting sushi there. As for breakfast, there's a buffett in the lounge area overlooking the garden which is beautiful. If you'd rather have a quick bfast, try the train station (yotsuya). They have a Beck's Coffee shop on street level as you enter the station, that serves a delicious breakfast (eggs, toast, yogurt, coffee or hot choc.) for about 6 bucks!For a 4 star hotel, this is a good deal, convenient location and has great service.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have stayed at New Otani twice in 2008. On both occasions, it was for 3-4 days.The hotel is huge, and has a complex layout. On my first visit, I actually got lost and had to ask my way around. However, the staff is really efficient and helpful. They all speak English, so it wasn't a problem to find my way.The entire complex houses not only the hotel but also several offices, a shopping complex (apart from the one in the main lobby area) and a few other things.The hotel is located centrally in Tokyo, and a short way from most places that one might want to visit. It is a convenient 3-5 minute walk from the nearest Metro station (Akasaka-Mitsuke, if I am not mistaken). Ask the concierge for a map of the locality and they'll be able to give you an English map with everything around the hotel marked neatly on it. Once you have that map, exploring the area is quite easy.As the title of this review says, the Top of the Tower breakfast is a great experience. Not only in the menu very good, but the view of Tokyo is excellent too. The size of the breakfast area is an issue sometimes because there can be too many guests turning up at the same time. Try to go very early or very late to avoid the queue.On the downside, the rooms are a bit on the smaller side. That seems to be the case with most hotels in Tokyo though.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed a week in the hotel for a business trip. Location worked out good for work and getting out in the evening. It is a BIG hotel, kind of reminds me of something in Vegas. I have future travel to Tokyo and will probably book it again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The hotel complex is massive, but once you get your bearings, you'll find it easy enough to navigate.The rooms: From what I hear, the rooms are spacious by Tokyo standards. By US standards the size is just a bit smaller than your average 3 star hotel room. I had a king bed in the garden tower and was fine by myself space wise. The bed was hard and you could feel the springs, but everything else was pretty comfortable and clean. Nice 27" plasma TV, lots of freebie toiletries, robes and slippers, casual kimono sleepwear, and paid minibar. The decor was a bit dated, but overall I thought the room was fine for what I paid compared to other hotels in the area.The food: Western food at the Otani sucks, so stick with Japanese food if you eat there. The main restaurants (the ones that they advertise and put at the forefront of entrances to trick you into thinking that's all that is available) are expensive! Expect to pay up to $50-150 USD for a meal at those places. A few reasonable places include the following:Tully's - Starbucks-esque coffee shop. The coffee isn't great, but you can get a cup of Joe, a ham & cheese hot pocket, and a pastry for less than 10 bucks.Towada and Niizu - These are soba noodle restaurants so they are casual and less expensive. You can get a tasty authentic soba meal for around $20 (which is still expensive for soba, but not as painfully expensive as the other restaurants).The western-style cocktails were no better than the food (bartenders could not make a decent cosmo), so again, stick with Japanese style drinks like sake and japanese beer.The recreation - One of the reviewers said that you had to pay to use the gym. This is not entirely true. The fancy gym cost over $50 bucks to use. But there are 2 "workout rooms" that have a couple elliptical machines, treadmills, and stationary bikes that you can use for free. Also check out the "relaxation room" near the business center and next to the workout room in the Garden Tower that has a shiatsu massage chair that you can enjoy for free. You do have to pay $20 to use the pool.The shopping - There are so many shops at the New Otani, but they mostly cater to middle aged business folks and their spouses. I guess that makes sense.General comments - the New Otani is right next to a Tokyo metro stop, ask the staff which entrance to use to get there as the hotel complex is quite large. The staff are very friendly and accommodating. You can get just about anything by asking the front desk. I borrowed an adapter and rented a japanese cell phone from the front desk. Oh, and you have to ask housekeeping to bring you an iron and they only let you keep it for 1 hour. So I ironed my entire wardrobe so that I wouldn't need to keep borrowing it. The same thing happened when I was in Sapporo - don't know what's up with that. All in all, I was quite satisfied with my stay at the New Otani Hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My wife and I went on a trip recently for 7 days and stayed at the Hotel New Otani. We both found the hotel to be lovely and enjoyed our time there immensely. As previous reviewers have noted the restaurants at the hotel are outrageously overpriced and definitely aimed at the business traveler with an expensive account. But, Tokyo has so many excellent restaurants I'm not sure why you would want to eat in the hotel anyway. The staff was friendly, helpful, and really seemed to have an interest in making sure we were pleased. Because we signed up for the New Otani Club (available on their website) we were automatically upgraded to a better room, so it is worth the effort. One other note is that the staff spoke excellent English: which is very helpful (and rare) in Tokyo. The Hotel New Otani was a great hotel and really added to our wonderful experience we had visiting Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed here on a business trip. The room and food was great. Too pricey for my personal tastes. The Hotel is very large, and is connected to some shops. There's a convenient store too (AM/PM) if you need anything.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed here for 5 nights in April 08 in the 'Main' section and quite liked the hotel. Here's a summary: * Location was quite good - Akasaka Mitsuke metro station is under 5 minute walk and is quite well connected to main sights. Area has lots of restaurants but is smaller and quieter than the main centres and is quite nice for a stroll. * Staff were very helpful and had good English as far as we experienced...helped us check helicopter flights and Tsukigi markets. * The garden is lovely and relaxing... can be enjoyed from the Garden Lounge.* Western buffet breakfast including eggs and bacon to order at the Garden Lounge was delicious and quite cheap for such a hotel when you join the club (for free online) and present your card (1700 yen)* Room was spacious for Tokyo but the bathroom was quite small ... comfy bed though! * One thing to keep in mind...the hotel is HUGE! So not a place to go if you're after a 'cosy' or more personal type of accommodation, but we were very happy overall.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Have just had four days at this hotel, service was superb, BUT hardly anyone spoke english well enough to understand me, ( I Am after all a New Zealander and might talk funny BUT how many ways can you say "Bar" ??????) The view from room was fine we actually SAW Mt Fuji one morning, the staff were helpful and because I had read all the advice from previous guests we knew there were cheaper eating places in basement and that turned out to be true and wonderful. Beware the "Sandwich buffet" in the Garden room unless you are a rugby player or a sumo wrestler you will be swept off you feet at 11.29am when ther starving hordes line up and push you away. Was funny to watch but not funny to be at the back of the ? queue all the time. All in all a great experience and would stay there again in a heartbeat.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed 5 days at this hotel while attending a Government of Japan hosted meeting. The corner room on an upper floor of the tower building was as large as any 4 or 5 star hotel room I have stayed in and well furnished. The bathroom was excellent in quality and size as well as with the toilet articles supplied. It is a huge rambling main floor conecting three buildings. The main lobby and other areas a little dated in their furnishings but clean and high quality. Although there are something like 35 or 37 bars and restaurants, they are pricy, especially the branch of the famous Paris restuarant located on the main floor ($400 easily for the menu without any drinks). The sandwich luncheon buffet overlooking the lovely Japanese garden is worth enjoying but be early as there is a rush and the food starts to run out. Likewise highly recommended is a tea house in the garden and another sushi-type little restaurant hidden in centre of the garden. The breakfast on the 40th floor at $35 is not worth that price except for the view of Mount Fuji which was perhaps worth the price. There is a Starbucks in the lower shopping level which is fine. The staff were very polite and the young lady who took my bags to my room insisted that I not tip which was refreshing.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was traveling on business and just checked out of the Grand Hyatt. Since it was going to be on my dime, I decided to stay somewhere more affordable. I was pampered and completely spoiled with luxury at the Grand Hyatt...so it's not fair to compare. The staff like any 4 star hotel in Tokyo were warm and accomodating. Everyone smiles and tries to be helpful...I wish all 4 star hotels all over the world share that same enthusiam. The room was a good size for Tokyo, but the bathroom was small in comparison. It didn't have any of the fancy amenities that I experienced at the Grand Hyatt, but hey...it's cheaper. The only positive regarding the location was that the nearest subway station seem to connect with every well known tourist area. All in all, even though it was cheaper, for the price I ended up paying, I expected a bit more.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We were only in Tokyo for a day but got a lot out our time by staying in the New Otani. The staff was very hospitable, the gardens were beautiful as well as the view from our room. We stayed in one of the rooms that had not been renovated and was outdated compared to the rest of the hotel. On the other hand, the Otani is in a great location for restaurants and shopping.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We have stayed in August at the New Otani and it was a wonderful experience. Become a member through the hotel´s website to avoid the long check in lines. Because of this card not only did we avoid the long lines, but also had private check in and upgrade to a just recently renovated room with beautiful decoration, flat screet tv and excellent bath amenities and cosmetics. Customer service and concierge are excellent, but do take the leaflets from their desk as there are activities and attractions not mentioned by them. This hotel is considered to be one of the top 5 in Japan, but make sure you get a room in the renovated part of the hotel. IT consists of different buildings, more than 35 restaurants, many lounge bars. Be sure to visit the lounge bar on the top floor where you can have a magnificent Tokyo view by night listening to jazz music (reminded me of New York). The restaurants in the hotel are not the quality you would expect in a hotel of this range but there is a street just accross the hotel with many restaurants, cafes, fast food chains, cigar bar. Also, in the Garden Court (business section of the hotel) there is Tully's coffee (a japanese version of starbucks). There is e number of spas and brand name shops (Armani etc).One of the most beautiful places of the hotel is the 14th ancient garden with traditional plants, lakes, and buildings.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My wife and I spent Christmas at the New Otani. (We were in Tokyo visiting our son who lives there.We liked the hotel. It was very full Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. (lots of young Japanese couples seem to treat themselves to a few nights at the Otani over Christmas).As others have written the hotel is HUGE so avail yourself of the hotel map when you book in.The food in the main restaurants is way too expensive but used to get a taxi into Roppongi at night ( about a 1000 yen) or get a train ( station 5/10 minute walk away ) to where our son lives in Kichijoji which had literally 100's of restaurants at reasonable prices.If you just want a reasonably priced meal at hotel then go to the Aux Bacchanales (go out of Tower exit, turn left and its about a minute away)  [--]Good lunch for about a 1000 yen.Also both the main and tower sections of hotel have 3 floors of shops and restaurants ( you have to get escalator or elevator down to the shopping areas.) You can find coffee bar, pizza etc at normal rates.Just avoid the hotels 'showcase 'restaurants, far too expensive.We had some drinks in the Bar Capri one night and I ask for some rice crackers. 6 were prented, each in its own wrapper.I thought it was like most bars where they give you peanuts or whatever to nibble on for free.I noticed on the bill that the 6 crackers cost 520 yen ,about 40 pence a cracker !The staff are helpful and friendly, the hotel, the room are spotless, .. but the main reason for staying is the 400 year old garden .. breathtakingly beautiful . Each morning if you have breakfast in the garden court restaurant yoy can look out on to the garden.There is also a lovely art gallery.If you intend staying at the New Otani then go on the site and sign up to the New Otani club (its free).It gives you a few freebies (free entrance to art gallery, no service charge for breakfast etc.) so its worth joining.To sum up, we loved the hotel and will stay there again, we will not be ordering any rice crackers though !

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I traveled to Tokyo just after Christmas together with some friends of ours. We chose this hotel because the rate was very reasonable (under USD200/night… we booked the room through the hotel’s website a month before our trip).The hotel is located right next (3 minute walk from hotel room) to Akasaka Mitsuke metro station and a 10 minute walk to a JR station. This meant we were only 3 or 4 stations away from Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ginza and Akihabara. The best part about this hotel is it was built in the 1960’s so you don’t have to worry about getting lost because everyone knows where it isIf you’re a United Airlines Mileage Plus 1K member you can get a free room upgrade. The guy who checked us in ignored this offer but after much “wrangling” he gave us an upgrade to a “deluxe” tower room for 4 out of 5 nights. I must admit he was pretty rude about it and made us feel like we were begging for the upgrade. The “deluxe” room is double the size of a regular standard room, complete with a large living room area. Our room was clean, with a huge bathroom. The room reminded me of the 1970’s because of the dark color scheme they used on the sofas and carpet. You could tell the hotel has been around for years (fair wear & tear) but everything was clean and they gave us an ample supply of Kanebo shampoo, conditioner and shower gel.I tried the in-room massage (JPY6300 for 50 minutes) and didn’t like it but maybe I’m not used to Japanese massages.We had dinner at Nadaman on our last night and had a very pleasant kaiseki dinner. The service was very good but I still don’t understand why they prefer to serve the men first in Japan!We took the airport limousine bus to the airport (the first departure of the day at 6:20am) which took us directly to Narita airport.Most people at the hotel spoke English (some spoke very good English) but we had to speak to a few people to get a reasonable answer if we had a complicated question.I recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani in Tokyo is huge. It consists of two towers, the new and the old tower. I stayed in the old tower because there was a huge price difference between the two. My single, king, room was a corner so it was large and spacious. No complaints regarding the room. The things that I do not like is that they charged me 300 yen ($3) for each toll-free call I made from my room (calling card). This is the first and only hotel that I have encountered this. I ordered room service once when I arrived (tired and exhausted), it was decent, hit the spot, but was about $30 for a fried chicken dinner. If you want to use the pool and facilities expect to pay extra for those $20-$30 per day... ouch. The location is great, right in the center of Tokyo, but there are also hundreds of other that are too. For the price and the service fees this hotel is very over rated and over priced. There are many more newer, trendier, and more personable hotels in Tokyo for the same price.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani is made up of two towers: the original 1964 Olympics tower (which looks austere) and a round-edged white tower built more recently. They are connected by a long corridor and the entire hotel sits on a 10-acre garden that has a small waterfall. (Actually it is a big waterfall if I were to have it but it's a small waterfall as waterfalls go.) The garden is worth a visit. It is intended for the leisurely stroll. There is a teahouse although that was closed when I was there.The executive room I had was very pleasant. The king bed was king indeed. The room was big enough so that my colleague complained that the 42-inch tv looked small when he was watching it from the bed. There is a small working area with lan connection for internet.The bathroom is small but very well stocked with L'Occitane shower, shampoo, conditioner and body lotion. I am still on the road and I took a couple of the lotion.I did not have any of the negative experience mentioned by other reviewers. I had a late flight so I took the morning to visit a friend. I left my bag and my handcarry (laptop bag with no lock) with a staff. He delivered it to the airport bus waiting area. So all I needed to do was to turn up where the bus was with my ticket. My laptop bag was intact and nothing was missing. Amazing.Food at the hotel restaurant is expensive. I had two coffees and a cake for tea and they came up to US$30. I guess someone has to pay for the water pouring down the waterfall.There are two subway stations nearby and they are about 10 mins easy walk. The Akasaka area has one of the train stations and it has a row of cheap (Tokyo standards) restaurants. There are offices in the area so the restaurants are busy during office hours but on weekends they are close to dead.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The hotel complex is larger. We took the airport shuttle through bumper to bumper traffic to the hotel front door. The checkin was easy since we had membership. We were in the towers, the bed was comfortable and we loved the bathroom. We had a great view of the city and the park outside of the hotel. The gym had adequate equipment and there was not an extra charge. The grounds were immaculate and very interesting to stroll in your spare time. It was great that there was a shopping mall in the basement. Breakfast was included and was a great presentation. Dining in the hotel was very expensive, as is all Tokyo. Americans would not appreciate the portions sizes as they are very small. The staff was very formal and very service oriented. Is is a great business hotel and I probaly would not recommend for the budget minded. It is a very short wlak to the nearest subway. I would recommend the hotel

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I tend to stay at this hotel every time I have a business trip to Tokyo.It's very classy and upscale. However, the carpeting on the lobby floor looks very old and moldy with stains.Employees are very polite, and they bow and greet you when you walk by.The rooms are always very nice, although most of the time, you get two single beds in the room. I like the deep bathtub, with the faucet that streams steadily at a set temperature.The only issue I had at that hotel was when a particular hotel manager was very rude to me. I don't think that the manager like the way I looked, as I look very young, and I was dressed extremely casual. He was very rude to me when I asked whether the front desk can charge my credit card for some cash. He refused to do it, until they realized that I was a regular at the hotel.To this day, when he sees me (he still works there), he is not very polite to me.But other than that, the hotel is very nice, and very convenient.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: It was just wonderful to be at Tokyo New Otani Hotel. It is a monument of Tokyo’s history with its 400 years old garden. But the most striking thing about it, besides a high level of professionalism of its management team, was the legendary kindness of the service personnel. It was so smooth and kind that within the ten days we spent there, we felt just like at home. If we have to go back to Tokyo, that will be the place where we would go and we highly recommend it

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I only stayed one night at this hotel and was pleased with the accomodations; it was above average but nothing spectacular. The bed in my room was huge like someone had put together 2 full size or 2 queen size beds. My problem with this hotel was the size. It was enormous. It seemed like you walked across a mall to get to the restaurant of your choice. I had dinner in the Chinese restaurant (buffet) which was VERY mediocre. I do not recommend it. The breakfast was better but it is hard to mess up fruit, dry cereal and pastries!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I just returned from two nights at the Hotel New Otani in Tokyo. This was my first time on Tokyo so I cannot give a good review of the hotel in comaprison to other local properties. It seems the hotel is overpriced (but again, it's my first time in Tokyo so I could be wrong) compared to New York or San Francisco.The room was actually much better then I expected. The beds were nice, and the pillows were nice soft down pillows. The bathroom could use some remodeling but the bathroom products (shampoo, lotions, etc) were fantastic.The rooms did not come with an iron and ironing board which was annoying. You could check one out for an hour from the front desk but at about $350 USD per night I expect an ironing board. The room service breakfast was about $35 usd and it was not good. The eggs were runny and I could hardly eat them (and I am not picky).The hotel dining options were expensive. A glass of wine was about $15 usd and beer was about $8 usd. Most dinners were between $45 to $105 without drinks. The breakfast buffet was about $25 usd and a value compared to everything else.The location of the hotel is good with good dining and nightlife within walking distance.The hotel gardens were a highlight. It was nice to take a stroll and relax after a long day.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani for 3 nights from aug 4 to 7th, We was in the Main building and the rooms have just been redone and they are fanastic, The Hotel is very Big, but all the staff were very helpful and all spoke good English, But the most important thing you must do if you intend to stay at this hotel, Is to go on the Hotel website and join The New Otani Club, This is free of charge and it gives you a nomber of perks, which can include. free upgrades, free Internet access, Free breakfast, Frree entry to Pool, You can not lose with this card, Tony, wendy, Emma 17 and Tom 14

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani in Tokyo is my all time favorite hotel in Japan. Many heads of state stay here. I have tried other hotels that were more expensive, but I keep returning to the New Otani. The best deal to be had is to join the New Otani Club, and reserve your room directly through the hotel's website. This should get you a free full breakfast each day. If you don't care about the breakfast, try expedia but be patient when they dont have your preferences upon your arrival. The hotel itself is very nice, despite being more than 40 years old. The recent rennovation of the Main has resulted in higher priced rooms, but the rooms in the Tower are still pretty cheap, especially if you reserve more than three weeks in advance. The garden is beautiful, the restaurants are great, and there are plenty of shops inside. If you want to save money, buy food in the gourmet market in the basement of the Tower. There are plenty of cheaper restaurants on the other side of the big intersection just east of the hotel where the akasaka mitsuke station is - noodles, sushi, chinese, whatever you desire.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The Hotel is very large and has little personality. The rooms in the tower are comfortable but nothing out of the ordinary for a hotel of this rating. It seemed to take forever to get from the rooms to many of the restaurants or other entrances. Breakfasts were great and the view from the 40th floor excellent. It is close to the subway and bars and restaurants. One amazing plus was to see Mt Fuji from my room!!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I have been a regular visitor to Tokyo for more than thirty years andtried something like fifteen hotels before I settled for the New Otani as my home from home. Normally, I prefer to avoid large hotels and this really is a big one, as others have said, more like a small town than a hotel.The clinchers for me are the New Otani's seamless service, the marvellous Japanese garden and the reasonable room rate. Every time I get off the airport bus and a bell boy runs to get the bags I know that I will be looked after as well as in some of the world's most expensive hotels. Many of the staff call me by my name when they meetme in the corridor, something that is not common in many other hotelswhere I have also been a regular.I am amazed to read some complaints on TA about the attitude of some members of staff. I do wonder if some guests appreciate that Japan remains a different culture from the West. For example, raising your voice is considered very rude indeed and causing an employee, particularly a junior one, to loose face will ensure a sudden drop inservice from anyone who observes this. As in most circumstances in Japan, a smile and an apology for being a nuisance will get you a great deal further than will a loud complaint.My main worry about the New Otani is that when the refurbishment is completed there will be a dramatic increase in prices and I won't be able to stay there any more.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I stayed in a double Tower room and we found the experience to be a very good one. Staff are helpful and polite, the rooms are a good size, amenities are good, room rates were reasonable (for Tokyo) and the location in Akasaka gives you a good base for exploring the rest of the city. Things that really impressed us: * We were able to check into our room straight away despite arriving mid-morning - a real blessing after a long overnight flight.* Ease of travel to and from the airport. The airport limousine bus to Akasaka stops at the hotel. * The hotel gardens - makes for a nice easy stroll for the jet-lagged!* Proximity of the metro station - nearest entrance was just a few minutes from the hotel.* The funky Japanese toilet!The downsides to this hotel were few, and in our opinion, easily avoided:* As other reviewers have noted, the restaurants are uber-expensive, but you'll find plenty of dining options around the hotel (there's a whole street of restaurants, karaoke bars etc right near the metro station less than 5 minutes' walk away). * Our room looked straight out onto the adjoining office building, and we could see people at their desks (not sure if they could see us); but if that bothers you, there'd be plenty of rooms that didn't look onto this.* The hotel complex is vast, which makes it pretty much impossible to avoid having to walk longer than normal distances to get anywhere in or out of the hotel. This didn't bother us, but may be a problem for the mobility impaired.Overall, we had a very good experience here and I would definitely recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Spent 3 nights in the newly removated wing (and would ask for that). Was supposed to get a standard double, but think this was a junior suite. The room was delightful and the bathroom fabulous! Lots of windows, modern furnishings, spacious, with king bed, sofa, coffee table, side chair, reading chair, desk and chair, etc. Bath had a toilet and cute tiny sink in one room and a large sink, huge shower and separate tub in another. Great toiletries! The staff were excellent--helpful with mailing packages, emails, recommendations; spoke good English. Breakfast (included) on top floor of the other tower had panoramic view of Tokyo. Mall adjoining hotel had lots of shops and a few tucked-away non-touristy restaurants. Nearby one could walk along the riverback underneath the cherry blossoms (April).
user_name:
bhutan02
Washington DC, District of Columbia

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This hotel is well known in Tokyo ("Oh, you're staying at the New Otani. Of course I know it.") and is one of the upper class hotels in the city.Request a room with a view of the city and overlooking the 400 year old Japanese garden. We stayed on one of the upper floors in the "Tower", and the view was great. We even saw Mt. Fuji on a clear day.The rooms were nice and clean, if somewhat dated. Service was excellent.The hotel complex is a city unto itself, with a mall, post office, barber shop, art galleries. There are a number of restaurants in the hotel, all of which are pricey. There are other dining options in walking distance.The hotel is in a very nice part of the city, and is convenient to a number of subway lines.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: On the last day of our one week stay, we were blessed with a clear morning view of Mt. Fuji from our hotel room (34th floor). It is rather rare to be able to see Mt. Fuji due to a number of atmospheric conditions or man made structures that obstruct the view.~~~~~~~~~~There is much more to like about this hotel than there is to dislike. I will begin with listing the cons in case that is what you use the most in making your decision of what you would choose to avoid. That’s generally where I tend to start when I am looking. *Cons*What I don’t like about this hotel*1. The inside of this hotel can be confusing as you navigate your way around the hallways. So, you might want to get a map of the inside from the concierge to help orient you for the first day or so.2. It is a long walk to the main lobby from the tower when you find that you have to do it several times a day. This is where the concierges desk is (The bell captains counter in the 'tower' lobby is not the concierges desk). 3. The restaurants are expensive and the food portions are small. 4. The location is a bit of a distance from the more visited sites. But, the sites in Tokyo are spread out from one another so you would have to use the train/subway either way. 5. There is only one bathroom sink and vanity which makes thing a bit crowed to share at the same time.6. Waiting on the elevator to go down to the lobby is a minor irritation.*The Two Lobby’s*------------------------------The tower lobby is not the main lobby. To get to the main lobby you come out of the elevators and once inside the tower lobby you go left down to the end of the corridor. The bellmen in the 'tower' lobby are limited on their tourist info and help. You will do will to go to the 'main lobby' and to the concierges desk where they have more information and maps and they speak and understand English very well. *Hotel Service* ----------------------The complete service is the wonderful aspect of this Hotel. The staff is so very helpful and polite and courteous and friendly. There was only one staff member that seemed a little bit put-out and that was the young man at the counter where we made our bus and tour reservations. Besides that, everyone treated us exceptionally well. Even the maids bow and (if you are present) apologetically clean your room. There are more than enough staff members to perceive your every need. And they are always visible and waiting. *The concierges*------------------------Every one of the concierge’s in the main lobby was very helpful and kind. Take advantage of their knowledge and printed material and don’t worrying how much to tip because you are not required to tip at all. If need be they will also give you verbal and detailed information on how to get to various locations using the subway system.The concierges will be able to arrange a Tokyo city tour (with the Gray Line Bus Service) for either a half or full day. A half a day was approximately 4,800 yen (close to. $40.00 USD). There is also a travel agent office in the building that can help you with tours. *Elevators*------------------The elevators in the lobby area of the tower (where our room was located) almost instinctively knew when we were approaching and would open. There are cameras and security throughout the hotel so perhaps the staff had a hand in the intuitiveness of the elevator. But, there seemed to perpetually be a bit of a long wait to take the elevator back down to the lobby. Our room was on the 34th floor. Our room was just a few doors away from the elevator but even still, it was quiet.*View (from our room on the 34th floor)*--------------------------------------------------------We had a wonderful view of the Japanese Garden below. And on the one day it was clear we had an honorable view of Mt. Fuji. Looking a bit to the right, way off in the distance, we could see the big video screens of Shibuya.*Breakfast*----------------The breakfast buffet in the Garden Lounge Restaurant of the Hotel has a variety of breads, rolls, croissants, muffins, cereals, salad, cheese, yogurt, and fresh sliced fruits such as apple, kiwi, peaches, melon, pineapple, and a few others. Some westerners that we talked to thought it strange that there were French fries at the breakfast buffet but really how different is that from fried potatoes or hash brown potatoes? You can additionally order off the menu and have eggs, ham, sausage, bacon and some other various foods that most Americans eat for breakfast but, keep in mind that you will have to pay additional yen. And it is not an inexpensive affair to eat at this hotel. There is an extra 10% to the bill for service. But, it is not required that you pay a tip. I thoroughly enjoyed the salad with the hotel’s sesame dressing even though it was for breakfast. I ate it every morning for the entire week that I was there. Breakfast is 7:00 am to 10:00 am. The breakfast buffet cost 1,890 yen (approximately, $15.60) without any additional items. You can order pancakes and waffles (893 yen), egg with ham, bacon or sausage ( 1,155 yen). These were the prices during the beginning of February 2007. That should give you a rough idea of the cost. Oh, and if you get there early enough you will most likely be able to be seated by the window where you can have a lovely view of the Japanese Garden.*Lunch & Dinner*------------------------We ate dinner at the Hotel 3 times and lunch twice for the sake of convenience. The food was good but as I stated before, a bit on the expensive side and the portions are a bit small. I don’t recall what it was we had for our meals.*Bedroom*-------------------We had a room with a king size bed. The room was of sufficient size but the dresser drawers were not full size height. The closet was about the size that you typically see in a hotel but, it did have a room safe where you could place your valuables. There were slippers for your feet in the closet. There were only Japanese language television stations. The bed was quite comfortable and everything was immaculately clean. Our room was reasonably quiet except for the occasional faint sound of an emergency vehicle on the road below. There is a fully stocked mini bar in the room with only a small bit of room to add any items of your own. There is an automatic hot water pot for coffee and tea as well as the cups to use. *Bathroom*-------------------The bathroom had only one sink with a vanity, and a full size tub with a removable shower head attached to a metal linking hose. The tub faucet was one where you could adjust the force of the spray without readjusting the temperature (pleasant feature). The toilet is a bidet style with one spray for the front and the one for the behind. You can also adjust the force of these hygienic sprays. (The toilets in the main lobby area are also the bidet style but they have the added feature of a heated seat.)When you are finished with your shower and your bathroom mirror is all foggy, you will see a clear spot above the sink that stays fog free for your viewing pleasure. *A Hotel Convenience*----------------------------------There are shops in the hotel and some are under the main floor. There is a convenience store under the main lobby where you can purchase beer and wine and a few goodies. To get to the store, take the main lobby elevator down 2 floors, go towards the ramp and stairs then when you come to the end you will have to make a right. Walk on a short distance and there is where you will find the convenience store. *Subway train station*--------------------------------The Akasaka Mitsuke subway station is just a couple of blocks away and the concierges in the 'main lobby' (not the tower lobby) can explain how to take the different lines. You will most likely be using the subway a lot because most of the sites are spread out around the city. *Airport to Hotel and return*----------------------------------------Transportation to and from the Narita airport can be done by using one of the express subway trains for most of the destination and a taxi to and from the train (about one hour). Or you can pay a little more (approx. $30 USD) and travel by motor couch and expect one to two hours travel depending on the traffic. We came in by way of train and taxi which I would not recommend doing if you have much luggage because there is not a lot of places for luggage on the train. We returned to the airport by way of motor couch which is somewhat fairly priced and our luggage was placed in the luggage compartment. Granted you need to allow approximately 2 hours travel time by way of motor couch due to traffic but this allowed me to be worry-free about being rude with my luggage strewn about on the train.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The room temprature was way too hot and the window couldn't be opened. The hotel staff could do nothing at all to change this unfortuante situation. They kept pretending as if they can fix it, but that never happened throughout the 3 nights we were there. We were left to sleep in terrible heat. We were also mistakenly charged double for the internet use (that is 2 X $20 per day) because something was wrong with their system. However, when it was time to pay, they would not cancel the second charge! They said it was too complicated to cancel it on the bill... We also had to wait 25 minutes before they brought a fresh towel to the room. It's not a terrible amount of time to wait but still, not that great when you pay for first class service. The hotel itself is well located but it is still somewhat under constraction and it is very easy to get lost in all the long corridors. In the same neighborhood there are at least 2 great hotels that cost less and are better all around. Next time we'll stay elsewhere.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I stayed at the New Otani for 5 nights on our belated honeymoon in March 2007. We booked a standard Tower room on expedia and were quite happy with the accommodations. The New Otani is an old money, elegant, and respected institution.The hotel is located in Akasaka-Mitsuke, close to 2 subway stops and several different subway lines. We found lots of very reasonably priced restaurants serving many different kinds of Japanese food within easy walking distance of the hotel. We particularly liked Jangara Ramen, which serves the prime minister's favorite ramen.The New Otani is massive. We found it convenient to have many services at our disposal. For example, on a couple occasions we bought groceries at the am/pm and/or the supermarket in the hotel and had a picnic in our room. We bought shinkansen train tickets to Kyoto from the travel agency. (This was after we had gone to Tokyo Station and were unable to figure out where to buy the tickets.) We used the international ATM at the post office to withdraw yen. And it was very easy for us to get to and from Narita using the airport limousine bus.Service at the New Otani, like everywhere in Japan, is really good. The staff were extremely polite and gracious. For example, after we stayed at the New Otani for 4 nights, we stored some of our luggage there while we visited Kyoto for 2 nights. We returned to the New Otani for our last night in Japan before our flight back to the States. When we returned to the New Otani, we found that the bellhop had already delivered our bags to our new room.We splurged on the breakfast buffet at the Garden Court one morning and it was quite good. It included some unusual items, like salad and french fries. The garden is gorgeous. The buffet does not include eggs, pancakes, or waffles.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed there with my wife in feb, all i can say is that we had a great time, what more can i ask for, the service, the location, the view and above all that i really liked the japanees garden which was really fantastic. I recommend this hotel to anyone especialy with children. This hotel really made my stay unforgetable.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This is a great hotel for the price. The rooms in the tower are older but good. Great bathroom. Great Shower. Great view from the 20th floor. It is close to subway. Inside the hotel their is a mall with an AM PM that is open very late. Hotel restaurant prices are expensive even though it has 8 restaurants and bar.We never ate at the hotel since there is so many restaurants in tokyo to choose from. We loved Tokyo!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We booked 8 nights with Expedia at the new Otani for our honeymoon and first trip to Japan and we were very satisfied with the service provided.The coach from the airport dropped us directly to the door, check-in staff was very polite and helpful. We even got an upgrade to a deluxe room when we mentioned the purpose of our trip and they sent a fruit basket to our room later.The room on the 25th floor of the Tower was very large with a great bathroom and these fantastic toilets you only find in Japan.The view was absolutely breathtaking, by night or day (see pics!).It was clean throughout our stay and the staff consistently refused tipping.Location is great with underground transportation only 3 minutes walk away. Also, there are loads of restaurants / bars in the hotel but they are very expensive compared to what you can get in the neighbourhood. Ask the reception desk for recommendations and bookings.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed 6 nights at the Otani as part of a business trip. The hotel has many lounges, bars, shops and restaurants which make it look like a shopping mall. There are also many weddings which contribute to keep these areas somehow crowded. The rooms in the Tower are reasonably spacious (including a sofa) but their views are nothing special. My stay was split in two because I had business somewhere else in Japan and on returning to the hotel they had misplaced ny reservation resulting in me being given a room in the main building - which was borderline. Internet access in the rooms but wireless in the lounge only, and an excellent Japanese breakfast. Getting access to the restaurants can be a bit of a challenge at rush hour as well.All in all, the hotel is value for money but do not go there if you need outstanding comfort.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: After staying at two smaller hotels in Japan, the New Otani was a bit of a shock to the system. The Hotel is very large, including a shopping mall, restaurants, and wedding facilities. We had a room on the 38th floor of the Tower which gave us lovely views of the gardens and the city beyond. The room was very nicely appointed, with a large and luxurious bathroom. Only oddity was the carpet -- it was a very bright, abstract pattern.The service was very nice. I was surprised that we had to pay extra for so many services -- including the pool and internet access. The brunch buffet was a little expensive, but it was peaceful to eat it next to a garden and waterfall.I did not love the location of the hotel. While it was only a few block walk to the nearest subway, there was not much of a neighborhood around the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Just stayed 6 nights in Tokyo at the Hotel New Otani. Athough many of the previous have been quite negative, I was happy with the standard of our room and the service we received at the hotel. Here are my thoughts and recommendations. We were recomended to stay here as it is regarded as one of the traditional big Tokyo hotels and an established venue to receive clients and discuss business. After reading the reviews on here , we avoided booking a Tower room and instead found a good deal for a new refurbished Standard room in the Main Building by booking directly via the New Otani website. We made several enquires with agents and online and found that most places were selling the Tower rooms at the same rates as booking directly and in some cases even more. We paid around 30,000 Yen which worked out to be around £130 per night and took advantage of a special offer for New Otani Members which included breakfast (We joined as members online just before making the booking).The room itself was refurbished to a high standard, neutral walls with dark real hardwood fixtures and fittings and a big HD LCD tv. The room layout and size was pretty standard around 280sq ft in total. We were up on the 13th floor, garden side and had a fantastic view of a wooded park, skyscrapers and on clear days Mount Fuji in the background. This was because of the newly installed top to bottom 1 piece panoramic windows, all our visitors commented on the great view. I especially liked the hidden ventilation hatch that you could open to allow fresh air in to the room. Another thing which I noticed was that the room was completely soundproofed, I didn't hear our neigbours at all (unlike the place I am currently staying in in HK!).The hotel was huge! 2 hotel buildings joined together by a shopping complex which itself appeared to be on several levels with numerous restaurants. It was quite confusing at first to navigate. The clientele were predominantly Japanese - retired groups, business men or even politcians apparently. I got the impression The New Otani was a very traditional, venerable, old money type of place. Throughout our stay there were daily conferences, school reunions, association meetings so the atmosphere tended to be very sedate and genteel. The service itself was very polite, quite effcient but some of the older front desk members could be quite stuffy. The spoken English amongst the staff was not brilliant but all our enquires and requests were dealt with efficiently. Internet was not included in our pacakge and was extra at around 2100 Yen (£10) per 24hrs but I felt this should have this really should have been included with our room. Breakfast selection was large, varied and good quality, serving Japanese, American and Continetal breakfast. If you can, take time out to walk around the large Japanese Garden with waterfall and huge Koi carps. I would not recommend eating at the hotel restuarants unless you can claim it as an company expense or budget is not an issue. We arrived late and jetlagged and decided to try out the ShabuShabu restaurant "Okahan". Nice food, cooked and served by a sweet old Japanese lady in a Kimono, but the bill came to around £140 with no drinks, it was good but not that good! Instead, ask Concierge for a map of restraurants in nearby Akasaka Mitsuke by cuisine (they won't produce this unless you ask.). On the main Akasaka Misuke "strip" I would recommend "Za Watami" (can't miss the b+w sign, on 2nd floor), the ground floor Tempura restaurant (plastic tempura models oustide) and along the adjacent main road (near Citibank, which has a international cash machine) a steak restaurant called "Kuni's Place" where you purchase Japanese marbled beef by per 100gms. All these meals were cheap ranging from £15 - £45 for 2. If you are a cake fan you have to try "Cozy Corner" for the Japanese take on European style cakes.The hotel was well located in a quiet area. Nearest and most convinient Metro station was on the Tower side - Akasaka Mitsuke - turn right just after you cross the bridge over the river/moat and go down exit D. This station sits on the Ginza and Maranouchi lines and get you to the major districts directly. Taxis were not too expensive and taxi drivers seemed honest. However don't take a taxi from Narita airport. It was our first time in Tokyo and we opted for the Aiport Limousine bus which cost 3000 yen each way and completely stress free. The journey did take over an hour but the buses are very comfortabe and clean. We didn't get to do much sightseeing but would recommend Isetan Department store in Shinjuku for onestop tax free shopping, Harajuku to see the latest Japanese youth fashions, Otemesando Hills for great shopping, also admire the well designed shopping centre and the unique Prada store. Visit the Park Hyatt Shinjiku to ride the superfast elavators and go to the view gallery up the top. Tokyo looked amazing at night with the skyscrapers and twinkling red lights, its a scene straight out of the film Akira. We loved Tokyo and the New Otani made our stay feel welcoming and relaxed. I would deifnitely stay here again and probably opt for the deluxe room for a bit more space. Already missing the Otani as we are currently in HK staying at a much inferior hotel!! (Cheaper though!!)

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I stayed at the New Otani for four nights in early November. The hotel is old and does not have anything stylish or contemporary and looks rather dull, but their service was impeccable. The hotel staff were incredibly polite, pleasant, and efficient.My room was on the 22nd floor in the Tower and had a nice view. It was spotlessly clean. It had a king-size bed, a large work/dinning table with a chair, a large sofa, a flat panel TV on the cabinet, an electrical kettle, a fridge, and a safe in the closet. Though I had to rearrange the drinks in the fridge to store my own food, they did not charge me any for that. The room was spacious and I thought was larger than the king-bedded rooms at the Hiltons, Sheratons, and Marriotts in major US cities I have stayed at. They provided tooth brushes and tooth pastes, disposable razors, disposable slippers, disposable hairbrushes, and yukatas (Japanese style pajamas), in addition to the regular toiletry and room amenities. If you need an iron and an iron board, you have to call house-keeping and return the set within one hour. Internet access from a hotel room was expensive (2100 yen/24 hours) and no free Wifi was detected. Room service was expensive, but the portion of the dishes I ordered was pretty generous based on the Japanese standard. Meals at the hotel restaurants were also expensive, but given the great views from the restaurants and their impeccable services I would consider the prices reasonable. If you like French pastries, try Satsuki in the Main building. If you look for cheap eats, try the Akasaka Mitsuke area, to which you just walk 5 minutes from the hotel (exit from the Tower, not from the Main). You can get a map of restaurants in the area from the concierge or you just walk around to see what’s available.The hotel is located in a nice and quiet neighborhood with good access to public transportation. If you would like to experience the traditional Japanese courtesy, this hotel could be a good option for you. Mind you that the hotel has some designated areas for smoking. If you are sensitive to smoking, you would likely get annoyed by the smell. I’d recommend that you obtain the New Otani club membership with which you can receive some privileges and services including free continental breakfast at the club room.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I've written previously about the New Otani (see review link in my profile), so I'll focus this update on what is new. As several reviews have noted, there is a remodel underway for the Main building at the New Otani. I had a newly remodeled room and wanted to report on it.The Main building has been undergoing remodeling for approximately 1 year. They are renovating each of the three wings in succession. The first remodeled wing just opened in October. So currently the Main building is 1/3 remodeled, 1/3 old, and 1/3 closed.I booked a "superior" remodeled room in the Main, but at check-in, it was not available. They upgraded me at no cost to an Executive style Deluxe room! How wonderful! The executive deluxe rooms are both larger than superior rooms, and have nicer fixtures. This was a very nice touch of service.Apart from that, however, I'd like to comment on the features that are common to all of the newly remodeled rooms. First, the rooms have been essentially gutted and rebuilt. This starts with the beautiful new windows (triple pane, floor to ceiling), through the bathrooms (beautiful and efficient) to redesign of the infrastructure (digital TV, well-planned PC/internet workspace). The color scheme has changed from the pastel look of the old rooms to a striking black and chrome style.How about the construction -- does it pose problems? Absolutely none that I observed. There was no construction noise during the day, no mess, no dust, nothing. The closed wing appears to be completely sealed both inside and out. Inside the building, it's been walled off so successfully you wouldn't even know it was there. On the outside it is completely encased and there is no sign of the construction. So don't let it bother or scare you away!The only downside of the remodel, I think, is that the prices have gone up for the new rooms, as compared to the old. The new pricing puts the New Otani into the same price range as Grand Hyatt and other top notch Tokyo hotels. However, with the beautiful new, large rooms, along with its many other positive qualities (location, services, etc), it deserves to be in that class. Note that most of the offers at travel sites are either for the Tower rooms (fine but moderate in age and with less personality than the Main) or for the old Main rooms. If your travel site doesn't show them, you might want to check directly with the hotel's website for offers on the newly remodeled rooms.The New Otani is a very large property, definitely not at all a boutique hotel. But it is a wonderful, convenient, friendly, and now up-to-date (at least in the new Main) hotel. Highly recommended if you want a central Tokyo location with full services.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Staff a the hotel are extremely considerate and careful, even by Japanese stadards. It's therefore rather diificult to understand how the hotel management has let the 20th century pass by without updating the property. Room decor and furnishings are from the 1940s, and were probably not even second-class quality when they were new. The Japanese restaurants are top quality but not very welcoming to Westerners arriving on their own (I happen to be a woman travelling alone on business, and generally get reactions of horrified panic when I try to enter---even though my Japanese is pretty darn good). I find the Western food, in contrast to other reviewers here, absolutely revolting. It's that 1960s Japanese interpretation of Western food which features weird combinations (hot dogs on sugar bread; everything covered with mayonnaise, spaghetti with tomoato sauce topped with seaweed shavings, etc etc). The gym has literally not been renovated since 1962----I asked. Yes, the garden is lovely....why not stop and check it out on your way to a nicer hotel?

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We arrived at Narita and took the limo-bus to the New Otani ($30). Travel to the hotel took about 90 minutes. Upon arrival we were greeted and quickly and effiiciently escorted to check-in. The process was quick and easy. We had a very large king bed room on the 39th floor. It was immaculately clean with a fully stocked bar and one of the most tasteful appointed and decorated bathrooms we have seen. The tile walls and floors complemented the spacious shower and large garden tub. The toilet was modern and included the various washing amenities--all automated.The staff of the hotel went out of their way to be helpful, were always friendly and always available.The hotel has 30+ bars and restaurants. In our opinion the Satsuki coffee room is the best place to have a quiet relaxing meal. The food selection is varied and all choices taste very good. Prices in this restaurant are comparable with NY, DC, LA, etc. The Prime Rib, is very expensive, the food quality is good and the service is first rate. The restaurants on the 40th floor were no match compared to the two previously mentioned.The hotel has a four hundred year old oriental garden with waterfall and pond. It is meticulously maintained and is the perfect place for a quiet walk after a stress full day. It is incredibly peaceful and quiet, There are two small restaurants in the gardens and the food at both is very good. The night time views of the illuminated gardens are spectacular.The hotel is located two blocks from the subway making it very easy to reach any area of Tokyo. Adjacent to the subway station are several blocks and streets and blocks of restaurants and shops. The local restaurants serve delicious food at very reasonable prices.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Having lived at the New Otani for a month I find it extremely positive that I have not one single negative remark about the hotel.Centrally located (right next to subway stations), beautiful gardens (it is a treat to have breakfast everyday with that view) and three options of restaurants for breakfast (essential for one who stays a long time in the same hotel).Service is excellent and that will be my first option in any future visit to Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: great hotel, good location, fantastic garden and in the restaurant in the garden fantastic (but expensive) deeppanyaki with kobe beef and other things.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: It's true that this hotel is under renovation. And will be so through October 2007. The part being renovated now is the main building so I would opt for a room in the 'tower' if possible. The rooms (at least in the main building) are right out of the 60's so expect that.The staff service was exceptional, as you would expect at a Japanese hotel of this caliber. They were more than helpful to us. This was demonstrated when we lost an umbrella and the bellhop lady came running through the hotel after us to bring it to us. She was out of breath when she got to us! Also, when we thought that I had lost our passports the staff turned the hotel upside down and even the Housekeeping Manager got directly involved! What more could you ask for?What a location! If you walk through the building through the tower, the hotel complex is a short walk away down a hill to the Akasaka-Mitsuke subway station. Here you will have a direct-line connection to Tokyo Station, Ginza, and Shinjuku via the Marunouchi or Ginza subway lines. There is a pleasant park and little lake close by where people fish. Akasaka has many great restaurants in itself.The complex property is enormous. There is a beautiful Japanese garden on site and several very nice Japanese restaurants in the middle of the garden that will make you feel like you are walking back into the Edo period.We'll be back!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I spent 3 nights at the New Otani in the Tower section of the hotel. The hotel itself is huge with multpile lobbies and restaurants. No problem with check-in and all staff spoke at least some English. Takes a while to get your bearings in the hotel since the complex is so large.Had one room overlooking a street and the other overlooking the garden area. Large, clean rooms and large bahrooms with full bathtub and shower. Pretty central location with easy access to the subway for getting around Tokyo. Lots of closet and drawer space with tea and yukata robes provided. The hotel itself is incredibly expensive and connot reccommend eating in any of its restaurants. There are much better places to eat for reasonable prices elsewhere. Did take part in a private traditional tea ceremony for approx $10 CDN per person which was excellent. Our rate included a complimentary breakfast at our choice of restaurants (one of which serves Japanese breakfast). Several restaurants on the 40th floor for a great view of the city. The main building is due to close at the end of June for repair and will not re-open until October 2007- not sure if the construction noise would interfere with your stay.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Everything about the Hotel New Otani was wonderful for us. The staff were extremely kind and helpful; the service was fantastic. The in-house restaurants offered a wonderful selection with great food in fantastic settings. The Japanese and Western Breakfast Buffet was especially good.Our room was on the next to top floor in the tower with wonderful views of the skyline, Akasaka Palace and the hotel garden and pool (closed for the season). It was, impeccable with a great king-size bed; high tech toilet, great bath and lovely tile work.In spite of its size it was a very friendly hotel. The only reproach I have is the long hallway from the main front desk to the tower, but this is to be expected when you consider the size of the hotel.I would love to stay there again!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The New Otani has a reputation for being an upscale hotel. So, I was very pleased to find a "low rate" - $160/night. The part that wasn't disclosed was that the hotel was in the middle of a renovation...the first since the hotel opened in 1964(or thereabouts) - according to their website (this was not posted at the time of my reservation!)I entered the hotel from the "tower" side (approach from the Asakusa-Mitsuke metro). When you enter from this side, you actually enter the hotel through an office building. There is NO hotel staff until you enter the building and get to the 6th floor. Normally this wouldn't be a problem, except that I had lots of luggage and had traveled by train and metro for over 3 hours from Kyoto...I was tired and wanted a bell boy to help!When I finally got to the lobby, the bell boys were there, but were of no help. I then had to go through 20 mins of negotiation to find a room since mine "wasn't ready" (it was 1:30pm). I offered to leave my luggage and go shopping but they didn't want to store my two bags (reasonable size...25" and a 20"). No reason was provided for not wanting to store the luggage. Finally, a smoking room was located (I had asked for non smoking). When I begged (between genuine coughs and sniffles), I was provided an air purifier unit (this was the #1 positive...I'll admit that they did provide a good air purifier and I did get over my cigarette smoke related sinus infection).The lobby and common areas looked "standard" for this class of hotel. So, I was shocked to enter the room to find a throwback to the late 70's early 80's! The only way I was able to turn the clock closer to the 80's is the TV style. Initially, I thought that the TV was as old as the hotel...but then I remembered that TV's in the 60's had the channel changing knobs. This tv didn't have the knobs. The notable accoutrement to the TV? A thick layer of soot all over the plastic case! Must have been from the prior smokers (I can't imagine one chain smoker causing that much soot!Another era clue...the bedstand. The last time I saw a bedstand with buttons and a dial clock like that one was back in the early 70's. There were buttons to control the tv channels too...but the room had been upgraded with closed circuit and a "newer" remote (maybe from the 90's?)The beds were as hard as a rock...reminds me of my old bed, circa 1965. The clues...no quilting, no padding...just rock hard! The linens...probably not circa 1965...but they weren't modern duvet with cool, puffy innerds. There was a high speed internet connection for an additional 2100 yen per day, measured from noon to noon. I wasn't able to use it though because there is NO available electrical plug at the desk (another era clue...the original desk configurations were never made for laptops...) I did search and found a neat octopus behind the desk for the closed circuit tv unit, the tv and the network box, as well as the mini fridge. No outlet was left for my laptop. I suppose I could have used my battery then recharged at the outlet across the room, but for 2100 yen/day, I didn't want to go through that much trouble. There are internet cafes and wireless spots everywhere, for much less.The bathroom was fine, except for the lovely burns above the sconce light fixtures (probably the result of the use of high wattage bulbs in the fixtures). This was checked for safety...but no one felt that this was an aesthetic problem. There were also "smoke trails" on the walls coming from the air exchange from the central A/C. Since I'm not a smoker, I don't know if this is "standard" for smoking rooms...but I didn't find it pleasant.The room was always dark, even with the lights on, due to the placement of the fixtures. The chairs had obvious wear on the seats and you just "sank" into the seat...like the support was giving way.The bellboy service was not pleasant. The head bell boy always passed me off to the other bell boys. The other bell boys seemed to know what I wanted, but had no answer. So I was left with the head bell boy who knew the answer, but didn't want to tell me. There was a concierge desk that was never manned and the bell boys didn't fill in! By the way...if you ask, the bell boys have a nice map indicating the local restaurants and what food they served. I went to the two shops labeled "jap sweets" and both places had EXCELLENT gift boxes. In the hotel's defense...I later learned that the service at "The Main" was excellent.
