The concierge was always too busy, so the manager always filled in and spoke to me in perfect English and always provided good directions - superfriendly, exactly what you expect from a Japanese hotel of that stature. Another staff member walked me to the ATM since it was hard to find (though she gave improper advice about which one to use...if you have a foreign bank card, you must use the ATM in the Post Office room, NOT the MUFJ ATM). Lesson Learned - if you want to stay at the New Otani before the end of The Main's renovation in 2007, ask whether you're in a renovated room or a non-renovated room. Also, ask NOT to stay at the Tower! All proper service is found at The Main (except bell boys...they were NEVER seen at The Main...). I think that they are selling the yucky rooms to unsuspecting tourists at cheap prices thinking that we deserve less. What they're really doing is ruining their reputation! I would have moved across the street, except that I had prepaid for the entire stay.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My eleven year old son and I spent three nights here (tower building, garden view), and loved it. The hotel was fine in every way. The Japanese gardens next to the hotel (which predate the hotel by a century or so) are truly amazing in the spring. Worth a visit even if you aren't staying at the hotel, and certainly a strong reason to pick this hotel. My only complaint is that internet access is expensive, and is charged Y2,000 noon to noon, so can be really expensive the first and last day. An alternative: They have a coin-operated computer in the business center. The hotel restaurants are very expensive, as you'd expect. The trick to finding restaurants outside is to leave from the tower entrance, not the main entrance.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I was in Tokyo for about 4 days, in January. The New Otani proved to be an excellent location. The area is relatively quiet, but very close to many restaurants. The hotel staff were extremely helpful and courteous (not what I always find in Tokyo). The facilities were ideal for casual meetings. The Japanese Garden is outstanding. On my last day, stay began to fall, and created a postcard view. When I return to Tokyo, I will definitely return to the New Otani.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani last August (05) for 5 nights on our way back from New Zealand. We had a double room in the "old" bit of the hotel (not tower) and it was great. The hotel is absolutely massive, a la Las Vegas hotel size (15 minute walk to your room), but really nice, clean and in a very safe area. It was also a great base for exploring Tokyo. Don't be put off by some of the pictures, it really is a first class hotel. We were provided with fresh Kimono each day and there are tea (plum!) and coffee making facilities in a tiny kitchenette foldaway cupboard thing, as well as a huge wardrobe area, adjacent to the bathroom. We had a nice seating area too, with a sofa and coffee table and there was a desk and chair. The room facilities were, overall, very good and the toiletries of a really good quality.The views of the city, particularly at night, were fabulous and we loved the Japanese tv shows - hilarious. The hotel staff are friendly and speak excellent English, the shops full of expensive clothing and amusing knick knacks and the hotel was, overall, extremely good value for money. One word of caution - don't go to Japan in August. It was absolutely sweltering and very, very humid. However, if you have a journey booked, consider staying at the New Otani.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I just got back from a 5 night stay at the New Otani Hotel in Tokyo. We enjoyed our stay here and would recommend it to anyone. We got a great deal online at Expedia for the flight and hotel together so we thought the rate was reasonable for a "Luxury" hotel in Tokyo (this was our first time in Tokyo). When we arrived check-in was easy, they unfortunately did not have any king beds left, we checked in a bit later in the day, but that was fine and we took 2 twin beds. We had opted for the deluxe size room which is a bit larger than a standard. We are glad that we did. The room size that we had was good for what we needed but the standard size might have been a tad too small. I know Japanese rooms tend to be smaller than American hotels anyway, so that's why we went with the deluxe. The room was very clean, and that is most important for me. Also, I know some people have had problems with the Main building (this is where we stayed), but we thought the room was perfectly fine - very clean and nothing seemed old or shabby.As usual restaurants in the hotel were very expensive, but this is to be expected. We had only breakfast twice at Satsuki, was pricey but good, and otherwise went outside the hotel for meals.The concierge was very helpful and booked 2 tours for us during our stay. They also provided us with a great map of the area to fing restaurants and other general stores (drug store, grocery, etc).Staff at the hotel was very friendly and we did not find them stuffy at all. The hotel is in a great area and very close to the subway.We liked the New Otani Hotel and would stay there again anytime.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Stayed here on night and had a good deal of email to catch up on - why don't expen$ive Japanese hotels offer hi-speed Internet access for free like counterpart hotels in America? The fee only was good for 12 hrs and there is no room-to-print email service. To get a print out, one needs to go to the business center where they charge the user AGAIN to get on the Internet and then they want 20 yen per printout page (!). I could not print any of my work email since I route through a VPN and can't get on at a public station. On top of it all, the business center is not 24/7 so consider that if you need access to a computer and/or printout.The room was fine on size (for Japanese-based hotels) and the amenities good.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed in this hotel right after our skiing holiday and we stayed at the Akasaka Prince (just across the road) on the same trip but before we went skiing, so you could say we are well placed to compare the two hotels. We knowingly paid a high price for a triple room at this hotel because we knew we would want a comfortable room after skiing. This was exactly what we got, a large 40sqm room (unusually large for Tokyo), well fitted out, with nice furnishings and a picture view of the Japanese garden below, the Shinjuku park in front and the office towers beyond. From the lobby right up to the room, this hotel is definitely one star up on the Akasaka Prince, particularly the beds--which are firmer and have much nicer comforters.My tip is to insist on a room in the "Tower" because when we called ahead to ask what is the difference, they told us all the rooms in the Main building were about to be renovated whereas the Tower rooms are still quite new. And if you could swing it, request a room facing the Shinjuku area, which has the best view in this hotel. If you have to pay extra for breakfast, then I urge you to do so. They give you a choice of 3 restaurants but by far the most stunning is the "Top of the Tower" on the 40th floor where on a sunny day (which is quite often between Nov to Feb), you would not want to leave.While the New Otani maybe more luxurious and comfortable, when it comes to service the Akasaka Prince wins hands down--from its concierge, business centre and reservations, all were too willing to please and efficient. In contrast, we felt the staff at the New Otani were a bit "aloof". My final tip is this, all double/twin rooms at the Akasaka Prince is 37sqm whereas in the New Otani Tower, they are 27sqm.Since I think both hotels are similarly priced and location wise they are right opposite each other (both are in one of the best neighbourhoods in Tokyo), if it's comfort and luxury you want, then choose the New Otani. If it's service and room size which concerns you then go for the Akasaka Prince (say if you have a child for intance, the 3 or you would be more comfortable at the Akasaka Prince since their double beds are 200cm or 79 inches wide). At the New Otani, you would need a triple room which would cost quite a bit more. We had emailed the Akasaka Prince concierge a bunch of questions on where to go, what to see and where to eat before arrival and when we checked in, they had printed out maps and clear directions in English for each of the places we enquired about ready for us, that's service !!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Hotel is well located with a subway station and an abundance of restaraunts close by.The rooms and furniture show signs of aging and an extensive renovation program is underway in one section of the hotel at least. The service was efficient and friendly. The food was edible but not special. I was particularly disappointed at the gym facilities which were quite expensive to use ( Y5000 per session). I prefer the Grand Hyatt.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We chose to stay at this hotel after reading some of the reviews in Trip Advisor. Generally we found it to be a good experience but the hotel certainly is in need of a major update.Upon arriving, we were placed in a room in the main building. The room was pleasant but the furnishings are tired and sadly out of date. The TV was very old and the air conditioning did not function well. The ensuite bathroom was very small and again is very much out of date.Generally the public areas of the hotel are in good shape and of course there are many shops and restuarants in the complex. But watch out for the high prices in the restaurants and shops. They are way above what you find even in highly priced Tokyo!Before arriving, we applied for a Membership card for the New Otani group of hotels. This is a free offer and is supposed to provide members with a number of benefits including free breakfast. When we checked in, we were never told about breakfast. It was only when we asked that we were told that breakfast was not included in our rate. We were not satisfied with this answer and again reminded the front desk that we were club members. One staff member then told us that as members we could get a special basic breakfast (reduced continental) in a special room in the tower part of the hotel. They would only give members the regular breakfast if you paid a much higher rate than we had paid. We found this to be a misrepresentation of their part. ( The hotel website clearly shows a more extensive breakfast). Despite discussions with their senior manager, they would not budge and we were forced to accept their basic breakfast which consisted of bagels, pastries, coffee, tea and juice.Although comfortable, the datd decorating and the breakfast misrepresentaion, detracted from our stay at this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The hotel is well located, near a convenient subway stop and has a lovely japanese garden. Although my reservation was for a tower room, I was put in the main building (suffering from jet lag I did not realize this at first and then did not want to bother to change). The main building is about to be renovated and it needs it. The room was slightly shabby, the curtains were drooping and the upholstery stained. Although I had a very good price for the room, you still don't expect that from a hotel of this caliber. The room had both terrycloth robes and japanese cotton robes, slippers, hot water and tea, refrigerator, safe and all the amenities. I could not get the internet connection in my room to work. The dining rooms are expensive and mostly have set meals, but there are other places close by. The tempura restaurant in the hotel was excellent and was very accomodating to my vegetarian daughter, which is a challenge in Japan as they want to use fish broth or bonito in everything. In an adjoining building there is a great am/pm convenience store and a Tully's Coffee (similar to Starbucks)which was our favorite breakfast place.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Although the New Otani is well-located (just a 500 metre walk from the metro at Akasaka Mitsuke) and the rooms of a decent size, I have to say I expected more.With the 'standard tower room' at a reduced rate of £80 per night (around ¥16,500) I suppose I shouldn't have expected star treatment, but the fact that the room wasn't provided with one single free item - no tea, coffee, even a bottle of water - was a little on the cheap side I thought. Even the most basic business hotels in Japan provide you with green tea bags and certainly would never expect you to pay ¥450 for what initially looked like a complimentary bag of M&Ms?!! They also nearly all provide free LAN internet access, which is pretty much an essential when you work and travel, but the Otani's flat rate of ¥2100 (£11) for use of their in-room LAN connection left me slackjawed to say the least.As many other reviews have said, the restaurants within the hotel are very pricey, which isn't a problem with the whole of Tokyo as your backyard of course. However, if you ever happen to be spending Christmas Day in this hotel, be sure to make reservations somewhere else months in advance, or bring a packed lunch. I made the mistake of thinking that, with 11 restaurants, we'd be able to find something decent at a not-too-extortionate price, but it turns out that ¥9700 (£50pp) for an all-you-can-eat Chinese 'Banquet' in the rather dog-eared, somewhat faded Blue Sky Restaurant was the very cheapest option on offer. Ironically, our last trip was spent at The Park Hyatt in Shinjuku, where a fabulous meal for both my partner and myself in the New York Bar & Grill cost us around the same. I didn't begrudge the cost a bit!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at this hotel during a trip to Tokyo in December 2005 and were very pleased. The hotel itself is huge and is spread over multiple buildings surrounding a wonderful japanese garden that has been preserved by the hotel.Check-in was easy and quick, and we had our room upgraded at no charge since the room we had initially booked was unavailable. The room was a good size, clean, with a good size bathroom and shower/tub. Bedside controls as usual in Asia, as well as bathrobes and slippers for guest use.There are several restaurants in the hotel, most of which are quite expensive, but we weren't planning to eat there anyway.The hotel is close to the subway, a quick 5 minute walk, and also has a good selection of restaurants and shops in the area to buy supplies, drinks, etc.All in all this was an excellent value in a great location and I would certainly stay there again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: i knew i was going to a a very good hotel after reading other guests comments,but i've just returned having spent a week in tokyo watching liverpooland i must say this hotel lived up to all expectations+more..the service was superb,the hotel gardensfantastic+plenty of nitelife;in the surrounding areas(akasaka+roppongi hills}we booked trips with sunrise tours within the hotel,1day trip to mt fuji superb +lunch cruise on the symphony another great trip..caught bullet train 3 times no problens as everybody is so helpful..just to make our stay even more enjoyable we woke at 6 every morning to have the perfect view of the tokyo skyline and mount fuji!!!!!!what a brill week!!!!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The Otani in summary is a very good hotel, good location and good restaurant. However we did have a number of gripes.From a vacation point of view - I would say it is more of a business hotel. The hotel is located in the embassy quarters which is reflected in the guests. The hotel lacked character - one guide book described it as being a cruise ship - and I couldn't agree more.The gym was a tad disappointing - you do have free use of a fitness facility but it is very limited - it contains only one treadmill, 2 bikes and 2 stair climbers. To use the other private fitness facility,i.e. indoor pool and hi-tech gym would have cost in the region of 25 pounds for each visit.The location though good is opposite an area full of hostess / strip bars and lacked good restaurants (although in the opposite direction it does contain a splendid Indian restuarant).In summary a very good hotel but is not one I would recommend for a business trip.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani, Tokyo in November 2005 and it we had a wonderful, unforgettable time. The hotel is HUGE (lost our way several times) but the size of the hotel didn’t prevent us being treating as very special guests. The staff are gracious, super efficient and simply go out of their way to meet your every need. This was our first visit to Japan and we were overwhelmed by the politeness we were shown by everyone we met and the cleanliness of everywhere we went.We booked through Expedia and got a good deal (flew with Virgin – they’re great too). Our room was large (we stayed in the Main building). We had a walk in wardrobe, big telly, desk, sofa, kettle constantly hot, newspaper ever morning, fresh flowers in the bathroom, turn down service with mints in the evening, freshly laundered cotton robe and a towelling robe every day… I could go on…Here’s a good tip: We booked only 8 days before we were due to travel. After reading other Trip Advisor reviews regarding the New Otani Discount card, we applied online for one each through their website. Naturally, there was no way that these cards would arrive at our home address within a week. I emailed the hotel directly asking if we could simply use a printout of their email confirmation instead. They sent me a prompt and courteous reply informing us that “Your cards will be waiting for you at reception on arrival”. And indeed they were! Now that’s service. The card is worth getting – there are many benefits, but the two we found most useful were the waiver on some service charges in the hotel restaurants/bars and the free breakfast (beverages, juice and pastries (In the Tower - great morning view of Tokyo). The hotel has many, many posh shops and they are dear, but window shopping is fun! The restaurants and bars are expensive, too. As this trip was my birthday treat, we did eat and drink at the hotel on occasions, and we nearly feinted at the bill, but the experience was worth it.The service we received was faultless. Tipping is not expected; indeed the concept is not really understood. But you will really want to provide a tip – not feel obliged to give one because you feel you have to, as with some other parts of the world…I can’t comment on the gym and pool as we never used them. I have nothing negative to say to say about the hotel. If forced, I would say that it was a bit ‘dated’ but I heard it was due for a facelift. But, regardless, the New Otani is Fantastic.Recommend this Hotel? DEFINITELY

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: A great hotel in lovely grounds. The rooms are as you would expect and some have good views of Tokyo. The shops are the usual designer stuff but it does have a post office, bakery, news agency, drugstore, and a travel agency in the hotel.A good location in Tokyo, the Metro is really close (use the covered underground walkway most of the way that means you don't have to cross any roads to get there) and provides good access to both East and West of the city and Akasaka has a good mix of restaurants, bars, and coffee shops.I would stay there again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Well placed on the Ginza line that'll take you from the shrines and markets at Asakusa to the nightlife of Shibuya. The limosine bus from the airport picks up and drops here so it makes getting there as easy as using a package deal.Hotel bars and restaurants were pricey - but a 5 min walk takes you to the centre of Akasuka with loads of choice - cheaper than the uk for good quality food. There is a fridge in the room for keeping anything ou bought from the supermarket. The garden is lovely and great to have a retreat to hand in such a busy city. I read on here about joining the Hotel club - it's free, but takes about a month for the card to arrive - if you do this you'll get entrance to small breakfast lounge with a view of Roppongi and Fuji - well worth it.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Now this is luxury! One of the nicest rooms we've ever seen. The rooms are hugh, clean, modern and comfortable - lots of nice toiletries. This was a really comfortable place to stay. The location is more for business travellers rather than tourists but the location is nice, safe and not too far from the tourist spots (about 2 to 3 metro stops away). The hotel did seem a bit impersonal to us - for example the help desk seemed keen to sell their guided tours to us but did not help us much to plan our own trips. Don't get me wrong - the staff are not rude at all - just less helpful than the previous Kyoto hotel we stayed in. The restaurants and shops in the hotel are really expensive - and I mean really expensive. However, there are loads of shops and eating places near the hotel. Overall a really nice hotel but very pricey (as Tokyo generally is).

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Now this was a really luxurious place! Bring your Corporate Amex, though – the place is as expensive as it is beautiful. In fact, avoid the restaurants in the hotel area altogether.My room was gorgeous, with all the latest amenities. Especially the electric kettle with constant hot water was much appreciated. The bathroom had a nice large tub and was squeaky clean. Hairdryer, coffee maker, slippers, bathrobes, etc.High-speed internet access is free only through the corporate package.I was in the Tower, so I had a great panoramic view. On the flip side, the place is so big that it takes 15 minutes to get out of the building.For breakfast, there are actually several restaurants to choose from, with Japanese and Western buffet choices, including items cooked to order. I watched them fix omelets with chopsticks – apparently I’m easily impressed.Location is ok, close to two metro stations but not in any of the actual tourist zones. This is probably an advantage, though.Service was great. They even rose to the challenge of getting me a converter for a Swiss 3-prong plug.Unfortunately, AC broke during my stay, but when I told them that I would prefer to stay in this room, they fixed it immediately.The only disappointment was the spa. Pool access is very expensive, even for hotel guests, and we didn’t find it worth it just for a quick swim. All in all, this was a great place to stay, and I would love to come back if I can afford it.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My husband and I stayed at the New Otani from October 15th - October 19th of this year. We were well pleased with our room, a large (by Japanese standards) king-sized bed, seating area, dressing area with walk-in closet. The staff at the hotel were amazing, always there when needed. The food at the hotel was good, except overpriced. Several nights were spent in the bar at Trader Vics where most drinks cost at least 1900 yen. But they were good! One night we ate there (we've eaten at one in Atlanta) and it was good, but portions very small. We did eat the breakfast buffet in the main hotel twice, also good and a big variety. Our room was in the main building which is older than the tower, but still very nice. Very convenient to the subway station which made it easy to get around. The hotel sent our luggage to the airport as we were traveling to another destination with just a couple of smaller bags. This was very inexpensive. To store 2 large bags for 3 days only $54. My husband was having a conference there, and the conference rooms were large and roomy. A couple of conference meals were good too. Overall I totally recommend the Hotel New Otani.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My wife and I just returned from a 10 day trip to Japan which included a 4 night stay at the New Otani. We loved this hotel. The service was more than just efficient. They made us feel like old friends and went out of their way to help us have a good time. Had a room in the Tower which, although a little smaller than those in the main part of the hotel, had outstanding views of the Tokyo skyline and the 400 year old garden on the property. Other advantage is it's closer to Akasaka and the subway station. Joining the New Otani Club (register online and it's free) gave us access to a complimentary continental breakfast each morning. Japan as a whole had a level of hospitality and graciousness I have never seen in either North America or Europe. The New Otani was definitely part of this tradition. Can't wait to go back to Japan and will most certainly stay at this hotel again.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: The service was impeccabble and the room was always clean.We stayed there for a total of 6 nights, 2 different times and 2 different rooms. For convenience of getting to the subway, stay in the tower. The views were really amazing and the garden was lovely.Another great thing was the you could walk about 2 blocks and find 3 avenues worth of great restaurants, restaurants and clubs--at every price range--be sure to ask the concierge for a map of the area.Tip: book on expedia or Hotels for best rates.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: My wife and I stayed for 3 nights. The location is not great for tourists. All of the tourist zones require either a cab ride or a subway ride, although 2 metro stations are convenient to the hotel. As for the hotel itself, it is huge. Just getting from the room to an exit takes 10 minutes at a good pace. However it may be worth it if you want a panaramic view of Tokyo. The tower has 40 stories. The size of the hotel also means that it is very crowded. On the flip side, the service was good, from the housekeeping, to the front desk to the concierge. The bed was comfortable and the bathroom was nicely appointed. An english language newspaper was delivered daily. There are numerous restaurants, but they are terribly expensive. The hotel has a pool, but you have to pay extra to use it.We paid about $225 US per night, which was a fair price for the hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: As others have written, a superb hotel with excellent service...especially the concierge. Two negatives are the tepannyaki restaurants on the grounds of the Japanese garden are exhorbitantly priced, which wouldn't have been an issue if the food wasn't superb as well. We ate at Seisen-tei where for $250 USD we would have rather spent $75 at Benihana in the US. Second negative, the hotel is a bit inconvenient to the subway (few block walk across heavy traffic) - they should offer a shuttle service during rainstorms or extreme heat and humidity (and it was).Ask for a room in the Tower with a view of the garden.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: WOW! is simply all I can say...this was my first visit to Japan and the New Otani welcomed us with open arms, showing us exactly what Japanese hospitality is all about.We honeymooned in Japan from July 25 - August 7th and loved every moment of it. We stayed 6 days in Tokyo at the new Otani. Though we did not have a room in the Tower building we paid $1400 on expedia for RT air on JAL from NY > Tokyo + 6 nights at Otani...thats a great deal. The rooms were nice and clean, there was some English TV stationed, as well as English radio. Broadband Internet was available for a reasonable fee in this hotel, bathrooms feature Japans famous smart toilets. (please see attached pictures.) Our first morning in Tokyo we had breakfast in the hotel's restaurant....BAD IDEA. We spent $36 on a simple Japanese/continental breakfast...we quickly learned that if you walked 5min (over the bridge and cross the street) there are restaurants of all kinds with very reasonable prices.The New Otani is a business hotel in downtown tokyo. It is centrally located to all subways and buses. If you travel by subway the the new Otani is located at the Akasaka-mitsuke subway station, from there you can catch the red, orange, purple and green subway lines. Subways operate on a "pay per distance" policy, so the further you have to go the more you would pay..an average subway ride is 190YEN ($1.90).The Japanese garden located on the grounds of the New otani was spectacular, its something that you must stop and take in if you ever stay at this hotel....its simple amazing you could have such calm in the middle of tokyo.Tokyo and Japan is an awesome place, if you are considering it even in the least...let me tell you, GO...its well worth the (14hr flight) trip.Few places around the New Otani worth visiting.Tokyo Tower -- They boast that its taller than the effel tower in paris...we've been to both and Tokyo tower is taller by an antenna's lenght :-), it is however worth the tripRoppongi district --- this is like New York meets Tokyo...they have everything from TGI Fridays and Applebees to KFC and Wendys...among other US retail stores and such...if you are homesick, you can always re-up in Roppongi. If you are into Dancehall and Reggae music, you can check out this nightclub called "Club Jamaica" its located in Roppongi, they have a website as well, google it...its a hole in the wall spot but you will NOT be disappointed, the best marker I can give you is that its next to a 7-11, which is one of the only ones in this district (subway gray or purple line)Akihabara -- Electronics galore, take it from me (Im a hardcore techy geek who spends tons on new gadgets) this place will drive you mad...technology overload, serious gadget lusting. But dont get too caught up in the madness...you can find better priced goods on the Internet. Some products like digicams are reasonably priced and you can get an english manual to most if you just ask (subway gray line)Ueno -- You have got to vist the Ueno Zoo...they have some really unique animals you might not have seen before in teh US. (subway gray or orange line)Cities worth visiting around Tokyo:Yokohama - If you love dancehall and reggae music like I do you need to check out the Yokohama nightlife scene, its incredible, I'm a native borned Jamaican and they were showing ME all the new dances.Kamakura - Ok, we all know Japan is not known for its beaches, but I really enjoyed the beach in Kamakura...something about that black sand the and history behind it makes me proud that I was able to just be a part of that. This city is also very beautiful and worth a few hours just walking around and browsing the local crafts shops. The giant Budda statue is worth the visit, but the 40 YEN to enter the buddah is a total rip (even if its just 40cents)...there is NOTHING to see inside the budda...you climb 4 steps and thats it...a big hollow, empy...nothing!My Best advice for first time travellers is to get an english map of whatever prefectures (cities) you vist, they are always available at the train or bus stations. Secondly, dont be afraid to ask for directions...I was VERY surprised to find that most Japanese speak at least a little english and were more than willing to help us navigate. It helped cause we had a map so we would simply just point to where we needed to go...the ones who couldn't speak english would actually gesture to follow them...they would walk us to where we need to be, bow and walk away, Forget what you heard, there is no such thing as a language barrier in Japan...speak slowly and use proper english and most japaneese will be able to understand and help you. Get a Japan Rail (JR) Pass...if you intend to say in Tokyo and its immediate areas then its useless, however if you decide to take the shinkansen (bullet) trains to other cities like Kyoto or Hiroshima you will need this, or prepare to spend a small fortune on rail transportation. Remember your JR pass does not apply to Nozomi (express) trains or Green Cars (think first class) on any train....also note that all Shinkansen's seats are reserved so you must show your pass and get a seat rez to ride the train. The Narita Express (JR train from Narita Airport terminal 2) will run you about $30 per person to Tokyo station if you do not have a JR pass. Japan Rail and subway systems is sooo simple I only wish New York and other major cities would adopt the same standards. Good LuckDid I mention I LOVE JAPAN?

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed for a total of 6 nights (4 nights, then a break to Kyoto, then returned for another 2 nights) at the New Otani Tokyo in September 2005 and enjoyed it. Although it is not a hip or trendy hotel, it has great rooms (superior room in the Tower was enormous - by any standards) with top views either of the 400-year old garden or the city of Tokyo, is close to the metro and the service is outstanding. All of the staff to a person bent over backwards (er, forwards, actually) to help in every way possible. I had originally booked our first 4 nights through Expedia (at an amazing £74/nt rate) but had not committed to the second leg of our Tokyo trip, as I wasn't sure whether we would want to change areas (maybe to Roppongi). In the end, our stay was so nice, we decided to return for our last 2 nights in Tokyo. When I talked to the front desk, they were very helpful and suggested that if I wasn't happy with the best rate they could offer me (with the New Otani membership I got on their website - get one - it's free and you get discounts), I might want to try to get a better rate on the internet, as I had before. They even offered to let me use the manager's PC, as the business center was closed at that time of night!The only "complaint" I have is the hotel is so enormous that it takes about 10 minutes to walk from the main lobby to the Tower (the metro is closer to the Tower entrance, anyhow) and you have to change elevator banks to get to the Tower rooms. But frankly, that is nothing compared to the many benefits of staying there.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We were pleasantly surprised witht the New Otani Hotel. We had received a ridiculously cheap rate -- $169 per night -- so we figured our room size would reflect that rate. Not at all! Our room was bigger than many of our past NYC rooms and came with great amenities -- robes, slippers, toothbrush and toothpaste, razors, soaps, etc. We had plenty of space for our two huge suitcases and all the souvenirs we collected over our week's stay. Plus it was spotless. The hotel was sprawling as well. It contained dozens of restaurants (most unfortunately out of our budget), shopping, a pool, a 400 year garden with adorable koi, and many helpful staff members. We also discovered a secret on their website --sign up for the club card. With membership, you are entitled complimentary breakfast (bagels and juice, more than enough to start your day) and free use of the pool (usually over $30). It also had a classy bar and was very close to the metro stop. I highly reccomend this hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I didn't think the New Otani was that great. There are plenty of other hotels in Tokyo that are less expensive, in a more centrally located area, and have better amenities.I stayed in the Tower and didn't think it was that great. The room was OK, but I didn't think the overall facilities (either the bar at the top of the Tower) or the bar downstairs were that great. To use the workout facility you had to pay ~$50 USD just for the day. Everything else was similary expensive. The hotel is somewhat convenient located to a train station, but to go anywhere fun other than the Imperial Palace you had to take the subway, which in my book doesn't make the location all that convenient.I specifically picked this place because of its popularity index being #3 for hotels in Tokyo, but I was really disappointed. There are a few other hotels that I would have ranked higher than this one.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: Having stayed at the New Otani as a child over 36 years ago, I recently returned for a five night stay this past July. While it may be true that the hotel is a bit dated, it certainly is still a grand old hotel. Service throughout this large complex was impeccable; everyone seemed to have a friendly, helpful attitude and I was repeatedly touched by many small acts of kindness. My room in the Tower building had great views of the bustling city below, wonderful linens, and a beautiful bathroom well stocked with high-end toiletries. It was immaculately maintained by housekeeping who seemed to have a sixth sense of when I would be out of the room. The hotel's location is superb; the Akasaka-Mitsuke subway station is a few minute walk (mostly via underground passageway) and provides access to 5 major lines: Ginza, Marunouchi, Hanzomon, Yurakucho, and Chiyoda. The Akasaka district itself has some wonderful dining options including a branch of SushiSei where the remarkably fresh fish and the friendly staff make for an irresistable combination.Yes, prices in the hotel's restaurants, bars, and shops can be high. And I was disappointed that the (great) high speed internet access in my room came with a hefty price tag. But this is a luxury hotel in one of the world's most expensive cities. And there are some tricks. Join the New Otani Club online -- (free) membership provides access to a lounge with complementary coffee, juice, and pastries every morning. Find the AM/PM convenience store in the Garden Court building (part of the hotel complex); you will be glad of it. But if you are going to stay here do not deny yourself some of this wonderful hotel's pleasures. Afternoon tea in the Garden Lounge overlooking the 400 year-old gardens. A drink in the Capri Bar whose amazingly polished bartenders also turned out to be remarkably friendly. And a meal in the revolving restaurant at the top of the Main building. While I've had better Chinese food, and the whole thing turned just a bit too fast for my taste, the views of Tokyo are stunning. A great hotel.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I wish TripAdvisor gave have a 6-star system. On this most recent trip to Japan I stayed in the New Otani, Park Hyatt, and Park Hotel. I must admit that while the New Otani is a very nice hotel and is certainly "above average", it was my least favorite of the three we stayed in.Here is my dilemma using the TripAdvisor system, with only 5-stars to work with and no star increments. The Park Hyatt is clearly in a class by itself. I would give it 6-stars as "beyond excellent" but TripAdvisor only offers a maximum of five. Thusly, the Park Hotel, an excellent, chic hotel in a very up and coming section of Tokyo should only receive 4 stars, since it is a clear step down from the Park Hyatt. So then, I am thus relegated to giving the New Otani 3 stars since it is a slight step down from the Park Hotel. Perhaps if I could give half stars it would get 3.5 stars but unfortunately, it cannot reach 4 stars because of the excellent company that I am comparing it to.Onto the hotel. The hotel is obviously quite nice but, as previous reviewers have stated, seems a little dated. It unfortunately cannot yet be called historic but is too old to play with the uber-hotels opened in the last 5-10 years. My tower room was adequately sized, comfortable, and offered a great view of the garden and waterfall, arguably the hotel's best feature. The bathroom in the room, while not luxurious was very well put together. All the fixtures were first-rate, the towels soft and clean, and everything laid out and constructed in an intelligent manner. The room had a slight musty smell to it that was not necessarily bad or overpowering but it was present. It wasn't at all strong enough to put a damper on our stay but it was undeniable.My biggest complaint with the hotel is the price of food and other basic services. I had no problem seeing dealing with the prices at the Park Hyatt, arguably the most expensive hotel in Tokyo, but here it seemed there was no relief. They wanted to charge $50 p/p to use their pool, and there is hardly a restaurant among the 20+ on-site that allows an individual to eat a meal for less that $50.00 p/p. I know Tokyo was recently voted the world's most expensive city, etc, etc, but this kind of annoyed me. I thought La Tour D'Argeant was suitable because of the legendary history behind the Paris branch, but $20.00 for a small piece of cake in their Garden Lounge was a little bit ridiculous. Enjoyable, but way overpriced. On the restaurant front, I recommend walking to to BelleView (I believe that's what it is called) building and eating at Daidaiya. The vibe is super chic, with young waiters in sharp suits, and the food is very creative modern approaches to mainly traditional Japanese cuisine. The Buta Kakuni (Braised Pork Belly w/ skin) was a culinary revelation, and this is someone who defines his life by the memorable meals and dishes he eats.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: This must have been some hotel when it first opened ... seems a little dated now, but nonetheless well worth experiencing. Stayed in a tower room with an extraordinary view of the city--at night it was quite amazing. We arrived fairly late in the evening and were given a corner room. It was very large by Japanese standards and had three beds and a huge bathroom (separate shower room in granite that was quite lovely).Ate in the top of the tower bar at night--way overpriced, but nice to do. Other restaurants, and there are probably 20 or so in the hotel as a whole, also expensive though there were some good deals for hotel residents.As others have said, the gardens are beautiful, an oasis in a crowded, noisy and polluted city.Short walk to the subway from the hotel and since there's not a lot of attractions (restaurants, bars) in the area this is just as well. Took a while to get out of the hotel complex because it's simply so large. Size also made for anonymity. Not the personal touches and service that had begun to seem commonplace after the other hotels we stayed at. But the prices are better than many other hotels--got a great rate on the hotel's website, better than anything on offer via Expedia etc.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I'm not sure what else you should expect besides first rate service at a hotel where both Yon-sama and President Bush stayed. The hotel is attached to a huge complex of hotels and shops located at various levels of the complex. The restaurants all tend to be pricey, I ate one night at the buffet at the top level, and the food was decent but I can't say it matched the price I paid. You would be better off eating outside of the hotel. There is an absolutely gorgeous Japanese garden located within the hotel grounds, one of the most beautiful I've seen in Japan. The rooms are spacious and modern with a fax machine and all the other expected amenities (even internet for a fee). The bathrooms have marble countertops and are spacious by even by western standareds. I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani Hotel for 5 nights May into June on holiday. My room was in The Main and was spacious, comfortable, well appointed and spotlessly clean. As well as a flat screen TV, there was a choice of radio stations available (including the hotel's piped classical selection) and nice touches such as electric curtain controls and "all room lights off" switches by the bed.The bathroom had razors and shave foam and toothbrush/paste provided as well as normal hotel toiletries, towels and bathrobes replaced daily and a Japanese Yukata robe too. An unusual feature was a small TV in there too and the electro-bidet toilet (very Japanese!!) was fun!!Service was excellent and attentive in all areas and the staff make one feel like a celebrity. They all speak excellent English too. There were a good selection of restaurants to choose from although the dining times 5-9pm were a bit early for us and only a couple of places stayed open for dinner till 10pm. Food was great in Blue Sky (Chinese buffet) and Aux Bacchanales (French bistro) and in Garden Room which has a superb view of the Japanese garden and does a nice Continental breakfast buffet.Hotel is huge and with the three buildings takes some exploring. It takes about 10 minutes from the lobby of The Main to walk out via the Garden Court and then the Akasaka Underground Passageway to reach the actual Akasaka-Mitsuke subway station and some of the lines at Nagatacho station were even further, but its pretty straightforward and as the two stations have 5 lines in total it makes it a very good base for exploring.All in all it was the best hotel I have stayed in and would definitely recommend it to anyone visiting Tokyo for a holiday.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: I made the mistake of booking a business-class hotel in Tokyo, the Listel. The room was tiny, and the window looked directly out into another building. I checked out the next morning and headed for the New Otani and never regretted my decision despite the extra cost. The room was large by Tokyo standards and I had a great view from the 37th floor. The staff was wonderful, I felt very well-cared for. Treat yourself to an in-room massage, which costs just $60. When I go to Tokyo again, I will definitely stay again at the New Otani.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: We stayed at the main building, which although not as tall, was great nonetheless. The hotel also prices the main building more expensive than the newer tower building. This is a huge hotel, with the fabulous garden in the back, and is well equipped with everything you would want and more of a 4-star hotel...but it's not new. It's well taken care of, but does show its age in the design so it was not a problem at all. Although we reserved a room with a single king bed, we had the fortune of getting a corner room (2 full-size beds though) which provided a great deal of extra space in the form of a semi-separate living room. It's not quite a suite, but definitely not the standard rectangular room. Our room had a garden view, but I didn't find the view of the garden particularly inspiring because looking straight down on it does it no justice. Instead, the faint view of Mt. Fuji in the distant horizon hidden behind the hazy clouds was what did it for me. The hotel is also conveniently located within several stations from the main districts without being smack in the middle of the dense madness. GREAT STAY!

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: 30 years ago my father stayed here and I wanted to follow in his footsteps. Ask for a room with a view of the garden and as high as possible. The mixture of old Japan and the view of the city at night is brilliant. The hotel has a revolving restaurant that serves excellent Chinese food and a fantastic view of the whole city. Service is excellent, the fastest I have ever experienced and the rooms are beautiful. You must stay here if you want luxury, decadence and fun.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: If your staying in Tokyo for the first time, I highly suggest you stay at the New Otani. The rooms are gorgeous, and most have GREAT views. We had an awesome view of Mt. Fuji! The service is excellent, as the staff will go to any length to make your stay the best. The hotel itself is huge, and is very comparable to a shopping mall, with many stores andrestauraunts. Outside, theres a beautiful garden, once belonging to the emperor of Japan, where people can walk through and feel at bliss. Also, theres a resturaunt in the hotel with a clear glass wall, so everyone can get a mezmorizing view of the garden. All in all, I would say this has got to be one of, if not BEST hotel in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Hotel New Otani Tokyo The Main
review_body: A key reason that I chose this hotel was for its wonderful Japanese garden that nobody should miss. Within the Japanese garden, there is a garden chapel (a real chapel unlike many chapels solely for wedding purpose in other hotels) in which I and my wife attended the Sunday service on a beautiful morning after a walk in the garden. The hotel is huge with a good number of shops like a mall. When we stayed there, the hotel was almost full and we just felt like we were in a small downtown area.We stayed at the deluxe tower room on 34/F which commanded spectacular city view facing Tokyo Tower (the garden view, if available, would even be better). The room is huge and the bathroom is spacious and completed with excellent amenities.The location of the hotel is also very good, 3 minutes walk to the nearest subway and 10 minutes to Shinjuku or Shibuya by subway.The only drawback would probably be the price and the crowd that you saw during rush hours (check-in/out time).
